parks.fullName: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site
parks.description: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site features a reconstructed 1840s adobe fur trading post on the mountain branch of the Santa Fe Trail where traders, trappers, travelers, and the Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes came together in peaceful terms for trade. Today, living historians recreate the sights, sounds, and smells of the past with guided tours, demonstrations and special events.

entranceFees.description: The fee allows visitors to experience the fort and its rooms and meet and visit with period-clothed interpreters. It is a per person charge.  Payment allows the holder to visit the site for one day on the date of purchase. The park collects a Living History fee of $3 for adults, $2 for 6-12 year olds with children under 6 years age free. The park collects a $5 person event fee (fee subject to change) for anyone 6 years or older during major events. Fees are collected at the fort. Credit cards are preferred.
entranceFees.title: Bent's Old Fort Living History Fee

entrancePasses.description: The fee allows visitors to experience the fort and its rooms and meet and visit with period-clothed interpreters. It is a per person charge.  Payment allows the holder to visit the site for one day on the date of purchase. The park collects a Living History fee of $3 for adults, $2 for 6-12 year olds with children under 6 years age free. The park collects a $5 person event fee (fee subject to change) for anyone 6 years or older during major events. Fees are collected at the fort. Credit cards are preferred.
entrancePasses.title: Bent's Old Fort Living History Fee

parks.directionsInfo: The park is accessed via U.S. Highway 50 and Highway 194. From La Junta, Colorado on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 109 north 1 mile to Colorado Highway 194, then east on Colorado Highway 194 six miles to the fort. From Las Animas, Colorado, on U.S. Highway 50, take Colorado Highway 194 west 13 miles. Set your GPS to 35110 State Highway 194 E., La Junta, CO.

operatingHours.description:
Summer Hours (Memorial Day Weekend to Indigenous Peoples' Day)
The fort is open from 8:00 am to 5:30 pm. The gate is open from 7:00 am to 5:30 pm.

Winter Hours (the day after Indigenous Peoples' Day to the day before Memorial Day Weekend)
The fort is open from 9:00 am to 4:00 pm, except on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day, when the fort will be closed. The gate is open from 7:00 am to 4:00 pm, except on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort in background with wagon in front; fall yellow cottonwood leaves in foreground
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort with shortgrass prairie in foreground and blue sky and clouds above
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: Open hearth cooking in the fort kitchen
images.altText: Cooking in fort kitchen
images.caption: Buffalo meat is broiled in the reflector oven as was done historically in the 1840s.

images.title: Fur trapper explains the work of the 1830s.
images.altText: Fur trapper in camp
images.caption: Special events bring the past alive with encampments, fort trade and Plains Indian life.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort
images.altText: Bent's Old Fort with shortgrass prairie, tepee and wagon in foreground and blue sky & clouds above
images.caption: For much of its 16-year history, the fort was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail between Missouri and the Mexican settlements.

images.title: A Lakota warrior barters with the traders in the fort plaza
images.altText: Plains Indian trade in plaza
images.caption: Trade with a Lakota warrior for trade goods from around the world.

images.title: Swivel cannon is fired using 18th century drill
images.altText: Swivel cannon firing
images.caption: The fort's security depended on its ability to resist attack.

images.title: Hiking the Santa Fe Trail
images.altText: HIkers follow behind the fort's wagon on the Santa Fe Trail
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail Encampment features a hike with the fort's wagon down the original Santa Fe Trail.

images.title: Santa Fe Trail Encampment and Trail Hike
images.altText: Interpreters and volunteers in period clothing on horseback and in wagons; group of people standing
images.caption: The Park features the Santa Fe Trail Encampment during certain years. Historical interpreters bring the fort to life. Visitors can hike 3 miles down the original Santa Fe Trail with the fort's wagons.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer temperatures are are often in the high 90s and low 100s. Weather is generally fair in the fall and spring. Winter temperatures can be below freezing. Most of the fort is unheated and does not have modern cooling systems, so dress accordingly.
parks.name: Bent's Old Fort

parks.description: Bering Land Bridge National Preserve lies at the continental crossroads that greatly influenced the distribution of life in the Western Hemisphere during the Pleistocene Epoch. It is a vital landscape for indigenous communities who depend on the land just as their ancestors did for many generations. It is a wild and ecologically healthy landscape unlike any other.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter the preserve.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: The Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center is located in Nome, AK. Nome, AK is not on the road system and may be reached via a commercial flight. The Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center is located about a mile from Nome Airport. Bering Land Bridge National Preserve is located in the northern portion of the Seward Peninsula. There are no roads or trails into the parklands. Logistics on how to reach Bering Land Bridge is based on an individual’s resources and abilities.

operatingHours.description: Bering Land Bridge Preserve is open 24/7 year round. Due to its remote location accessing the preserve can be challenging, costly and time consuming.
operatingHours.name: Bering Land Bridge National Preserve

images.title: Wet Muskox
images.altText: Three wet muskox stand in a line.
images.caption: Three wet muskox.

images.title: Fall Colors
images.altText: A hiker is seen in the distance as autumn colors dominate the tundra landscape.
images.caption: Autumn hike at Bering Land Bridge

images.title: Coastal Moon Rise
images.altText: Rolling sand dunes with sparse vegetation with full moon rising above.
images.caption: Coastal moon rise

images.title: Aerial View of Serpentine Hot Springs in Summer
images.altText: A vast expanse of undulating hills with granite spire jutting from the top.
images.caption: A small aircraft descends on Serpentine Hot Springs.

images.title: Flock of shore birds
images.altText: Flock of shore birds taking flight
images.caption: Flock of shore birds taking flight

parks.weatherInfo: Weather in the Seward Peninsula is generally characterized by long freezing winters and short, cool summers. Coastal areas typically have mild weather, while the interior has greater seasonal variation in temperature and precipitation.
parks.name: Bering Land Bridge

parks.description: There is a place in Far West Texas where night skies are dark as coal and rivers carve temple-like canyons in ancient limestone. Here, at the end of the road, hundreds of bird species take refuge in a solitary mountain range surrounded by weather-beaten desert. Tenacious cactus bloom in sublime southwestern sun, and diversity of species is the best in the country. This magical place is Big Bend...

entranceFees.description: This fee includes all occupants of a private, non-commercial vehicle and is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Per Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Fee applicable to one motorcycle; valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Fee applicable to one individual walking in or bicycling in and is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Individual

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups with a vehicle capacity of 15 or less pay a per vehicle fee.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial groups with vehicle capacity 15 or less

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups with a vehicle capacity of 16 or more pay a $12.00 per person fee. Children 15 and younger are free. Annual and lifetime passes may be used.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial groups with vehicle capacity of 16 or more

entranceFees.description: $12 per client; passes may not be used. Business is required to obtain commercial use authorization. Bus tours, 25 person capacity or greater, $200 (commercial use authorization not required).
entranceFees.title: Commercial Group Fee

entrancePasses.description: The Big Bend Annual Pass covers entrance fees to Big Bend National Park. Pass is available at Big Bend National Park entrance stations or the Panther Junction Visitor Center. Pass is non-transferable.
entrancePasses.title: Big Bend Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Several highways lead to Big Bend National Park: TX 118 from Alpine to Study Butte or FM 170 from Presidio to Study Butte (then 26 miles east to park headquarters) or US 90 or US 385 to Marathon (then 70 miles south to park headquarters). Distances between towns and services are considerable. Be sure you have plenty of gas, food, water, and supplies for your trip.

operatingHours.description: Big Bend National Park is always open. You can enter and exit at any time of the day or night. Park entrances are open 24 hours daily, all year.
operatingHours.name: Big Bend National Park

images.title: Blooming Cenizo
images.altText: Blooming Cenizo
images.caption: Cenizo, or Big Bend Silverleaf blossoms after summer rains.

images.title: Century Plant Agave
images.altText: Century Plant Agave
images.caption: Century Plants bloom only once in their long lives.

images.title: Vermilion Flycatcher
images.altText: Vermilion Flycatcher
images.caption: Big Bend is home to over 450 species of birds!

images.title: Fascinating Geology
images.altText: Fascinating Geology
images.caption: Volcanic features abound near Castolon

images.title: Desert Scenery
images.altText: Desert Scenery
images.caption: Big Bend is a prime example of Chihuahuan Desert

images.title: Santa Elena Canyon
images.altText: Santa Elena Canyon
images.caption: Santa Elena Canyon

images.title: View from the South Rim of the Chisos
images.altText: View from the South Rim of the Chisos
images.caption: Big Bend is a place of expansive views

images.title: Rio Grande Scene
images.altText: Rio Grande Scene
images.caption: The Rio Grande serves as the park's southern boundary

images.title: Blooming Ocotillo
images.altText: Blooming Ocotillo
images.caption: When ocotillo bloom, they transform the desert

images.title: Balanced Rock
images.altText: Balanced Rock
images.caption: The balanced rock is a popular day hiking destination.

images.title: Top of the Lost Mine Trail
images.altText: Top of the Lost Mine Trail
images.caption: Hiking the Lost Mine Trail affords many amazing views.

images.title: Chisos Mountains
images.altText: Chisos Mountains
images.caption: The Chisos Mountains rise above the desert

parks.weatherInfo: Big Bend is a desert park, so be prepared for extreme conditions. SPRING: From February through April the park abounds with pleasant and comfortable temperatures. SUMMER: May through September is very hot. Temperatures will exceed 100 degrees in the lower elevations by late morning, and often exceed 110 along the Rio Grande. Afternoon thunderstorms can be a welcome respite. WINTER: October through January temperatures are cooler; the weather can quickly turn cold at any time during these months.
parks.name: Big Bend

parks.description: The freshwaters of the Big Cypress Swamp, essential to the health of the neighboring Everglades, support the rich marine estuaries along Florida's southwest coast. Conserving over 729,000 acres of this vast swamp, Big Cypress National Preserve contains a mixture of tropical and temperate plant communities that are home to diverse wildlife, including the Endangered Florida panther.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Big Cypress National Preserve
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Big Cypress is located along Tamiami Trail East and I-75 in southern Florida. The preserve can be accessed by driving from Miami and Naples. The preserve's two visitor centers are located along Tamiami Trail East.

operatingHours.description: The preserve is open 24 hours a day 365 days a year.  The Oasis Visitor Center and the Nathaniel P. Reed Visitor Center are closed on December 25th. No fee is charged for access to the preserve.
operatingHours.name: Big Cypress National Preserve

images.title: Florida Panther
images.altText: a Florida Panther sits in a tree
images.caption: The Florida Panther is one of the most iconic animals of Big Cypress

images.title: Alligators of Big Cypress
images.altText: Two Alligators rest on a river bank
images.caption: Two Alligators rest on a river bank

images.title: Canoeing through mangrove tunnels
images.altText: two visitors in a canoe go through mangrove tunnels on the Turner River
images.caption: Canoeing is one of the many activities you can enjoy in Big Cypress

images.title: Prairies and Pine Lands in Big Cypress
images.altText: A prairie foreground with tall pine trees in the background. A large blue sky with white cloud
images.caption: large open expanses of prairie bordered by pine lands create stunning landscapes

images.title: Sunrise in Big Cypress
images.altText: palm trees emerge out of the fog in an orange sunrise
images.caption: palm trees emerge out of the fog as an orange sunrise dots the landscape

parks.weatherInfo: Big Cypress National Preserve experiences two predominant seasons- wet and dry. RAINY SEASON (May through October) While visiting during this season you may find daily afternoon thunderstorms, high humidity, temperatures in the mid-to-high 80s and a multitude of mosquitoes. DRY SEASON (November through April) Falling water levels within Big Cypress make this a pleasant time to hike, camp, and watch wildlife.
parks.name: Big Cypress

parks.description: On August 9, 1877 gun shots shattered a chilly dawn on a sleeping camp of Nez Perce. By the time the smoke cleared on August 10, almost 90 Nez Perce were dead along with 31 soldiers and volunteers. Big Hole National Battlefield was created to honor all who were there.

entranceFees.description: Big Hole is fee free!
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

entrancePasses.description: There are no entrance fees to Big Hole National Battlefield or Bear Paw Battlefield.
entrancePasses.title: Entrance Passes

parks.directionsInfo: Big Hole National Battlefield is located on Highway 43 ten miles west of the town of Wisdom in southwestern Montana. Bear Paw Battlefield is located on Route 240 sixteen miles south of the town of Chinook in north-central Montana.

operatingHours.description: The park is open from sunrise to sunset year round.  At the park you can enjoy the visitor center, observation deck and walking trails.  Please refer to visitor center hours for times as to when the visitor center is open.  The observation deck is located off the west side of our visitor center, open year round and provides a great view of the entire battlefield.  The walking trails are accessed from our lower parking lot during the summer and from our upper gate during the winter.
operatingHours.name: Big Hole National Battlefield Visitor Center

images.title: Battlefield at Dawn
images.altText: Multiple tepee poles and a river are silhouetted against a dawn sky.
images.caption: Today tepee poles stand sentinel at the site of August 9th, 1877 dawn attack at the Big Hole.

images.title: Camas Blooms Near the Nez Perce Camp at the Big Hole
images.altText: Blue camas flowers dot a green field with tepee poles in the background.
images.caption: The Nez Perce chose their camp site in the Big Hole in part due to the Camas, whose roots they gathered prior to the August 9th attack.

images.title: Mountain Howitzer at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: a cannon overlooks a valley and distant mountains
images.caption: Nez Perce warriors captured and dismantled the Mountain Howitzer cannon before the US army could use it effectively at the Battle of the Big Hole.

images.title: Monument to the US Soldiers and Volunteers at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: cross country skis rest against a large granite monument on a snowy day.
images.caption: In 1883 the United States Government erected this monument in honor of the soldiers and volunteers that served and died at the 1877 Battle of the Big Hole.

images.title: Chief Joseph Memorial at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.altText: Stone carving of a Nez Perce Warrior's head in full regalia.
images.caption: This monument, erected on the Big Hole Battlefield in 1928, reads; "To the everlasting memory of the brave warriors Chief Joseph's Band who fought on these grounds in the Nez Perce War of 1877."

images.title: Bear Paw Battlefield
images.altText: Three large stone monuments and four interpretive signs overlook a series of low hills.

parks.weatherInfo: This climatic region is typified by large seasonal temperature differences, with warm to hot (and often humid) summers and cold (sometimes severely cold) winters. Wisdom has a humid continental climate.
parks.name: Big Hole

parks.fullName: Big South Fork National River & Recreation Area
parks.description: Encompassing 125,000 acres of the Cumberland Plateau, Big South Fork National River and Recreation Area protects the free-flowing Big South Fork of the Cumberland River and its tributaries. The area boasts miles of scenic gorges and sandstone bluffs, is rich with natural and historic features and has been developed to provide visitors with a wide range of outdoor recreational activities.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for Big South Fork NRRA.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Please use the following link to learn more about how to get here from various locations.

operatingHours.description: The park is always open.
operatingHours.name: Park Operating Hours

images.title: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.altText: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall
images.caption: Big South Fork NRRA in Fall

parks.weatherInfo: The weather along the Cumberland Plateau can be best described as unpredictable. Each season brings its own weather patterns. Summers are generally hot and humid, with high temperatures sometimes eclipsing 90 degrees. The low temperatures in winter often dip below freezing. Spring sees the most amount of precipitation, but rainfall can occur in various amounts throughout the year.
parks.name: Big South Fork

parks.description: Life of all types abounds in the Big Thicket. This national preserve protects the incredible diversity of life found where multiple habitats converge in southeast Texas. Hiking trails and waterways meander through nine different ecosystems, from longleaf pine forests to cypress-lined bayous. It is a place of discovery, a place to wander and explore, a place to marvel at the richness of nature.

entranceFees.description: Big Thicket National Preserve does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Free Admission

parks.directionsInfo: The main corridor through the Big Thicket is US 69/287 between Beaumont and Woodville. Many smaller roads and highways branch off of the main corridor to reach trailheads and scenic areas. The visitor center is located at the intersection of US 69/287 and FM 420, about 8 miles north of Kountze and 30 miles north of Beaumont.

operatingHours.description: Big Thicket National Preserve is open 24 hours a day. Primitive camping is permitted only with a camping permit, available at the visitor center.
operatingHours.name: All Park Hours

images.title: Big Thicket Swamp
images.altText: green swamp with cypress trees, cypress knees, palmetto, and a thick canopy
images.caption: Cypress swamp in the Lance Rosier Unit

images.title: Pitcher Plants
images.altText: A dense stand of funnel-shaped carnivorous pitcher plants awaiting their next insect meal.
images.caption: Look for carnivorous pitcher plants in bogs along the Sundew Trail and Pitcher Plant Trail.

images.title: Kayak on the river
images.altText: a woman kayaking on a river in autumn
images.caption: See the Big Thicket by kayak or canoe

images.title: Pine Savannah
images.altText: a man standing in an open forest of tall pines
images.caption: Tall pines loom over a hiker in the woods

images.title: Palmettos
images.altText: palmetto plants growing in the forest
images.caption: Dwarf palmettos grow in the Big Thicket's palmetto hardwood flats.

images.title: Cypress Tree Trunks
images.altText: a grouping of wide-buttressed bald cypress tree trunks growing out of a green, murky swamp
images.caption: Wide-buttressed trunks of bald cypresses

images.title: Cypress Knees
images.altText: Knobby cypress knees resembling cave stalagmites protrude up from a pool of water.
images.caption: Knobby knees, extensions of the root system, are a distinctive feature of the bald cypress trees.

images.title: Hiker on bridge over Village Creek
images.altText: A woman and her dog on a metal bridge spanning a creek lined with bald cypress trees.
images.caption: The view from the bridge over Village Creek is a highlight for hikers on the Kirby Nature Trail.

images.title: Kirby Nature Trail Bridge
images.altText: small wooden bridge in the forest
images.caption: Small wooden bridges guide hikers across waterways on the Kirby Nature Trail.

images.title: Longleaf Pines
images.altText: a stand of young longleaf pines growing near each other
images.caption: Young longleaf pines grow in a newly-replanted forest near the preserve's visitor center and headquarters.

images.title: Green Anole
images.altText: close up of a green anole lizard on a fence
images.caption: Green anoles are commonly seen in the Big Thicket

parks.weatherInfo: Southeast Texas is generally very hot and humid during late spring and summer. Fall brings comfortable temperatures. Winters are mild. Snow and subfreezing temperatures are uncommon. The Big Thicket region averages 55 inches of rainfall per year. Occasional tropical storms and hurricanes from the Gulf of Mexico bring powerful wind, rain, and flooding to the region. Hurricane season lasts from June 1 to November 30, with peak activity typically in September.
parks.name: Big Thicket

parks.description: The vast, wild landscape of Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area offers visitors unparalleled opportunities to immerse themselves in the natural world, and experience the wonders of this extraordinary place. With over 120,000 acres, one can find an astounding diversity in ecosystems, wildlife, and more than 10,000 years of human history to explore.

entranceFees.description: Access to the Bighorn Canyon NRA is not gated and there is no access fee.
entranceFees.title: Fee Free Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: Bighorn Canyon has two districts that are separated by a three hour drive. To get to the North District at Fort Smith, MT from Billings,take Interstate 90 south to Hardin, MT. Turn at exit 495 onto State Highway 313 to St. Xavier and then to Fort Smith, Montana. To get to the South District at Lovell, WY from Billings, MT, take Interstate 90 west. Turn at exit 434 at Laurel, MT. Turn onto US 310 East/US 212 South. Turn at US 310 East to Lovell. The visitor center is on the east side of Lovell.

operatingHours.description:
The park is open every day. 

The Yellowtail Dam visitor center in Fort Smith, MT is only open in the summer from Memorial Day to Labor Day. 

The Cal S. Taggart visitor center in Lovell, WY is open Tuesday - Saturday 8:30 - 4:30 and is closed Sundays and Mondays through the fall.
operatingHours.name: Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area Lovell, WY District

addresses.line1: Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area South District Visitor Center
Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area South District Visitor Center

images.title: Yellowtail Dam (Fort Smith, MT District)
images.altText: Summer view of the Yellowtail Dam from the Ok-A-Beh road.
images.caption: Summer view of the Yellowtail Dam from the Ok-A-Beh road. (Fort Smith, MT District)

images.title: Spring Cactus
images.altText: spring cactus with yellow flowers
images.caption: Spring Cactus

images.title: Kayaks at Barry's Landing (Lovell, WY District)
images.altText: Four orange kayaks laying with their tips on the red rocks at Barry's Landing.
images.caption: Kayaks at Barry's Landing ready to go. (Lovell, WY District)

images.title: Bighorn Sheep Overlooking the Canyon
images.altText: Bighorn Sheep Overlooking the Canyon
images.caption: Bighorn Sheep Overlooking the Canyon

images.title: Devil Canyon Overlook from Sullivan's Knob Trail (Lovell, WY District)
images.altText: Looking up canyon toward Devil Canyon from the rim at Sullivan's Kob.

images.title: On The Lake
images.altText: smooth water just south of Barry's Landing
images.caption: A Great Day on the Lake

images.title: Horseshoe Bend from the Sykes Mountain (Lovell, WY District)
images.altText: Red hills in the foreground with Bighorn Lake in the background with a brilliant blue sky.
images.caption: Horseshoe Bend from the Sykes Mountain (Lovell, WY District)

parks.weatherInfo: North District: Semi-arid, receiving 18 to 20 inches of rain annually. South District: High-desert, receiving 6 to 10 inches of rain annually. Summer temperatures: Highs in the 80s (F) and 90s (F), lows in the 50s (F) and 60s (F). Summer temperatures can peak over 100 degrees. Winter temperatures: Range in the 20s and 30s with low temperatures averaging the 10s (F) and 20s (F). During the winter the thermometer can drop below 0 (F) with extreme wind chill factors.
parks.name: Bighorn Canyon

parks.description: In 1963, images of snarling police dogs unleashed against non-violent protesters and of children being sprayed with high-pressure hoses appeared in print and television news around the world. These dramatic scenes of violent police aggression against civil rights protesters in Birmingham, Alabama were vivid examples of segregation and racial injustice in America.

emailAddresses.description: Birmingham Civil Rights National Monument Informational Inbox

entranceFees.description: No Entrance Fee. The interior of the A.G. Gaston Motel is currently closed to the public and updates for the Motel opening will be available on the NPS park website at a later date.
entranceFees.title: Birmingham Civil Rights National Monument

entranceFees.description:
Adults $15 ea.

Seniors (age 65+) $13 ea.

College students (with ID), Military with ID $13 ea.

Youth (grades 4-12 living in Jefferson County, Alabama) Free

Non-Jefferson County Youth (grades 4-12 living outside Jefferson County, Alabama) $13 ea.

Children (age 4 and younger) Free
entranceFees.title: Birmingham Civil Rights Institute Entrance Fees

parks.directionsInfo: Via I-65 North or South From I-65, take I-20/59 NE towards Atlanta. Exit at the 17th Street Exit (first exit off of I-20/59). Bear right and proceed to the light. From that light go two blocks to 6th Avenue N. Turn right on to 6th Avenue N. The Birmingham Civil Rights Institute is one block up on your left. A.G. Gaston Motel The interior of the A.G. Gaston Motel is currently closed to the public and updates for the Motel opening will be available on the NPS park website at a later date.

operatingHours.description: Birmingham Civil Rights National Monument brochures and NPS passport stamp are available for visitors at the Birmingham Civil Rights Institute on Sunday's, 1:00 - 5:00 PM and Tuesday - Saturday, 10:00 AM - 5:00 PM. The A.G. Gaston Motel is currently closed to the public and updates for the Motel opening will be available on the NPS park website at a later date.
operatingHours.name: Brochures and NPS Passport Book Available

images.title: Mural Sculpture of the four little girls
images.altText: 4 separate statues of the four little girls who were killed in the 16th st Baptist Church bombing
images.caption: Hundreds of people visit Kelly Ingram Park each year to learn about the Civil Rights Movement in Birmingham

images.title: Kelly Ingram Park foot soldiers statue
images.altText: Statue of a boy being grabbed by a policemen who is holding a dog posed to bite on a leash
images.caption: Statue in Kelly Ingram park dedicated to Birmingham Foot soldiers

images.title: 16th St. Baptist Church
images.altText: Colored Photo of the front of the 16th St. Baptist Church
images.caption: Hundreds of people visit Birmingham each year to see the 16th St. Baptist Church and learn about its important role in Birmingham's Civil Rights Movement

parks.weatherInfo: Temperatures can soar to extremes of heat and humidity in the summer and fall to damp, wet, cold in the winter. Visitors should dress in comfortable clothing during the summer season, wear comfortable shoes, and use sunscreen. Drink plenty of fluids to maintain hydration. In the spring and fall, visitors should have a light jacket available as temperatures can drop suddenly. Winter temperatures can be unpredictable, ranging from mild to extremely cold.
parks.name: Birmingham Civil Rights

parks.description: Within sight of Miami, yet worlds away, Biscayne protects a rare combination of aquamarine waters, emerald islands, and fish-bejeweled coral reefs. Evidence of 10,000 years of human history is here too; from prehistoric tribes to shipwrecks, and pineapple farmers to presidents. For many, the park is a boating, fishing, and diving destination, while others enjoy a warm breeze and peaceful scenery.

emailAddresses.description: If you can't find what you are looking for on the park website then e-mail us at bisc_information@nps.gov.

entranceFees.description: The park has no entrance fees.
entranceFees.title: No entrance fees.

entrancePasses.description: No entrance fees.
entrancePasses.title: No entrance fees.

parks.directionsInfo: The Dante Fascell Visitor Center may be reached from the Florida Turnpike by taking Exit 6 (Speedway Boulevard). Turn left from exit ramp and continue south to SW 328th Street (North Canal Drive). Turn left on 328th Street and continue for four miles to the end of the road. The park entrance is on the left just before the entrance to Homestead Bayfront Marina.

operatingHours.description: Park waters are open 24 hours a day, all year.
operatingHours.name: Park Waters

operatingHours.description: The Visitor Center features a museum, park films, art gallery, and a spectacular view of Biscayne Bay.
operatingHours.name: Dante Fascell Visitor Center

operatingHours.description: Launch your own canoe or kayak from the ramp near the parking area, enjoy a picnic on the lawn, or stroll along the jetty trail.
operatingHours.name: Convoy Point Grounds

images.title: Snorkeling
images.altText: Coral reef with two snorkelers diving below the surface
images.caption: Snorkeling is a great way to explore the coral reefs in the park

images.title: Boca Chita Key
images.altText: Downtown Miami in background.
images.caption: Boca Chita Key is the park's most popular island destination.

images.title: Coral Reef
images.altText: Underwater view of coral reef with a large school of yellow and blue fish
images.caption: The coral reef is home to many species of fish

images.title: Coral Reef
images.altText: The coral reefs are located mostly on the Eastern side of the park.
images.caption: Biscayne National Park is 95% water.

images.title: Green sea turtle
images.altText: Green sea turtle
images.caption: Loggerhead, Green and Hawksbill turtles are all commonly observed in park waters.

images.title: Totten Key
images.altText: Aerial view of Totten Key.
images.caption: Biscayne National Park includes the northernmost Florida Keys.

parks.weatherInfo: The park is situated in a subtropical climate, which ensures sunshine year-round. Winters are normally dry and mild, with occasional fronts bringing wind and little rain. Summer brings hot and humid weather with scattered thunderstorms in the afternoons. The average temperature in January is 68 degrees Fahrenheit and 82 in July. The average rainfall for the area is 2.17 inches in January and 3.95 inches in July. June to November is hurricane season.
parks.name: Biscayne

parks.fullName: Black Canyon Of The Gunnison National Park
parks.description: Big enough to be overwhelming, still intimate enough to feel the pulse of time, Black Canyon of the Gunnison exposes you to some of the steepest cliffs, oldest rock, and craggiest spires in North America. With two million years to work, the Gunnison River, along with the forces of weathering, has sculpted this vertical wilderness of rock, water, and sky.

operatingHours.description:
The park is open 24 hours a day, every day, and no entry reservation is needed. The South Rim Road is open to vehicles from early April to mid-November. In winter, the South Rim Road is open to Gunnison Point. The remainder of the road is closed to vehicles, but open to cross country skiing and snowshoeing.

South Rim Visitor Center hours are listed on the Basic Information page.

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day. North Rim Road is open intermittently in Summer and Fall. North Rim Road and ranger station are closed in winter. The road typically closes late November and reopens mid-April.

Summer daytime temperatures range between 55 to 90F (13 to 32C), nights 45 to 60F (7 to 16C). Winter daytime temperatures range between 15 to 40F (-9 to 4C), nights 10 to 20F (-12 to -6C). Afternoon thunderstorms are common during the summer. Snow accumulation varies greatly year to year. Layered clothing appropriate for the season is recommended.

parks.fullName: Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park
parks.description: The Blackstone River powered America's entry into the Age of Industry. The success of Samuel Slater's cotton spinning mill in Pawtucket, RI touched off a chain reaction that changed how people worked and where they lived, and continues to reverberate across the nation to this day. Come visit and see how this revolution transformed the landscape of the Blackstone Valley and then the United States.

entranceFees.description: At this point, the National Park Service does not charge any fees at the Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park. However, some of our partner sites do charge fees, as these sites are run by private, non-profit organizations.
entranceFees.title: Blackstone River Valley National Historical Park

parks.description: A Blue Ridge Parkway experience is unlike any other: a slow-paced and relaxing drive revealing stunning long-range vistas and close-up views of the rugged mountains and pastoral landscapes of the Appalachian Highlands. The Parkway meanders for 469 miles, protecting a diversity of plants and animals, and providing opportunities for enjoying all that makes this region of the country so special.

entranceFees.description: Driving the parkway is free.
entranceFees.title: No entrance fee

parks.directionsInfo: The parkway is a 469-mile-long scenic road connecting Shenandoah National Park in Virginia to Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina. Numerous federal and state highways provide access to the parkway. Milepost markers are positioned every mile along the parkway, starting at 0 in Virginia and ending at 469 in North Carolina. We suggest using a map to identify the area you want to visit, as GPS directions often do not incorporate the parkway's milepost system.

operatingHours.description:
The road is open 24 hours a day, weather permitting. Road closures due to inclement weather occur most frequently during winter. Sections of the road may also be closed during road maintenance projects. Check our road closure map to verify that the parkway is open before traveling.

Visitor centers and other facilities have hours and seasons that vary. Most picnic areas, campgrounds, and visitor centers are closed from the beginning of November until early May.
operatingHours.name: Parkway Road Hours

parks.weatherInfo: The weather on the parkway can vary widely along its 469-mile route. Precipitation is possible any time of the year. Winter can be cold and snowy, especially at the higher elevations. Spring and fall can have large temperature swings, from near freezing to over 80 degrees Fahrenheit. Summers are hot in the lower elevations, but the highest elevations remain cooler. Summertime thunderstorms are common, so be prepared for weather changes.
parks.name: Blue Ridge

parks.description: The Bluestone River and the rugged and ancient gorge it has carved is a richly diverse and scenic area of the southern Appalachians. Bluestone National Scenic River is preserved as a living landscape that provides an unspoiled experience for visitors and a haven for a variety of plants and animals. The park protects a 10.5-mile section of the Bluestone River in southern West Virginia.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for the park. Pipestem Resort State Park charges a small fee to ride the tram to and from the bottom at the entrance in Pipestem.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: Bluestone National Scenic River is most easily accessed via Bluestone State Park and Pipestem Resort State Park. A narrow, graveled park road provides access to the Bluestone Turnpike Trail at the former Lilly town site at the confluence of the Little Bluestone River. To reach these parks from I-64, take exit 139, then south on Rt. 20. From I-77 take exit 14 to Rt.20 north. Either direction, Bluestone State Park is 15 miles and Pipestem is 22 miles.

operatingHours.description: The park is accessible year-round at two entrance points, Bluestone State Park and the former Lilly townsite, and seasonally at Pipestem Resort State Park. The park is open 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Bluestone National Scenic River

parks.name: Bluestone

parks.description: Booker T. Washington was born a slave in April 1856 on the 207-acre farm of James Burroughs. After the Civil War, Washington became the first principal of Tuskegee Normal and Industrial School. Later as an adviser, author and orator, his past would influence his philosophies as the most influential African American of his era. Come explore his birthplace.

operatingHours.description: Booker T. Washington National Monument is open daily except for Thanksgiving, December 25, and January 1. The park may close due to inclement weather. Call the park at 540-721-2094 for more information.

parks.fullName: Boston African American National Historic Site
parks.description: Centered on the north slope of Beacon Hill, the African American community of 19th century Boston led the city and the nation in the fight against slavery and injustice. These remarkable men and women, together with their allies, were leaders in the Abolition Movement, the Underground Railroad, the Civil War, and the early struggle for equal rights and education.

emailAddresses.description: Please use this email for general inquiries.

parks.fullName: Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area
parks.description: . . . where you can walk a Civil War-era fort, visit historic lighthouses, explore tide pools, hike lush trails, camp under the stars, or relax while fishing, picnicking or swimming-all within reach of downtown Boston. Youth programs, visitor services, research, wildlife management, and more are coordinated on the park's 34 islands and peninsulas by the Boston Harbor Islands Partnership.

entranceFees.description:
Boston Harbor Islands is a Partnership park; fees and reservations vary. 

The park does not charge an admission fee, but a transportation fee applies for the public ferry. Reservations are recommended. Please note that National Park Land Passes do not cover transportation fees.

Visit bostonharborislands.org to plan your trip.
entranceFees.title: Fees and Reservations Vary

parks.directionsInfo: There are many ways to enjoy Boston Harbor Islands and many ways to get there. For more information on how to get to the park by ferry, car, or private boat, please visit www.bostonharborislands.org.

operatingHours.description:
Boston Harbor Islands is a Partnership park. Operating hours and seasons vary.

Visit bostonharborislands.org to plan your trip.
operatingHours.name: Boston Harbor Islands

Typical summer conditions feature air temperatures approximately 5-10 degrees cooler than the mainland between 60-80 Fahrenheit, winds of 0-15 knots and waves of 1-3 feet.

parks.description: Discover how one city could be the Cradle of Liberty, site of the first major battle of American Revolution, and home to many who espoused that freedom can be extended to all.

entranceFees.description:
There are no fees at the federally or municipally owned historic sites within Boston National Historical Park, including Faneuil Hall, Bunker Hill Monument, Bunker Hill Museum, USS Constitution, and the Dorchester Heights Monument.

Fees and suggested donations are collected at the park's privately owned and operated partner sites. These sites are maintained and run by self-supporting historical associations working cooperatively with Boston National Historical Park.

parks.directionsInfo: Visitor Centers are located at Historic Faneuil Hall, 1 Faneuil Hall Sq, and the Charlestown Navy Yard, Building 5. Go to the Directions page for more detailed information.

operatingHours.description:
Boston National Historical Park is a unique collaboration of federally, municipally, and privately owned and operated historic sites. Most of the park is along Boston's Freedom Trail®, a 2.5 mile (4 km) walking path marked by a red brick or painted line weaving through Downtown Boston, the North End, and Charlestown.

The trail itself is outdoors and open year round. Every site along the trail has its own hours which vary throughout the season. Please check ahead before planning your visit.
operatingHours.name: Boston National Historical Park

operatingHours.description: The Bunker Hill Monument is currently closed to climbing. The Monument grounds are open.
operatingHours.name: Bunker Hill Monument

operatingHours.description: Dorchester Heights marks the site of George Washington's first Revolutionary War victory. Located atop the last remaining hill in South Boston fortified by the Continental Army, the park grounds are open from dawn to dusk. The monument is currently not open to the public.
operatingHours.name: Dorchester Heights

operatingHours.description: Located in the heart of downtown on the market floor of the historic 1742 building, the Faneuil Hall Visitor Center is the main visitor center for Boston National Historical Park and Boston African American National Historic Site. Maps and information for the Freedom Trail and Black Heritage trail are available here. Tours begin here seasonally.
operatingHours.name: Faneuil Hall

operatingHours.description: The Paul Revere House is a Boston National Historical Park partner site operated by the Paul Revere Memorial Association.
operatingHours.name: Paul Revere House

operatingHours.description: Old North is a Boston National Historical Park partner site operated by the Old North Foundation of Boston.
operatingHours.name: Old North Church

operatingHours.description: The Old State House is a Boston National Historical Park partner site operated by Revolutionary Spaces.
operatingHours.name: Old State House

operatingHours.description: The Old South Meeting House is a Boston National Historical Park partner site operated by Revolutionary Spaces.
operatingHours.name: Old South Meeting House

operatingHours.description: The Great Hall is operated as a historic site by the National Park Service in partnership with the City of Boston. Faneuil Hall is owned and managed by the City of Boston. The Great Hall is closed to public visitation when City-permitted events are scheduled.
operatingHours.name: The Great Hall of Faneuil Hall

operatingHours.description: USS Constitution is the oldest commissioned ship in the United States Navy. Naval officers and crew still serve aboard her. The Navy operates the ship as a historic site in cooperation with the National Park Service.
operatingHours.name: USS Constitution

operatingHours.description: USS Constitution Museum collects, preserves, and interprets the stories of "Old Ironsides." The museum is a partner of Boston National Historical Park located in the Charlestown Navy Yard.
operatingHours.name: USS Constitution Museum

operatingHours.description: USS Cassin Young is a Fletcher Class destroyer docked in the Charlestown Navy Yard. Park staff operate the ship seasonally. Weather conditions may alter hours without advanced notice.
operatingHours.name: USS Cassin Young

parks.weatherInfo: Temperatures range from warm, humid summer days to cold New England winter days. Wear comfortable sportswear in season, with comfortable walking shoes.

parks.fullName: Brices Cross Roads National Battlefield Site
parks.description: The Confederate victory at Brices Cross Roads was a significant victory for Major General Nathan Bedford Forrest, but its long term effect on the war proved costly for the Confederates. Brices Cross Roads is an excellent example of winning the battle, but losing the war.

emailAddresses.description: For a quicker response please call the Parkway Visitor Center at 1-800-305-7417. A park ranger is available 7 days a week during business hours to answer your questions about the park. The visitor center is closed Thanksgiving, December 25th and January 1st.

entranceFees.description:
Brice's Cross Roads National Battlefield Site is free.

The Mississippi’s Last Stands Visitor and Interpretive Center is open 9 a.m. -5 p.m. Tuesday-Saturday. Admission is $5 for adults and $2 for children under 12 years old. Group rates are available.
entranceFees.title: No entrance fee

parks.directionsInfo: Brices Cross Roads National Battlefield Site can be found 15 miles north of Tupelo, Mississippi. Exit U.S. Highway 45 onto Mississippi 370, in Baldwyn, Mississippi. The battlefield is located 6 miles west of Baldwyn, on Mississippi 370. Visitors may also consider visiting the Mississippi's Final Stands Interpretive Center in Baldwyn. Exit U.S. Highway 45 at Mississippi 370 and turn east. Take the first right off of Highway 370 to the interpretive center.

operatingHours.description: The grounds of the Brices Cross Roads National Battlefield Site are open sunrise to sunset everyday of the year.
operatingHours.name: Brices Crossroads National Battlefield Site

images.title: Brices Crossroads Monument

parks.weatherInfo: Mississippi is classified as a humid subtropical climate, the weather ranges from mild winters to hot summers with high humidity between May and September. Average high temperatures reach into the high 80's in summer, and into the high 40's in winter. Check local forecasts to plan your trip.
parks.name: Brices Cross Roads

parks.fullName: Brown v. Board of Education National Historic Site
parks.description: The story of Brown v. Board of Education, which ended legal segregation in public schools, is one of hope and courage. When the people agreed to be plaintiffs in the case, they never knew they would change history. The people who make up this story were ordinary people. They were teachers, secretaries, welders, ministers and students who simply wanted to be treated equally.

entranceFees.description: Free Admission
entranceFees.title: Fees

parks.directionsInfo: The site is located in downtown Topeka, Kansas at 1515 SE Monroe Street.

operatingHours.description: We are currently open Tuesday through Saturday. We are closed for Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day.

parks.description: Hoodoos (irregular columns of rock) exist on every continent, but here is the largest concentration found anywhere on Earth. Situated along a high plateau at the top of the Grand Staircase, the park's high elevations include numerous life communities, fantastic dark skies, and geological wonders that defy description.

entranceFees.title: Private Vehicle - Valid for 7 days

It admits the purchaser and any accompanying persons in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or the purchaser and accompanying immediate family (spouse, children, parents) when entry is by other means (shuttle, bicycle, and foot). This pass covers entrance fees only and is not refundable and/or transferable.

parks.directionsInfo: From the North: Take I-15 south to UT-20 (exit 95). Travel east on UT-20 to US-89. Follow US-89 south to UT-12. Travel east on UT-12 to UT-63. Take UT-63 south to Bryce Canyon NP. From the South through Zion National Park: Take I-15 north to UT-9 (exit 16). Follow UT-9 east through Zion National Park to US-89. Travel north on US-89 to UT-12. Go east on UT-12 to UT-63. Take UT-63 south to Bryce Canyon NP. From the East Travel west on UT-12 to UT-63. Take UT-63 south to Bryce Canyon NP.

operatingHours.description: Visitor Center and Fee Booths are closed on Thanksgiving and Christmas Day.
operatingHours.name: Park is Open 24-7

images.title: Bryce Amphitheater from Inspiration Point
images.altText: A red rock landscape and plateau forest glows with the morning sun
images.caption: Viewpoints of the iconic Bryce Amphitheater are located along the first 3 miles of the park road and are a popular destination at sunrise.

images.title: Winter sunrise at Sunset Point
images.altText: Snow blankets a red rock landscape of tall rock spires beneath an early morning sky
images.caption: Here at 8,000' (2438 m) winter comes early and stays late. Snow transforms the landscape and requires seasonal closures in some areas and trails.

images.title: Milky Way over the Hoodoos
images.altText: The center of the Milky Way galaxy is seen rising above a horizon of forest and red rock spires
images.caption: Bryce Canyon's clean air and dark night skies are some of its most precious and vulnerable resources. Full moon nights also provide a unique experience of seeing the park after dark.

images.title: Queen's Garden Trail
images.altText: A lone white rock tower stands surrounded by red rock walls and forest along a trail
images.caption: More strenuous trails below the rim provide up-close views of the hoodoo rock spires, while easier walks along the rim give perspective from above.

images.title: Bristlecone Loop trail near Yovimpa Point
images.altText: Red and white rock cliffs lightly dusted with snow with a forest atop them and a long view beyond
images.caption: The park's highest elevations at its southern end and backcountry areas provide views of over 100 miles (161 km) atop high steep cliffs.

parks.weatherInfo: Due of its high elevation climate, weather at Bryce Canyon through autumn, winter, and spring can be highly variable. From October to May temperatures fall below freezing nearly every night. The park typically experiences its coldest and snowiest periods from December through February. Spring storms in March and April can still produce heavy snowfall that may impact travel in the region. Summer highs are typically in the 70s-80s F and afternoon thunderstorms are common in July and August.
parks.name: Bryce Canyon

parks.description: Welcome to Buck Island! Before you come, please watch our 2014 Telly Award winning film "Caribbean Gem." Watching this will catch you up on 50+ years of National Park Service protection and civic engagement. Learn what we do every day to preserve this resource for Virgin Islanders and visitors alike. For the General Management Plan and Environmental Compliance, visit the News page.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to Buck Island.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: No Entrance Pass
entrancePasses.title: No Entrance Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Use one of our concessionaires to get to Buck Island!

operatingHours.description: From March through September, Buck Island is open to visitors between 6:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. to 5:30 p.m, October through February. Anchoring is restricted to the West Beach anchoring area. An annual permit is required for all vessels, including those vessels entering the lagoon to access the underwater trail moorings or to scuba dive. Overnight use of the West Beach Anchoring Area requires a special overnight permit from Christiansted National Historic Site.
operatingHours.name: Buck Island Reef National Monument

images.title: Tropical dry forest, Buck Island
images.altText: Photograph of the trees and vegetation along the hiking trail on Buck Island
images.caption: The plants that make up the subtropical dry forest on Buck Island range from old historic tamarinds to gumbo limbo, from cactus to delicate orchids.

images.title: Snorkeling at Buck Island
images.altText: Photograph of snorkeler among the coral reefs at Buck Island
images.caption: Enjoy snorkeling the reefs and see lots of tropical reef fish.

images.title: Green sea turtle hatchling
images.altText: green sea turtle hatchling on beach heading towards the ocean
images.caption: For over 30 years scientists have studied sea turtle nesting habits on Buck Island, training over 100 students in the field of biology.

images.title: End of the rainbow
images.altText: Photograph of rainbow at Buck Island
images.caption: Buck Island is a magical place! Come snorkel the waters and hike the trails.

images.title: Beach at Buck Island
images.altText: the forest meets the sandy beach and waves
images.caption: Come see the unspoiled beauty of Buck Island

images.title: Buck Island from the water
images.altText: view of Buck Island from the water
images.caption: From the highest ridge to the water and reefs below, Buck Island offers adventure and learning.

images.title: Coral garden
images.altText: fish swimming among the corals
images.caption: Our underwater trail will take you through beautiful gardens of coral.

images.title: Hiking trail
images.altText: hiking trail wandering through a beachside forest
images.caption: Take our hiking trail through beach forests up to the observation deck at 300 feet above sea leve.

parks.description: Established in 1972, Buffalo National River flows freely for 135 miles and is one of the few remaining undammed rivers in the lower 48 states. Once you arrive, prepare to journey from running rapids to quiet pools while surrounded by massive bluffs as you cruise through the Ozark Mountains down to the White River.

entranceFees.description: None
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Buffalo National River is a long, narrow park that is crossed by three main highways. Highways 7, 43, and 62/65 are the main roads out of Harrison, Arkansas that will take you to the Buffalo River, depending on which part of the park you wish to visit. GPS systems are not reliable in this area so please call ahead for directions or pick up a map of the area beforehand.

operatingHours.description: Buffalo National River is 135 miles long. The park is open 24 hours.
operatingHours.name: Buffalo National River

images.title: Indian Rockhouse
images.altText: A large bluff shelter near Buffalo Point.
images.caption: Every year thousands of people hike to the Indian Rockhouse to admire this large bluff shelter.

images.title: Skull Rock
images.altText: Kayakers floating towards Skull Rock near Buffalo Point.
images.caption: A peaceful day on the Buffalo River as kayakers approach Skull Rock and Buffalo Point.

images.title: Steel Creek Campground
images.altText: Camping at Steel Creek
images.caption: Camping along the Buffalo River is a wonderful way to enjoy the park.

images.title: Floating the Buffalo
images.altText: Floaters on the river.
images.caption: Canoeing and kayaking the river is a wonderful way to spend a day at the Buffalo.

images.title: Sod Collier Homestead
images.altText: Historic homestead built by the Collier Family.
images.caption: Many historic structures are scattered along the Buffalo River reminding us of the hardworking settlers that once called this river valley home.

images.title: Smallmouth Bass Fishing
images.altText: Fisherman with smallmouth bass.
images.caption: Fishing for smallmouth bass is a popular activity on the Buffalo River.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer in the Ozarks can be very hot and humid. Please check the weather forecast prior to your arrival and plan accordingly. The weather the rest of the year has the potential to be wet and cool or dry and warm. Please pay special attention to river levels and the rain forecast when planning a trip on the river. River levels can rise dramatically in a short period of time so please be aware of conditions.
parks.name: Buffalo

parks.description: Climbing out of his boat and onto shore in 1542, Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo stepped into history as the first European to set foot on what is now the West Coast of the United States. In addition to telling the story of 16th century exploration, the park is home to a wealth of cultural and natural resources. Join us and embark on your own Voyage of Exploration.

Your group is welcome to come whenever it's convenient for you (no reservations are necessary), and we have plenty of bus parking available.

"Passenger Capacity" is based on the number of seats on the vehicle, rather than number of actual passengers.

The commercial pass is only valid for one visit.

parks.weatherInfo: Check the current weather from the National Weather Service at https://www.weather.gov/. San Diego's climate is characterized by warm, dry summers and mild winters, with most of the annual precipitation falling between December and March. The city has a mild climate year-round, with an average of 201 days above 70 °F (21 °C) and low rainfall (9–13 inches [230–330 mm] annually).
parks.name: Cabrillo

parks.description: Follow in the footsteps of over 250,000 emigrants who traveled to the gold fields and rich farmlands of California during the 1840s and 1850s: the greatest mass migration in American history. The California National Historic Trail is over 5,000 miles long and covers portions of 10 states. Step into history along more than 1,000 miles of ruts and traces from travelers and their overland wagons.

entranceFees.description: There are no user or entry fees for the California National Historic Trail. Fees may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please contact individual trail sites before visiting for more information.
entranceFees.title: Entrance fees vary site by site

parks.directionsInfo: Those portions of the California National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 2,000 miles of historic trail that was once the primary "road" taken by farmers, enterprising business managers, gold-seekers, and fortune hunters who chose to make a new life on the California frontier. The route passes through ten states from Missouri to California.

operatingHours.description: The California National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: California National Historic Trail

images.altText: A white canvas wagon sits in front of a large rock buttress with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: Wagon at Register Rock in City of Rocks National Reserve

images.caption: A creek in Carlin Canyon, Nevada on the California Trail

images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

parks.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the California National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
parks.name: California

parks.description: Established as a supply depot and hospital during the Civil War for the U.S. Army, Camp Nelson became a large recruitment and training center for African American soldiers (USCTs), and a refugee camp for their wives and children. Thousands of enslaved people escaped to this site with the hope of securing freedom and ultimately controlling their futures by aiding in the destruction of slavery.

entranceFees.description:
No entrance fee is charged to visit the park.
https://www.nps.gov/cane/planyourvisit/fees.htm
entranceFees.title: Camp Nelson National Monument

parks.directionsInfo: Camp Nelson National Monument is located along US 27 about 20 miles south of Lexington, Kentucky, 6 miles south of Nicholasville on US 27, and 16 miles north of Danville, KY on US 27. The Park entrance is on the original Danville Pike, adjacent to US 27, one mile north of the Camp Nelson National Cemetery.

operatingHours.description: The Camp Nelson Visitor Center and Museum are open Wednesday through Sunday. The Perry "White" House is under renovation and currently not open. The grounds, including nearly 5 miles of unpaved trails and dozens of wayside exhibits explaining the significance of Camp Nelson, are open seven days a week from sunrise to sunset. .
operatingHours.name: Camp Nelson National Monument

images.title: Camp Nelson National Monument Visitor Center
images.altText: The visitor center building is a gray wooden structure that models a typical barrack building.
images.caption: The Camp Nelson National Monument Visitor Center

images.title: Interior of Soldiers' Barrack Building
images.altText: A row of rough, wooden bunk beds in the soldiers' barrack house.
images.caption: Visit the barracks to imagine life at Camp Nelson during the Civil War.

images.title: Perry House
images.altText: A white, 2 story farm house with a Civil War cannon sitting in front of it
images.caption: The Perry House at Camp Nelson

images.title: United States Colored Troops at Camp Nelson, KY during the Civil War
images.altText: African American Civil War soldiers stand at attention outside their barracks.
images.caption: African American Civil War soldiers fighting for the Union stand at attention outside their barracks at Camp Nelson, KY.

images.title: Open fields and earth works at Camp Nelson National Monument in Kentucky.
images.altText: Open fields and earth works at Camp Nelson
images.caption: Open fields and earth works at Camp Nelson National Monument in Kentucky.

parks.weatherInfo: Kentucky has a moderate climate, summers are humid with highs typically in the upper 80s, and winter highs in the low 40s. Of course be aware of the possibility of storms or more extreme temperatures on occasion. The wettest months are March - July when about 4 inches of rain per month are expected, other months of the year are usually drier.
parks.name: Camp Nelson

parks.description: This pristine barrier island composed of dune, hammock and lagoon habitats provides protection from storms, preserves ancient Timucua Native American mounds, and is sanctuary for thousands of species of plants and animals that call Canaveral National Seashore home. Reflect on a pristine undeveloped shoreline, explore a historic site, or experience the rumble of a rocket soaring into space.

entranceFees.description: Per vehicle fee (cars, mini-vans, etc..), valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Vehicle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: The motorcycle entrance fee is valid for 7 days and is a per motorcycle fee.

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provisions of the service. (Costs vary based on design capacity of vehicle, and range from $25 to $100).

parks.directionsInfo: Canaveral National Seashore is located along Florida's East coast in both Volusia & Brevard counties. To access Apollo Beach - take I-95 to exit 249, then go east until it turns into A1A. Follow A1A south to the park entrance. To access Playalinda Beach - take I-95 to exit 220. Go east through Titusville on Garden Street, continue east and follow the signs.

operatingHours.description: Apollo District is currently open 6:00 AM - 8:00 PM with limited operations. A return to full operations will continue to be phased, and services may be limited. When recreating, please follow local area health orders, practice Leave No Trace principles, and avoid crowding and high-risk outdoor activities.
