parks.name: Canaveral

parks.fullName: Cane River Creole National Historical Park
parks.description: The Cane River region is home to a unique culture; the Creoles. Generations of the same families of owners and workers, enslaved and tenant, lived on these lands for over 200 years. The park tells their stories and preserves the cultural landscape of Oakland and Magnolia Plantations, two of the most intact Creole cotton plantations in the United States.

entranceFees.description: No fees
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

parks.directionsInfo: To reach Oakland Plantation, take I-49 to Exit 127, Flora/Cypress. Head east on LA Highway 120 toward Cypress. Cross over LA Highway 1 onto LA Highway 494. The parking lot and entrance pavilion for Oakland is 4.5 miles east of Highway 1 on the left. To reach the grounds of Magnolia Plantation, take I-49 to Exit 119, Derry. Head east on LA Highway 119. Cross over LA Highway 1 and proceed for 1.1 miles. The parking area of Magnolia Plantation is on the right just before the road closure.

operatingHours.description: Interior access to the Oakland Plantation Store is open with reduced capacity from 9:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. from Wednesday to Sunday. The Oakland Plantation Main House is open for self-guided tours on Saturday and Sunday only from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. with limited occupancy. The grounds, trails, and visitor restrooms are open daily at Oakland and Magnolia Plantations from 9 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Guided grounds tours of plantation outbuildings are available Wednesday through Sunday. Closed federal holidays.
operatingHours.name: Oakland and Magnolia Plantations

images.title: Oakland Plantation Quarters
images.altText: A small cabin sits beneath the branches of a Live Oak in the Oakland Plantation Quarters.
images.caption: One of two remaining cabins built for enslaved workers on Oakland Plantation. The cabin was lived in by sharecroppers into the 1960s.

images.title: Magnolia Plantation Overseer's House
images.altText: A raised Creole cottage surrounded by oak trees.
images.caption: Originally built as a hospital for the enslaved workers on Magnolia Plantation, this raised Creole cottage also served as home to the plantation Overseer.

images.title: Live Oak Trees
images.altText: The sunrise shines through Live Oak trees at Oakland Plantation.
images.caption: Live Oak trees at sunrise on Oakland Plantation.

images.title: Cabins in the Magnolia Plantation Quarters
images.altText: Brick cabins built to house enslaved workers, served as homes for tenant farmers into the 1960s.
images.caption: These brick cabins were built in the 1840s to house enslaved workers on Magnolia Plantation. Following Emancipation the cabins served as homes for tenant farmers.

images.title: Oak Allee
images.altText: Two rows of Live Oak trees stretch from the Cane River to the Oakland Plantation Main House.
images.caption: The Oak Allee, planted in the mid-1820s, stretches from the Cane River to the Oakland Plantation Main House.

images.title: Magnolia Plantation Cotton Gin and Press Barn
images.altText: This wood screw cotton press was used at Magnolia Plantation to form cotton into bales for market.
images.caption: The Magnolia Plantation Gin Barn houses this rare wood screw cotton press.

parks.weatherInfo: Weather in central Louisiana can be unpredictable. Summers are hot and humid. Winter is relatively mild with measurable snowfall every 5-10 years. Average rainfall is approximately 55-60 inches per year. The area is also subject to severe thunderstorms, hail, damaging winds, and tornadoes. Visitors might want to bring hats, umbrellas, and drink plenty of water. Please check the local weather forecast before planning your visit to the park.
parks.name: Cane River Creole

parks.description: For nearly 5,000 years, people have lived in these canyons - longer than anyone has lived uninterrupted anywhere on the Colorado Plateau. In the place called Tsegi, their homes and images tell us their stories. Today, Navajo families make their homes, raise livestock, and farm the lands in the canyons. A place like no other, the park and Navajo Nation work together to manage the land's resources.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for the park.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: The recommended route to the park is from Highway 191 in Chinle then turning east on Route 7. The park entrance and Visitor Center is about 3 miles from Highway 191. An alternative is entering the park on the East side via Route 64. There are 3 overlooks to stop at along Route 64 before getting to the Visitor Center. Travel on Route 7 from the East is NOT RECOMMENDED since the road is unpaved and unmaintained between Sawmill and the Spider Rock turnoff.

operatingHours.description: North Rim Drive, South Rim Drive, 10 overlooks and White House Trail remain open all year round.
operatingHours.name: Rim Drives, Overlooks and White House Trail

addresses.line1: 3 miles E of Highway 191 on Route 7

images.title: Canyon Farm
images.altText: Farm in the canyon
images.caption: Navajo families continue to live and farm in the canyon they call Tsegi

images.title: Canyon Hike
images.altText: Hiking in the canyon
images.caption: Visitors can enjoy a free ranger led hike into the canyon

images.title: Spider Rock
images.altText: View of Spider Rock from the overlook
images.caption: Her home on top of Spider Rock, Spider Woman taught the Navajo people how to weave

images.title: Canyon View
images.altText: View of the canyon from the White House Trail
images.caption: The Navajo people call the canyon Tsegi meaning "within the rocks"

images.title: White House
images.altText: View of White House Ruin
images.caption: Ancient Puebloans built villages like White House that offered opportunities for trade, ceremony, and social gatherings.

parks.weatherInfo: Canyon de Chelly is located at 5,500 feet. Spring is cool and windy; highs from 50 to 70; lows of 35 degrees. Expect dust storms and canyon flooding. Summer is hot and dry; highs from 85 to 100; lows of 51 degrees. Drink plenty of water outdoors. Fall is warm and often wet; highs from 60 to 80; lows of 40 degrees. Expect lightning, thunderstorms, and flash floods. Winter is cold and breezy; highs from 40 to 60; lows of 18 degrees. Expect 1-4 inches of snow and freezing nighttime temperatures.
parks.name: Canyon de Chelly

parks.description: Canyonlands invites you to explore a wilderness of countless canyons and fantastically formed buttes carved by the Colorado River and its tributaries. Rivers divide the park into four districts: Island in the Sky, The Needles, The Maze, and the rivers themselves. These areas share a primitive desert atmosphere, but each offers different opportunities for sightseeing and adventure.

emailAddresses.description: We check this email inbox at least once a week. We will respond to your email as soon as we can.

entranceFees.description:
Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle 
(15 passenger capacity or less) and all its occupants.
entranceFees.title: Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Admits a private, non-commercial motorcycle and its riders.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car. Typically used for bicyclists, hikers, and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free.
entranceFees.title: Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year through the month of purchase. Admits one (1) private, non-commercial vehicle or its pass holder to Arches and Canyonlands national parks, and Natural Bridges National Monument.
entrancePasses.title: Southeast Utah Parks Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Canyonlands National Park is cut into three land districts by the Green and Colorado rivers. Island in the Sky, in the north of the park, is about 40 minutes from Moab, UT via UT 313. The Needles district is in the southeast corner of Canyonlands, about 90 minutes from Moab or an hour from Monticello, UT via UT 211. The Maze district, in the west of the park, is the most remote and challenging; its ranger station is down 46 miles of dirt road from UT 24. All roads in The Maze require high-clearance 4WD.

operatingHours.description: Canyonlands National Park is generally open 24 hours a day, year-round.
operatingHours.name: Open Year-round

addresses.line1: Island in the Sky - 33 miles from Moab on UT 313
addresses.line3: The Maze - 68 miles from Hanksville off UT 24 - unpaved roads
addresses.line2: The Needles - 49 miles from Monticello on UT 211

images.title: Mesa Arch
images.altText: a broad stone arch with rock pinnacles in the distance
images.caption: Mesa Arch, at Island in the Sky, is a great spot for photographers.

images.title: Pothole Point
images.altText: shallow pools with a double rainbow in the background
images.caption: Pothole Point Trail

images.title: The Maze
images.altText: a rugged canyon
images.caption: The Maze is the most remote district of the park. Visiting requires four-wheel drive, self-reliance, and extra time.

images.title: White Rim Road
images.altText: a long gravel road with cyclists on it
images.caption: The White Rim Road at Island in the Sky is a popular road for mountain bikers.

images.title: The Needles in Chesler Park
images.altText: pinnacles of horizontally striped sandstone
images.caption: The Needles, pinnacles of Cedar Mesa Sandstone, are visible in many parts of the Needles District, including this view in Chesler Park.

images.title: Boating on the Colorado River
images.altText: a person rowing a dory on the Colorado River
images.caption: Boating the Colorado and Green rivers is a popular activity at Canyonlands (permit required).

parks.weatherInfo: Canyonlands is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.
parks.name: Canyonlands

parks.description: The great Outer Beach described by Thoreau in the 1800s is protected within the national seashore. Forty miles of pristine sandy beach, marshes, ponds, and uplands support diverse species. Lighthouses, cultural landscapes, and wild cranberry bogs offer a glimpse of Cape Cod's past and continuing ways of life. Swimming beaches and walking and biking trails beckon today's visitors.

entranceFees.description: The daily vehicle beach entrance pass grants access to all six Cape Cod National Seashore-managed beach parking lots for one private vehicle. The pass must be purchased on the day of use and is good for that calendar day. Purchase at beach entrance stations during business hours. Fees are typically collected at the six beaches from late spring through the end of September.
entranceFees.title: Daily Beach Entrance Fee, Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: The daily beach entrance fee for motorcycles grants access to all six Cape Cod National Seashore-managed beach parking lots for one motorcycle. The pass must be purchased on the day of use and is good for that calendar day. Purchase at beach entrance stations during business hours. Fees are typically collected at the six beaches from late spring through the end of September.
entranceFees.title: Daily Beach Entrance Fee, Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: The daily beach entrance fee for pedestrians and bicyclists grants access to all six Cape Cod National Seashore-managed beaches for one individual. Children 15 or under are free. The pass must be purchased on the day of use and is good for that calendar day. Purchase at beach entrance stations during business hours. Fees are typically collected at the six beaches from late spring through the end of September.
entranceFees.title: Daily Beach Entrance Fee, Pedestrian/Bicycle

entrancePasses.description: This pass provides private vehicle entrance into the six beach parking lots managed by the national seashore for the entirety of the park's charging season. This pass is in the form of a sticker affixed to the windshield of a vehicle and is not transferable. Purchase at beach entrance stations during business hours. Fees are typically collected at the six beaches from late spring through the end of September.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Private Vehicle Beach Entrance Pass to Cape Cod National Seashore

parks.directionsInfo: The national seashore is located in eastern Massachusetts on Cape Cod and is accessed via Route 6. The park is 20 miles east of Hyannis, MA.

operatingHours.description: Beaches, parking areas, and trails are open year-round between 6 AM and midnight.
operatingHours.name: Cape Cod National Seashore

images.title: Sunrise Waves
images.altText: A curling wave breaks against the backdrop of a pink sunrise.
images.caption: Visiting the beach to watch the sunrise over the Atlantic Ocean is a beautiful experience.

images.title: Sand Ripples
images.altText: Low tide exposes rippled ridges of sand and water.
images.caption: You will never walk the same beach twice on Cape Cod; daily low and high tides expose and then cover the sand.

images.title: Exploring the Park by Water
images.altText: A red kayak floats on a pond facing a forest colored with red and orange leaves.
images.caption: Exploring the park by water offers a different perspective.

images.title: Birds and Beach
images.altText: A flock of birds flies along a beach with waves in the background.
images.caption: The national seashore is known for its species diversity, including threatened and endangered shorebirds.

images.title: Atlantic White Cedar Swamp Trail
images.altText: Boardwalk trail runs through a swamp surrounded by green ferns and tall trees.
images.caption: This popular trail takes visitors through the rare habitat of an Atlantic White Cedar swamp.

images.title: Sunrise Over the Atlantic
images.altText: A brilliant sun rises over the ocean reflecting light on the water's surface.
images.caption: Cape Cod provides the opportunity to watch the sun rise out of the Atlantic Ocean and set into Cape Cod Bay.

parks.weatherInfo: Cape Cod's weather is generally moderated by its proximity to the ocean. Winter is typically cold with some snow. Spring is often rainy. Summer is usually warm and humid. Fall is generally dry and clear.
parks.name: Cape Cod

parks.description: The sound of ocean waves, the starry night sky, or the calm of the salt marshes, you can experience it all. Shaped by the forces of water, wind, and storms these islands are ever changing. The plants, wildlife, and people who live here adapt continually. Whether you are enjoying the beach, kayaking the sound, or climbing the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse there is something for everyone to explore!

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enjoy the grounds of Cape Hatteras National Seashore.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: Cape Hatteras National Seashore is located along NC-12 in the Outer Banks of North Carolina. You can reach the seashore from the north by following US 158 to Nag Heads, NC and the turn-off to NC-12 and Cape Hatteras National Seashore. From the south, you can take NCDOT ferries from Swanquarter, NC and Cedar Island, NC to the village of Ocracoke on Ocracoke Island. The provided physical address is the location of the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse, roughly in the middle of the park.

operatingHours.description: The grounds of Cape Hatteras National Seashore are always open for visitors, though there are resource closures that seasonally affect different parts of the beach.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.title: Fresnel Lens
images.altText: The first-order Fresnel lens is visible in the lantern room of the Bodie Island Lighthouse.
images.caption: Bodie Island Lighthouse still has its first-order Fresnel lens.

images.title: Paddling Pamlico Sound
images.altText: A young girl paddles across the water with the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse visible in the distance.
images.caption: Lots of recreation opportunities await visits on the sound side of the barrier islands.

images.title: Cape Hatteras Lighthouse
images.altText: Black and white painting of the brick Cape Hatteras Lighthouse.
images.caption: Black and white spirals decorate the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse.

images.title: Playing in the Sand
images.altText: Two kids play in the sand.
images.caption: Two kids enjoy the sands of Cape Hatteras.

parks.weatherInfo: The weather along the Outer Banks varies throughout the year and even throughout the day. Please check the National Weather Service information at http://www.weather.gov/mhx/ for forecast information.
parks.name: Cape Hatteras

parks.fullName: Cape Henry Memorial Part of Colonial National Historical Park
parks.description: English colonists first landed here in April 1607, erected a wooden cross and gave thanks for a successful crossing to a new land. In 1781, Americans could watch from these same sand dunes the largest naval battle of the Revolutionary War. Our French Allies defeated a British fleet just off this shore to set the stage for General George Washington's victory at Yorktown.

entranceFees.description: Due to COVID restrictions on JEBLCFS only military ID holders can access the Cape Henry Memorial. Currently, Cape Henry Memorial is only open to those who have access to Joint Expeditionary Base Little Creek – Fort Story. You must be able to provide a military ID.
entranceFees.title: Currently, Cape Henry Memorial is only open to those who have access to Joint Expeditionary Base Little Creek – Fort Story

parks.directionsInfo: Located on the south side of the Chesapeake Bay, Cape Henry Memorial sits within the Joint Expeditionary Base Little Creek-Fort Story. From Interstate 64 E take exit 282 to merge onto US-13N/Northhampton Boulevard towards the Chesapeake Bay Bridge. Then take US-60 E/Shore Drive exit toward Beaches, this is the last exit before the Chesapeake Bay Bridge. Follow Shore Drive and turn left onto Atlantic Ave and proceed to Gate 8. Follow Atlantic Ave to Cape Henry Memorial.

operatingHours.description:
Due to COVID restrictions on JEBLCFS only military ID holders can access the Cape Henry Memorial
Currently, Cape Henry Memorial is only open to those who have access to Joint Expeditionary Base Little Creek – Fort Story. You must be able to provide a military ID.

This quarter acre of ground marks the approximate site of the first landing of the Jamestown settlers in Virginia.
operatingHours.name: Cape Henry

addresses.line1: Colonial National Historical Park P.O. Box 210

images.title: Memorial Cross
images.altText: Memorial Cross
images.caption: A granite cross erected in 1935 by the National Society Daughters of the American Colonists, in memory of the wooden cross erected by the English colonists in 1607.

images.title: Admiral de Grasse Statue
images.altText: Admiral de Grasse Statue
images.caption: Located near overlook at Cape Henry

images.title: Battle of Capes Wayside
images.altText: Battle of Capes Wayside
images.caption: At Overlook

images.title: Memorial Cross
images.altText: Memorial Cross
images.caption: Near Overlook

parks.weatherInfo: Spring: Temperatures usually range from 40 F to 80 F. Rain is common. Summer: Temperatures usually range from 80 F to 100 F. Rain and sun are equally common. On very sunny days, be prepared with plenty of water . Fall: Temperatures usually range from 40 F to 70 F. Winter: Temperatures range from 40 F to 20 F. Be prepared with cold weather gear and numerous layers if you intend to be outside.
parks.name: Cape Henry Memorial
parks.designation: Part of Colonial National Historical Park

parks.description: North of the Arctic Circle, the monument forms 70 miles of shoreline on the Chukchi Sea. More than 114 beach ridges provide evidence of human use for 5,000 years. The Inupiat continue to use the area today. Vast wetlands provide habitat for shorebirds from as far away as South America. Hikers and boaters can see carpets of wildflowers among shrubs containing wisps of qiviut from muskoxen.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee required to visit Cape Krusenstern National Monument
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: Cape Krusenstern National Monument lies within a remote area of northwest Alaska and is bordered by the Arctic Ocean and Chukchi Sea. Visitors generally access the monument via the regional hub in Kotzebue. Commercial airlines provide daily service from Anchorage to Kotzebue. Chartered flights with licensed air taxi services, booked in advance, can take backcountry travelers to remote destinations within the monument.

operatingHours.description: Since there are no roads into Cape Krusenstern National Monument, the visitor center is located in Kotzebue, AK.  From Kotzebue, visitors will charter an air taxi to transport them into the actual national monument which is open 24/7 every day of the year.
operatingHours.name: Cape Krusenstern National Monument

images.title: Muskox and Geese
images.altText: muskox standing on the tundra
images.caption: Muskox and Greater White-fronted Geese on vegetated beach ridges in front of the Igichuk Hills.

images.title: Winter Moon
images.altText: moon over snow covered hills
images.caption: January light and a bright moon at 2 pm over the Igichuk Hills in Cape Krusenstern National Monument.

images.title: Beach Ridges on the Shore of Cape Krusenstern
images.altText: aerial view of beach ridges
images.caption: Beach ridges created by years of wave action during storms can be seen as parallel lines in the fall vegetation covering the old gravel.

images.title: Fish on a Drying Rack
images.altText: fish hanging on rack
images.caption: Pike (left and right) and trout (middle) dry on a rack at a subsistence camp. The slash marks allow more air to circulate and dry the meat more quickly.

images.title: Old House Uncovered
images.altText: archaeologist digging
images.caption: A University of Washington archeology crew conducts research on an old semi-subterranean house along the beach ridges of Cape Krusenstern. Old house timbers are slowly revealed about 4 feet down

parks.weatherInfo: Snow, rain, and freezing temperatures can occur any time of the year. Always travel with good quality rain gear and warm layers. Be especially careful to stay dry. Hypothermia can set in on a windy, wet day, even when it doesn't feel that cold.
parks.name: Cape Krusenstern

parks.description: A boat ride three miles off-shore brings you to the barrier islands of Cape Lookout National Seashore. Horse watching, shelling, fishing, birding, camping, lighthouse climbing, and touring historic villages--there’s something for everyone at Cape Lookout. Be sure to bring all the food, water, and supplies you need (and carry your trash out of the park) when visiting these remote beaches.

entranceFees.description: There is no charge for coming to Cape Lookout National Seashore.  The Harkers Island Visitor Center and the Beaufort Visitor Information Center can be reached by car.  All other locations require a trip by ferry.  There is a charge for the ferry. Contact the ferry company for costs and schedules.
entranceFees.title: Cape Lookout Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Only two areas of Cape Lookout National Seashore can be reached without taking a ferry: the Visitor Center on Harkers Island and the Visitor Information Center in Beaufort, NC. Please note: the park mailing address does not bring you to the Harkers Island Visitor Center parking lot. If you are using a GPS device - use the parking lot coordinates (34.68494, -74.52725) or the following "address" which approximates the location of the parking lot entrance: 1800 Island Rd, Harkers Island, NC 28531

operatingHours.description: Cape Lookout National Seashore is open 24 hours and 365 days a year (weather permitting). Operating hours for visitor centers and other services will vary throughout the year.
operatingHours.name: Cape Lookout National Seashore

images.title: Cape Lookout Lighthouse
images.altText: : Black & white patterned tower of the Cape Lookout Lighthouse stands against a blue & white cloud f
images.caption: The Cape Lookout Lighthouse is still an active aid-to-navigation, warning ships of the nearby shoals.  Climbing to up to see the view from the gallery level, 14 stories above the ground, is also a popular activity by visitors during the summer.

images.title: Sea Oats
images.altText: Mature sea oat plant seed heads gracefully drooping in the sun
images.caption: In late summer, Sea Oats are the most conspicuous plant growing on the sand dunes with their graceful, drooping seed heads.

images.title: Sanderlings
images.altText: small sandpipers poke their bills in the sand while waves break in the background
images.caption: Small sandpipers, called Sanderlings, are common sights on the ocean beach as they search for food in the sand between waves

images.title: Relaxing by the Ocean
images.altText: 2 ladies sit in beach chairs on the sand with their feet in the water
images.caption: Watching the waves, feeling the cool sea breeze and the warmth of the sun make for a relaxing day.

images.title: Surf fishing
images.altText: A surf fisherman stands in the water holding his surf rod and watching the waves
images.caption: Surf fishing is a popular pastime at the beach

parks.weatherInfo: Spring: Temperatures generally range from 50 F to 70+ F. Rain & wind are common Summer: Temperatures usually range from 80 F to 100 F with high humidity (80-90%). Average wind speed is 10-15 mph. Be prepared with plenty of water. With little shade on the islands, an umbrella to provide shade from the sun is a good idea. Fall: Temperatures usually range from the high 70 F to the upper 40 F. Winter: Temperatures usually range from 50 F - 32 F. Winds can be strong. Dress in layers.
parks.name: Cape Lookout

parks.description: The Capitol Hill Parks include several park areas east of the U.S. Capitol. Included in this group are Folger, Lincoln, Stanton, and Marion Parks, the Eastern Market and Potomac Avenue Metro stations, and several smaller land parcels such as Seward Square, Twining Square, the Maryland Avenue Triangles, the Pennsylvania Avenue Medians, and 59 inner-city triangles and squares.

entranceFees.description: No Required Fee
entranceFees.title: No Required Fee

entrancePasses.description: No Pass Required
entrancePasses.title: No Pass Required

operatingHours.description: Parks open at sunsrise and close at sunset.
operatingHours.name: Capitol Hill Parks (Lincoln, Stanton, Folger, Marion Parks)

images.caption: Bethune Memorial in Lincoln Park across from Emancipation Group Memorial

parks.weatherInfo: Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30 to 50 F. There is occasional snow. Spring: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Rain is common. Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70 to 90 F. Humidity is usually high. Be prepared and drink plenty of water. There is a water fountain in the visitor center. Fall: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Humidity can remain high in the earlier part of the season.
parks.name: Capitol Hill Parks

parks.description: Located in south-central Utah in the heart of red rock country, Capitol Reef National Park is a hidden treasure filled with cliffs, canyons, domes, and bridges in the Waterpocket Fold, a geologic monocline (a wrinkle on the earth) extending almost 100 miles.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee for Capitol Reef National Park is paid into a self-serve tube at the beginning of the Scenic Drive, just past the campground. The cost includes all in a private vehicle. America the Beautiful Interagency passes cover this entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Capitol Reef Entrance fee - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee for Capitol Reef National Park is paid into a self-serve tube at the beginning of the Scenic Drive, just past the campground. The cost includes all on a single motorcycle. America the Beautiful Interagency passes cover this entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Capitol Reef Entrance fee - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee for Capitol Reef National Park is paid into a self-serve tube at the beginning of the Scenic Drive, just past the campground.  America the Beautiful Interagency passes cover this entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Capitol Reef Entrance Fee - Bicycle and Pedestrian

entranceFees.description: Buses and commercial vehicles are based on vehicle size/occupants. This fee can be paid at the visitor center.
entranceFees.title: Capitol Reef Entrance Fee - Commercial vehicles with a seating capacity of 26 seats or greater

entranceFees.description: Buses and commercial vehicles are based on vehicle size/occupants. This fee can be paid at the visitor center.
entranceFees.title: Capitol Reef Entrance Fee - Commercial vehicles with a seating capacity of 7-25 seats

entranceFees.description: Buses and commercial vehicles are based on vehicle size/occupants. This fee can be paid at the visitor center.
entranceFees.title: Capitol Reef Entrance Fee - Commercial vehicles with a seating capacity of 1-6 seats

entrancePasses.description: This pass covers the entrance fees to Capitol Reef National Park of the pass holder and occupants of a single, private non-commercial vehicle. It is valid for 365 days from the date of purchase. For information about other passes available see https://www.nps.gov/care/planyourvisit/fees.htm.
entrancePasses.title: Capitol Reef Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: From I-70: Take exit 149, then take UT-24 west toward Hanksville; continue for 43.8 miles (70.5 km). Turn right to continue on UT-24 west and continue for 37.3 miles (60 km). From I-15: take exit 188 then US-50 east toward Scipio. Left on UT-50; continuing 0.7 miles (1.1 km). Turn right onto US-50 east; continue for 24.4 miles (39.3 km). Turn right onto UT-260 south and continue 4.2 miles (6.8 km), then right on UT-24 for 71.3 miles. UT-12: North on highway 12 to Torrey, UT. Right onto UT-24.

operatingHours.description: Capitol Reef is a 24 hour park, open all day, every day. The visitor center is open daily, except for some major holidays. Visitor center hours vary, call 435-425-3791 and follow the prompts for current visitor center information.
operatingHours.name: Capitol Reef National Park

images.title: Gifford House and Pendleton Barn
images.altText: Wingate Sandstone cliffs behind historic barn and farmhouse
images.caption: Windgate sandstone towers above historic Fruita farms and homes

images.title: Hickman Bridge
images.altText: A hiker stands beside Hickman Bridge, a natural sandstone bridge
images.caption: Hickman Bridge, a natural sandstone bridge, is a popular hike in the park.

images.title: Strike Valley
images.altText: Exposed layers of rock in the Waterpocket fold
images.caption: The Strike Valley shows colorful layers in the Waterpocket fold.

images.title: Capitol Reef Visitor Center with "The Castle"
images.altText: Cliffs known as "The Castle" tower above the Capitol Reef Visitor Center
images.caption: The Capitol Reef Visitor Center sits below cliffs known as "The Castle".

images.title: Capitol Reef Peach Orchard
images.altText: Fruit tree with peaches in front of red sandstone cliffs
images.caption: The Capitol Reef Orchards, planted in the pioneer era, remain a popular place for visitors today.

parks.weatherInfo: Weather is posted daily; check at the park visitor center for weather updates. Do not enter into narrow canyons if there is a threat of rain or if rain has been falling in the area. Rain and snow may also make dirt roads impassable to vehicles.
parks.name: Capitol Reef

parks.fullName: Captain John Smith Chesapeake National Historic Trail
parks.description: People first arrived in the Chesapeake Bay during the last ice age. As glaciers melted, diverse societies learned to thrive in a world of water. When Englishman Captain John Smith explored the Bay in 1608, he documented hundreds of American Indian communities. Today, sites on his map are archeological treasures and sacred sites for tribal citizens. Come join us on the shores of the Chesapeake Bay!

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to use the Captain John Smith Chesapeake National Historic Trail. Some of the visitor centers, state parks, museums, wildlife refuges, and other sites along the trail may charge entrance fees.
entranceFees.title: Trail Visitor Fees

parks.directionsInfo: The water trail is 3,000 miles long and there are countless places to explore it. The trail's headquarters and main visitor center is at Colonial National Historical Park - Historic Jamestowne. For an internet map search or GPS, use the following: Historic Jamestowne Visitor Center, 1368 Colonial Parkway, Jamestown, Virginia 23081.

operatingHours.description: The water trail is open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year! To launch your kayak or other vessel on the trail, access a local boat launch along one of the trail's many tributary rivers and coastlines. Local boat launches, state parks, and other locations may have specific operating hours and seasons. Always check weather and conditions before going out on the water - take care during the winter months to dress appropriately for the weather and the possibility of submersion in cold water.
operatingHours.name: Trail Operating Hours

images.title: Heron at sunset at Blackwater NWR
images.altText: A heron at sunset in the waters and marshes of Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge
images.caption: Many people visit Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge to spot birds, like this heron, that rely the natural resources of the landscape.

images.title: Living History at Jamestown Settlement
images.altText: A re-created American Indian town.
images.caption: At Jamestown Settlement, trail visitors can view yihakan, the houses seen pictured here, which are constructed from saplings and reed mats.

images.title: Cypress Trees Chickahominy River
images.altText: Many baldcypress trees standing in the Chickahominy River
images.caption: Some scenes - like this one of cypress trees in the Chickahominy River - look similar to what Captain John Smith would have seen 400 years ago.

images.title: Kayaker at Jug Bay
images.altText: A lone kayaker explores the Patuxent River
images.caption: The upper reaches of the Patuxent River at Jug Bay give visitors a view of the Chesapeake region that feels similar to a time before European settlement.

images.title: Susquehanna River view from Zimmerman Center
images.altText: A view of the Susquehanna River and the boat dock at Zimmerman Center for Heritage
images.caption: Visitors can use the dock at Zimmerman Center for Heritage to launch canoes and kayaks onto the beautiful Susquehanna River in south central Pennsylvania.

parks.weatherInfo: During the summer season, visitors should dress in light, comfortable, moisture-wicking clothing, and use sunscreen. High temperatures and humidity create a higher risk of heat cramps, heat exhaustion and heatstroke. We recommended you carry a bottle of water with you and wear a life jacket at all times. During the winter, be aware that submersion in freezing cold water can be deadly. If you are going out, bring safety gear such as a wetsuit and practice techniques to avoid tipping over.
parks.name: Captain John Smith Chesapeake

parks.description: Part of the 8,000 square mile Raton-Clayton Volcanic Field, Capulin Volcano showcases the volcanic geology of northeastern New Mexico. The views are spectacular day or night, with views of 4 different states from the volcanic rim and one of the darkest night skies in the country. Whether it's a quick stop or a day's trip, enjoy exploring the landscape of this unique volcano!

emailAddresses.description: General mailbox of the Capulin Volcano National Monument Interpretation and Visitor Services staff.

entranceFees.description:
receipt valid for 7 Days
Admits private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and all occupants to Capulin Volcano National Monument. Please contact us in advance if you are arriving in a large vehicle (RV) or bus. The maximum size of a vehicle allowed on the Volcano Road without a permit is 26 feet in length and/or 8 feet in width.
entranceFees.title: Capulin Volcano Entrance Fee--Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Valid for 7 days. Fees won't exceed the commercial fee for the same-sized vehicle. Individuals or families with a valid Annual or Lifetime pass may use their pass for entry at the per person rate. Present pass & photo ID on entry. Contact us in advance if you're in a large vehicle (RV) or bus. Max vehicle size allowed on the Volcano Road without a permit: 26' long, 8' wide
entranceFees.title: Capulin Volcano Entrance Fee--Non-Commercial Organized Groups per Person Fee

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles that can carry seven or more passengers regardless of the actual number of passengers.
entranceFees.title: Capulin Volcano Entrance Fee--Commercial Tours of 1 to 6 people

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles that can carry seven or more passengers regardless of the actual number of passengers.
entranceFees.title: Capulin Volcano Entrance Fee--Commercial Tours of 7 to 25 people

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles that can carry seven or more passengers regardless of the actual number of passengers.
entranceFees.title: Capulin Volcano Entrance Fee--Commercial Tours of 26 or more people

entranceFees.description:
receipt valid for 7 Days
Admits one private motorcycle and all occupants to Capulin Volcano National Monument. Capulin Volcano accepts the America the Beautiful - Federal Lands Passes (Interagency Annual, Senior, and Access passes) in place of an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Capulin Volcano Entrance Fee--Private Motorcycle

entrancePasses.description: This pass covers the entrance fees for the pass holder's vehicle. It is valid for 365 days from the date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Capulin Volcano Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Capulin Volcano National Monument is located in northeast New Mexico. The monument is located 33 miles east of Raton, NM, and 57 miles west of Clayton, NM on NM325 north of US64. No public transportation systems serve the park.

operatingHours.description: Capulin Volcano National Monument is open from sunrise to sunset with the exception of the night sky viewing area (visitor center overflow parking lot) which is open throughout the night. The Volcano Road and Visitor Center have separate hours. Please see their individual hours below
operatingHours.name: Capulin Volcano National Monument

operatingHours.description: We extend the hours of the Visitor Center during the summer months from Memorial Day to Laboy Day. Daily from 8:00 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours Summer

operatingHours.description: Standard hours for the Visitor Center in winter monthes from Labor Day to Memorial Day are 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours Winter

operatingHours.description: Volcano Road, access to the top of the volcano, is on separate hours from the lower volcano and Visitor Center. Volcano Road closes to uphill traffic one half hour before the Visitor Center closing time.  In the summer from Memorial Day to Labor Day, it is open from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. and the rest of the year it is open from 8:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.
operatingHours.name: Volcano Road Volcano Top Access Summer

operatingHours.description: Volcano Road, access to the top of the volcano, is on separate hours from the lower volcano and Visitor Center. Volcano Road closes to uphill traffic one half hour before the Visitor Center closing time. In the winter from Labor Day to Memorial Day, it is open from 8:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.
operatingHours.name: Volcano Road Volcano Top Access Winter

images.title: Capulin Volcano
images.altText: A cloud shrouded volcano rises behind a field of yellow flowers.
images.caption: Capulin Volcano in summer.

images.title: Aerial View of Capulin Volcano
images.altText: View of cinder cone volcano and the road leading to the top of the volcano as seen from the air.
images.caption: Capulin Volcano is a classic example of a cinder cone. The crater is approximately 130 m (420 ft) deep and 440 m (1,450 ft) across. The base of the mountain is 6 km (4 mi) in circumference. Volcano Road spirals up the volcano, providing panoramic views.

images.title: Nature Trail at Capulin Volcano
images.altText: A shaded bench on the side of a paved nature trail wending through juniper trees and grasses.
images.caption: A paved nature trail at Capulin Volcano NM.

images.title: Volcano Road
images.altText: Layers of rock are visible in the steep hillside along a road.
images.caption: Layers of volcanic material can be seen in the Volcano Road that takes visitors to the top of Capulin Volcano.

images.title: Capulin Volcano-Best Example of a Cinder Cone in North America
images.altText: View of a cinder cone volcano covered with grasses, small trees, and other plants.
images.caption: Although Capulin Mountain is considered no longer active, because its excellent condition, the cinder cone is considered one of the best and most accessible examples of a cinder cone in North America.

parks.weatherInfo: Elevations range from 7247 feet at the park visitor center to 8182 feet on the crater rim trail. Summers usually have mild temperatures with highs averaging in the low to mid 80s F/app. 30C with occasional afternoon thunderstorms. Winters average from the low 40s to low 50s for highs, but temperatures vary. Snowfall is most common from December into April and may cause temporary closures of the volcano road. Sunny winter days are beautiful days to be in the park. Check weather conditions before visiting.
parks.name: Capulin Volcano

parks.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
parks.description: Carl Sandburg provided a popular voice for the American people of the twentieth century and still speaks to us through his words, activism, music and the beauty and serenity of Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site. Explore Sandburg's legacy and Experience Your America!

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter the park to hike the trails, enjoy the grounds or visit the barn and bookstore.  Start your visit in the ground floor of the Sandburg Home for information, house tour tickets, videos and more.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Online house tour reservations available at https://www.recreation.gov/ticket/facility/300005
entranceFees.title: House Tour Fee - Adults age 16-61

entranceFees.description: Online house tour reservations available at https://www.recreation.gov/ticket/facility/300005
entranceFees.title: House Tour Fee - Adults age 62 and older, and all interagency pass holders

entranceFees.description:
Online house tour reservations available at https://www.recreation.gov/ticket/facility/300005.
Child reservations online will incur $1.00 processing fee.  Day-of-tour walk up child tickets are free.
entranceFees.title: House Tour Fee - Children age 15 and under

parks.directionsInfo: The park is located three miles south of Hendersonville, NC on Little River Road off of the Greenville Highway/Rt. 225 in Flat Rock, NC. Visitors using GPS or mapping software should use 1800 Little River Road and look for the signs directing you to the visitor parking lot off Little River Road.

operatingHours.description: Parking lots, grounds, gardens, and trails are open every day, year-round, sunrise to sunset. Occasional closures arise from weather events, check park alerts for more information.
operatingHours.name: Parking Lots, Grounds and Trails

operatingHours.description: The house, barn, and barnyard are closed until further notice.
operatingHours.name: FACILITIES INCLUDING SANDBURG HOME AND BARN - CLOSED DUE TO COVID-19

images.caption: The Sandburg family enjoyed living in the Carolina mountains along with a collection of 12,000 books and a herd of dairy goats.

parks.description: High ancient sea ledges, deep rocky canyons, flowering cactus, and desert wildlife—treasures above the ground in the Chihuahuan Desert. Hidden beneath the surface are more than 119 caves—formed when sulfuric acid dissolved limestone leaving behind caverns of all sizes.

entranceFees.description: 16 years and older
entranceFees.title: Adults (Per Person)

entranceFees.description: 15 years old and under
entranceFees.title: Children

parks.directionsInfo: To access the park's only entrance road, New Mexico Highway 7, turn north from US Hwy 62/180 at White's City, NM, which is 20 miles (32 km) southwest of Carlsbad, NM and 145 miles (233 km) northeast of El Paso, TX. The entrance road stretches a scenic seven miles (11.3 km) from the park gate at White's City to the visitor center and cavern entrance. The address for the park's visitor center is 727 Carlsbad Caverns Hwy, Carlsbad, NM, 88220, located 27 miles (43 km) from the town of Carlsbad.

operatingHours.description: Last Entrance Ticket Sold: 2:15 pm / Last Cavern Entrance: 2:30 pm

parks.weatherInfo: Carlsbad Caverns National Park is located in the Chihuahuan Desert in southeast New Mexico. Summers are hot with temperatures between 90°F (32°C) and low 100s °F (38°C). Windy conditions and mild temperatures are common in early spring (March-May) with frequent rain in early fall (August-September). This part of the country also sees cold temperatures in the winter with occasional snow and icy conditions. Most days, the park is enveloped by a gorgeous blue sky with very few clouds, 278 sunny days a year!
parks.name: Carlsbad Caverns

parks.fullName: Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site
parks.description: Before Dr. Carter G. Woodson, there was very little accurate written history about the lives and experiences of Americans of African descent. Today a National Historic Site, Dr. Woodson’s home served as the headquarters for the Association for the Study of African American Life and History. Dr. Woodson established Negro History Week here in 1926, which we celebrate today as Black History Month.

entranceFees.description: No Fee Required
entranceFees.title: No Fee Required

entrancePasses.description: No Pass Required
entrancePasses.title: No Pass Required

parks.directionsInfo: From The National Mall travel east onto Constitution Avenue NW, until you come to 12th Street (which is a one-way street). Make a left turn onto 12th Street. Continue traveling north on 12th Street NW, until you come to Rhode Island Avenue. Make a right turn onto Rhode Island Avenue. Keep straight on Rhode Island Avenue, until you come to 9th Street. Make a right turn onto 9th Street. Keep straight and 1538 9th Street will be the third house on the right (the red brick one).

operatingHours.description: The Carter G. Woodson Home is normally open for tours on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays. Visiting the site on other days of the week (Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday) is available by appointment only. To request a tour outside of the listed hours, please contact us by email (woodsonnhs@nps.gov) or phone (202-438-6593 or 202-426-5961). (Scheduling is dependent upon staff availability)
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.altText: The restored facades of three historic Victorian row-homes on an urban street in Washington, DC
images.caption: The view from across the street of the facades of the Carter G. Woodson Home National Historic Site.

images.altText: The backs of the three restored homes that make up the Woodson Home NHS with accessibility
images.caption: Handicapped Accessibility (ramp, parking space) at the back of the Carter G. Woodson Home NHS.

images.altText: The second level in a historic home with wooden floorboards, steps, railings, light fixtures, window

images.caption: An old-fashioned typewriter sits on top of a desk along with other office supplies in the reception area and office space of Dr. Woodson's office-home.

parks.weatherInfo: Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30 to 50 F. There is occasional snow. Spring: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Rain is common. Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70 to 90 F. Humidity is usually high. Be prepared and drink plenty of water. There is a water fountain in the visitor center. Fall: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Humidity can remain high in the earlier part of the season.
parks.name: Carter G. Woodson Home

parks.description: Explore the mystery and complexity of an extended network of communities and irrigation canals. An Ancestral Sonoran Desert People's farming community and "Great House" are preserved at Casa Grande Ruins. Whether the Casa Grande was a gathering place for the Desert People or simply a waypoint marker in an extensive system of canals and trading partners is but part of the mystique of the Ruins.

emailAddresses.description: General park information and specific questions will be received at this email address and answered by appropriate park staff.

entranceFees.description: The monument no longer sells the Annual or Senior passes. However, the following free passes can still be issued: Military (Active Duty), 4th Grade, Access, and Volunteer.
entranceFees.title: Entrance to Casa Grande Ruins National Monument is free.

parks.directionsInfo: Transportation is by private vehicle. The park is in Coolidge, Arizona, about an hour-long drive from either Phoenix or Tucson. From Interstate 10 take the Coolidge exits and follow the signs to the park entrance.

operatingHours.description:
Limited Hours Due to COVID-19: With public health in mind, Casa Grande Ruins National Monument is closed on Sundays and Mondays.


The monument is open Tuesday - Saturday and is closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, and Independence Day. 


The gate closes 15 minutes prior to closing, with access for exiting the park still available on the outgoing side.
operatingHours.name: Operating Hours

images.title: Great House
images.altText: eathern building under modern roof structure
images.caption: The Great House at Casa Grande Ruins has existed for over 600 years.

images.title: Great House from the South
images.altText: earthern ruins including the Great House and other parts
images.caption: A highlight of Compound A is the Great House but it is not the only earthern building to intrigue visitors.

images.title: Great House in the Sonoran Desert
images.altText: earthern Great House with its roof among desert plants
images.caption: The Great House at Casa Grande Ruins is a sentinel of the desert.

images.title: Morning from the Northeast
images.altText: earthern Great House standing out in the Sonoran Desert plants
images.caption: The Great House at Casa Grande may have been an orientation point for travelers and traders.

images.title: Historic Sign
images.altText: historic copper sign with Great House and saguaro flanking
images.caption: The park's historic copper sign was relocated with roadway changes, and now sits near the visitor center.

images.title: Actors Recreating Jewelry
images.altText: child, adult female, adult male American Indian actors in costume making jewelry in movie shoot
images.caption: In this scene from the park movie, actors demonstrate jewelry making as done in ancestral times.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer daytime temperatures frequently exceed 100 degrees F. Winter temperatures range from the 60's to the 80's F. Spring and fall are warm and dry, with highs in the 80's and 90's F. During summer months, be prepared for hot temperatures. Protective clothing, hats, sunscreen and personal water containers are highly recommended. BE AWARE: Walls of dirt and debris, usually miles wide and thousands of feet high, are pushed across dry desert terrain by high winds, causing dust to engulf highways.
parks.name: Casa Grande Ruins

parks.fullName: Castillo de San Marcos National Monument
parks.description: Built by the Spanish in St. Augustine to defend Florida and the Atlantic trade route, Castillo de San Marcos National Monument preserves the oldest masonry fortification in the continental United States and interprets more than 450 years of cultural intersections.

entranceFees.description: Individual admission for persons 16 years of age or older.
entranceFees.title: Castillo Entrance Fee - Per Person - Adult

entranceFees.description: Individual admission for person age 15 and younger
entranceFees.title: Castillo Entrance Fee - Per Person - Child

entrancePasses.description: One year admission pass for the card holder and up to three additional adults.
entrancePasses.title: Castillo Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: On State Route A1A overlooking Matanzas Bay in the heart of the historic district of Saint Augustine, the Castillo is approximately a five mile drive from Interstate 95.

operatingHours.description: The Castillo de San Marcos is open to the public 7 days per week, except Thanksgiving Day (fourth Thursday in November) and Christmas Day (December 25). A maximum capacity of 100 visitors in the historic fort at any time will be in effect. First admission is at 9:00 a.m. and last admission is at 5:00 p.m. The Castillo closes and visitors must exit at 5:15 p.m. The park grounds are closed from midnight until 5:30 a.m.
operatingHours.name: Castillo de San Marcos National Monument

images.title: Castillo Drawbridge
images.altText: Drawbridge entrance to the Castillo de San Marcos
images.caption: Crossing a dry moat, this drawbridge was the only way into the Castillo.

images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Hot Shot Furnace
images.altText: Furnace for heating cannon balls
images.caption: This furnace, in the water battery on the east side of the Castillo, heated cannonballs red hot to be fired at wooden vessels.

images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Cannon
images.altText: Four black iron cannon mounted on carriages line the walls of the Castillo.
images.caption: The Castillo features both iron and bronze cannon and mortar from the period.

images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Cannon Firing
images.altText: Re-enactors of the first Spanish period cover their ears while firing a cannon.
images.caption: Cannon firing demonstrations are scheduled five times a day every Friday, Saturday, and Sunday.

images.title: Castillo de San Marcos Aerial View
images.altText: Aerial view of the Castillo and the city of St. Augustine
images.caption: the Castillo commands the northern edge of the heart of downtown St. Augsutine.

parks.weatherInfo: St. Augustine has a semi-tropical climate with over 300 days of sunshine each year. Summers (May-September) are hot, bright, and humid with afternoon thunderstorms common. Temperatures range from the lower 70s to the mid 90s F. Spring (March-mid-May) and Autumn (October-late November) can be pleasant with temperatures ranging from the upper 50s into the 80s F. The Winter months (December-March) are usually dry. Temperatures can be cool ranging from the upper 30s through the 60sF.
parks.name: Castillo de San Marcos

parks.description: Located at the southern tip of Manhattan Island, Castle Clinton stands where New York City began, and represents not only the city’s growth, but the growth of a nation. Initially intended to prevent a British invasion in 1812, the fortification has transformed over the years to welcome theatergoers, immigrants, sightseers, and now, millions of visitors to New York Harbor.

entranceFees.description: open to all
entranceFees.title: Castle Clinton Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: There are no park-specific passes required or sold at this location.
entrancePasses.title: Park Specific Passes

parks.directionsInfo: Castle Clinton is located in historic Battery Park. It is only directly accessible by foot, bicycle, or wheelchair. You cannot drive directly to the site. Local parking is nearly impossible to find and expensive. All public transportation options are located outside of Battery Park.

operatingHours.description: Castle Clinton is open daily except Thanksgiving day and Christmas Day.
operatingHours.name: Castle Clinton

images.title: Castle Clinton National Monument
images.altText: Castle Clinton NM Entrance
images.caption: Castle Clinton stands where New York City began.

parks.weatherInfo: Castle Clinton National Monument has a variety of weather. New York City has hot summers and cold winters. Spring can have heavy rains and Autumn can be cool. http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?CityName=New+York&state=NY&site=OKX&lat=40.7198&lon=-73.993#.Vqj8OvkrJlZ
parks.name: Castle Clinton

parks.description: Castle Mountains represents some of the most unique elements of the Mojave Desert. Nestled between the Nevada state line and Mojave National Preserve, the nearly 21,000 acres of Castle Mountains boasts Joshua tree forests, unbroken natural landscapes, rare desert grasslands, and rich human history. This intriguing area provides serenity and solitude from nearby metropolitan areas.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to enter Castle Mountains National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Castle Mountains Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: Castle Mountains is a fee free area.
entrancePasses.title: Castle Mountains Pass

parks.directionsInfo: You can approach Castle Mountains from Walking Box Ranch Road off of Nevada State Rd 164 (Nipton Road) or from several unnamed dirt roads off of Lanfair Road in Mojave National Preserve.

operatingHours.description: Castle Mountains National Monument is open year-round. There are no facilities in the Monument. Visitor Centers in neighboring Mojave National Preserve provide information and orientation.
operatingHours.name: Castle Mountains

images.title: Red Rocks Outcropping
images.altText: Red rocks frame a stand of Joshua trees and sage brush.
images.caption: Red rocks frame a stand of Joshua trees and sage brush in the desert floor..

images.title: View of Castle Peaks
images.altText: Foreground is desert greenery. The isolated spires of the Castle Peaks rise up in the background
images.caption: From Walking Box Ranch road, visitors to Castle Mountains can enjoy the stunning view of the Castle Peaks, which are located in surrounding Mojave National Preserve lands.

parks.weatherInfo: Weather at Castle Mountains changes with the seasons. Freezing temperatures are expected in winter, with occasional snow. Spring brings mild warm days and cooler nights. With enough rain, wildflowers can carpet the area, making for spectacular displays. Summer months are much hotter, with temperatures nearing 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Strong monsoonal storms in late summer may cause flash-flooding in low-lying areas and can create hazardous road conditions. Fall is a cooler respite after the heat of summer.
parks.name: Castle Mountains

parks.description: President Franklin D. Roosevelt created programs to give people a chance to rebuild their lives from the Great Depression. The Works Progress Administration and the Civilian Conservation Corps gave this land a second opportunity and through re-growth, a new role as a recreation area.

entranceFees.description: The park does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: To reach the visitor center from the east, follow US Route 15 to MD Route 77 and go west about 3 miles. The visitor center is on the right side of the road. From the west, take I 70 to MD 66 at exit 35. Turn left onto MD 66 north and travel about 5 miles, passing through the roundabout. Turn right onto MD 64 and drive 1 mile. Turn right onto MD 77. Drive on MD 77 about 7.5 miles. The visitor center is on the left.

operatingHours.description: Hiking trails and parking areas are open year round, dawn to dusk, but may close as a result of security or safety concerns.  Consult the park's website for updates: http://www.nps.gov/cato/index.htm.  The visitor center, camps, and campgrounds have separate hours.  Please see descriptions for those facilities elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Catoctin Mountain Park

images.title: Chimney Rock Vista
images.altText: Rock formation with mountains in the background
images.caption: A challenging hike leads to Chimney Rock, the most popular vista in the park.

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: A stone and wood building with plants and flowers in front
images.caption: First time visitors should begin their park experience at the visitor center.

images.title: Eastern Mud Salamander
