images.caption: Life is abundant at Catoctin Mountain Park, and habitat is plentiful for many salamander species.

images.title: Big Hunting Creek
images.altText: A fast flowing stream cutting through a green forest.
images.caption: Winding its way through the ridge, Big Hunting Creek is a popular fly fishing destination.

images.title: Historic Camp Misty Mount
images.altText: A log cabin in the woods
images.caption: Visitors can stay overnight in one of the historic Misty Mount cabins.

images.title: Wolf Rock
images.altText: A large angular boulder that resembles the shape of a wolf.
images.caption: At the end of a boulder field the size of a football field, stands Wolf Rock. Do you see the wolf?

images.title: Blue Ridge Summit
images.altText: A rocky outcrop nestled amongst trees overlooking a valley.
images.caption: Blue Ridge Summit offers hikers a view northward into Pennsylvania.

images.title: Sun Rays Through the Forest at Misty Mount
images.altText: Multiple bright sun rays shining through a forest with log cabins.
images.caption: Natural beauty envelopes the mountainside throughout the day.

images.title: The Horse Trail
images.altText: Two riders, on horseback, walking through a forested trail.
images.caption: The west side of the park is a popular trail riding destination.

images.title: Chimney Rock in the Fall
images.altText: A large rocky outcropping overlooking a mountainside with fall foliage.
images.caption: Chimney Rock provides an excellent view of the mountain's fall foliage.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer (June-Aug) average temperature is between 61 and 81 degrees Fahrenheit. Fall (Sep-Nov) average temperature is between 45 and 64 degrees Fahrenheit. Fall foliage is at its peak in mid-October Winter (Dec-Feb) average temperature is between 24 and 41 degrees Fahrenheit. Winter snowfall is between 5-12" per month. Spring (March-May) average temperature is between 41 and 63 degrees Fahrenheit. Average precipitation is approximately 4 inches per month. (Source: usclimatedata.com)
parks.name: Catoctin Mountain

parks.description: Crowning the grand staircase, Cedar Breaks sits at over 10,000 feet and looks down into a half-mile deep geologic amphitheater. Come wander among timeless bristlecone pines, stand in lush meadows of wildflower, ponder crystal-clear night skies and experience the richness of our subalpine forest.

entranceFees.description: This fee is for visitors, age 16 or older and is valid for 7 days from the time of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee - Per Person

entrancePasses.description:
Admission to Cedar Breaks National Monument for one year from date of purchase. 

This pass covers the entrance fee for the purchaser and three additional people 16 years of age or older. Admission for children 15 & under is free.
entrancePasses.title: Cedar Breaks Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Cedar Breaks National Monument is located east of Cedar City, Utah, just a short drive from Interstate 15. The park is centrally located between Zion and Bryce Canyon National Parks. For detailed driving directions, please visit our Directions & Transportation page by clicking the green button below.

operatingHours.description: Visitor access, services, and activities vary by season. Normally, between late May through mid-October, the road through the park is open to vehicle access. Visitor services and facilities vary, visit the Operating Hours and Seasons or Current Conditions pages for more information.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

addresses.line1: Cedar Breaks National Monument: Administrative Office

images.title: Cedar Breaks Amphitheater
images.altText: The ground falls away from the viewer creating brilliant rock formations of pink, red, and orange.
images.caption: Cedar Breaks Amphitheater

images.title: Cedar Breaks Information Center
images.altText: A small log cabin with a stone chimney on one side.
images.caption: This log cabin built in 1937 housing the information center and park store.

images.title: Wildflowers
images.altText: Yellow sunflowers and orange paint-brush wildflowers in a meadow.
images.caption: Cedar Breaks is famous for wildflowers blooming throughout the summer!

images.title: Bristle-cone Pine Tree
images.altText: Ancient Bristle-cone pine with sun shining through the branches.
images.caption: Ancient Bristle-cone pines grow along the rim at Cedar Breaks National Monument.

images.title: Bluebells on the Rim
images.altText: Bluebell flowers growing on the rim of the Cedar Breaks Amphitheater.
images.caption: Bluebell flowers growing on the rim.

parks.weatherInfo: Cedar Breaks sits at over 10,000 feet in elevation and is usually 10-20 degrees cooler than surrounding parks. Be prepared for cooler temperatures and unpredictable weather. Snow, sleet, and hail can occur at any time of the year, even in the summer! Summer-time highs are between 60 and 70°F and night-time lows dip to 30-40s°F. Thunderstorms frequently develop in the afternoons. Be aware of lightning and avoid exposed trails and overlooks until storms pass.
parks.name: Cedar Breaks

parks.fullName: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove National Historical Park
parks.description: The Shenandoah Valley invites you to learn about its rich heritage, from Native Americans who first shaped the land, to pioneers of this frontier; this fertile area became one of the most important wheat producing regions of the entire South. The Valley also witnessed some of the most dramatic events of the Civil War,including the Battle of Cedar Creek, a decisive October 19, 1864 Union victory.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to enter the Visitor Contact Station, to visit public areas administered by the NPS, or to attend any ranger led program. America the Beautiful - The National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass Series discounts do not apply at partner sites. Contact our partners directly for admission fees to their visitor facilities.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

parks.directionsInfo: Cedar Creek and Belle Grove National Historical Park is along U.S. Route 11 in Middletown, Virginia. Take exit 298 off Interstate 81 to Middletown. The Visitor Contact Station is at 7712 Main Street in Middletown Courts Plaza.

operatingHours.description: Public areas administered by the National Park Service— Morning Attack Trails, Claven Lane parking area, Vermont Monument property and parking area, and park headquarters— are open from sunrise to sunset.
operatingHours.name: NPS-administered Public Areas

images.title: Sunrise over Belle Grove
images.altText: Sunrise over Belle Grove
images.caption: Sunrise over Belle Grove

images.title: The Heater House
images.altText: Image of the Heater House
images.caption: The Heater House

images.title: Kids Program
images.altText: Ranger giving kids Program
images.caption: Ranger Jeff presenting a kids program.

images.title: Cedar Creek and Belle Grove in a Box
images.altText: Visitors watching a ranger program at Belle Grove
images.caption: Ranger Shannon presents Cedar Creek and Belle Grove in a Box.

images.title: Signal Knob Program
images.altText: Ranger presenting program on top of the Massanutten Moutain.
images.caption: Ranger presenting program at Signal Knob.

parks.weatherInfo: Summers in Virginia are often very hot with high heat indexes. Check the weather in advance of your trip, and plan accordingly. Dress for the heat and for sun protection. Pack lots of water. The Shenandoah Valley experiences temperate spring and fall seasons and winters with snowfall and cold temperatures.
parks.name: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove

parks.description: Today the massive buildings of the Ancestral Puebloan people still testify to the organizational and engineering abilities not seen anywhere else in the American Southwest. For a deeper contact with the canyon that was central to thousands of people between 850 and 1250 A.D., come and explore Chaco through guided tours, hiking & biking trails, evening campfire talks, and night sky programs.

entranceFees.description: Vehicle entrance is for all visitors who drive to the park in private vehicles and provides admittance for seven days.
entranceFees.title: Vehicle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Motorcycle entrance allows one motorcycle to enter for seven days.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Allows a single individual traveling on foot, bicycle or as an individual in a non-commercial group to enter the park for seven days.
entranceFees.title: Individual Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Road conditions can be rough or impassable. Please call in advance for updates.

operatingHours.description:
The Visitor Center is open from 8:00am-4:00pm, November-April
The Visitor Center is open from 8:00am-5:00pm, May-October

The park and visitor center is closed on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours

operatingHours.description: All hiking trails and archaeological sites are open from 7am until 5:00pm. After sunset, you must be leaving or if you are camping, you need to be back in the campground.
operatingHours.name: Chaco Culture National Historical Park

images.title: Red Mesa Black on White Bowls
images.altText: Black on White Bowls
images.caption: Many of the things discovered at Chaco came from other places. These bowls came from the Red Mesa area. Red Mesa Black on White was produced from about A.D. 875 to 1040. Due to the lack of adequate resources, very few pots were produced in Chaco Canyon.

images.title: Pueblo Bonito with Cliff Face
images.altText: Pueblo Bonito with Cliff Face
images.caption: Pueblo Bonito is the most famous Chacoan great house. Constructed between 850 and 1150, Pueblo Bonito had almost 700 rooms, 32 kivas, and 3 great kivas.

images.title: Gallup Black on White Pitchers
images.altText: Gallup Black on White Pitchers
images.caption: These pitchers are another form of pottery that was created elsewhere and then brought to Chaco canyon. This particular style was manufactured from A.D. 1030 to 1150.

images.title: Night Sky Above Fajada Butte
images.altText: Night Sky Above Fajada Butte
images.caption: In 2013 Chaco Culture NHP was designated an International Dark Sky Park. The park has night sky and sunrise programs throughout the year.

images.title: Una Vida
images.altText: Black and White Photo of Una Vida Great House
images.caption: Una Vida is one of Chaco's largely un-excavated great houses. It's location provides great views of the canyon floor while being a short walk from a striking rock art panel.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer highs are typically in the 80's to mid-90's. Thunderstorms can produce heavy localized downpours and sudden dramatic drops in temperatures. Winter temperatures will drop to well below freezing most nights. If you plan to camp in the winter, prepare for nighttime temperatures in the teens or lower. Spring and Fall are great times to visit with more moderate temperatures, but unexpected storms can change things dramatically. Monitor local weather forecasts.
parks.name: Chaco Culture

parks.description: Chamizal is more than just an urban park to recreate or enjoy a quiet afternoon. These grounds are a reminder of the harmonious settlement of a 100-year boundary dispute between the United States and Mexico. We celebrate the cultures of the borderlands to promote the same mutual respect that helped to diplomatically resolve an international disagreement.

entranceFees.description: Chamizal National Memorial is a fee-free park.  There is no entrance fee for the park grounds or Cultural Center exhibit. Programs and events sponsored or presented by the Memorial's park rangers are free to the general public.
entranceFees.title: Chamizal Entrance and Sponsored Programs

parks.directionsInfo: Chamizal National Memorial is located in a large, bi-national metropolitan area and easily accessible by road. El Paso International Airport is nearby, as well as an Amtrack train station.

operatingHours.description: The Memorial grounds are open to vehicle and foot traffic only when the gates are open.
operatingHours.name: Entrance Gates / Memorial Grounds

images.title: Mountain View
images.altText: a bench next to a tree with U.S. and Mexican flags flying against a mountain background
images.caption: Chamizal National Memorial stands as a reminder of the effectiveness of diplomacy and the power of friendship.

images.title: Junior Rangers
images.altText: a group of children with hand raised in front of park rangers and ground squirrel mascot
images.caption: Junior Rangers learn about Chamizal National Memorial.

images.title: Trails
images.altText: walking trails cross a field of green grass with mountain in the background
images.caption: Enjoy the green space of Chamizal in the heart of El Paso.

images.title: Theater Performances
images.altText: Women in swirling skirts and men with sombreros and colorful ponchos dance onstage
images.caption: Take in a theater performance such as this ballet folklorico.

images.title: Franklin G. Smith Gallery
images.altText: paintings hang from art gallery walls
images.caption: Browse art from the borderland in the Franklin G. Smith Gallery.

parks.weatherInfo: Chamizal National Memorial is open year-round, but periodic winter weather conditions may cause closure. Please check for alerts on the park website: www.nps.gov/cham. Thunderstorms typically occur during summer and early fall. There may be no shelter to avoid lightning, so please prepare by looking at weather forecasts and paying attention to developing weather conditions.
parks.name: Chamizal

parks.description: Channel Islands National Park encompasses five remarkable islands and their ocean environment, preserving and protecting a wealth of natural and cultural resources. Isolation over thousands of years has created unique animals, plants, and archeological resources found nowhere else on Earth and helped preserve a place where visitors can experience coastal southern California as it once was.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit the Channel Islands National Park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: While the mainland visitor center in Ventura is readily accessible by car or public transportation, the islands are only accessible by park concessionaire boats and planes or private boat. Advanced planning is highly recommended.

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day. Services and facilities have separate hours. Please see descriptions of those facilities elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Channel Islands National Park

images.title: Inspiration Point by Tim Hauf
images.altText: Steep, rugged ocean cliffs extending in an island chain.
images.caption: Inspiration Point, Anacapa Island: One of the most spectacular views in the park can be found from Inspiration Point. Looking to the west, one may see Middle and West Anacapa, with Santa Cruz Island in the distance.

images.title: Arch Point by Tim Hauf
images.altText: Yellow flowers in foreground extending out along a rocky coastline to a natural arch.
images.caption: Arch Point, Santa Barbara Island: With winter rains, the coreopsis emerges from summer's dormancy with light green foliage and bright yellow daisy-like flowers

images.title: Torrey Pines by Tim Hauf
images.altText: Pine tree high on a ridge overlooking a bay with blue water and white sand beach.
images.caption: Torrey Pines, Santa Rosa Island: Torrey pines occur naturally in only two locations throughout the world--on the cool, fog drenched northeastern slopes of Bechers Bay and just north of San Diego.

images.title: Point Bennet by Tim Hauf
images.altText: Brown seals and sea lions on white sand beach with blue water and partly cloudy sky.
images.caption: Point Bennet, San Miguel Island: One of the greatest concentrations of wildlife in the world occurs on San Miguel with over 100,000 pinnipeds gathering to breed, pup, and rest.

images.title: Island Fox by Tim Hauf
images.altText: Rust and grey colored fox in green grass.
images.caption: Island Fox, Santa Cruz Island: Thousands of years of isolation in a unique island environment has resulted in the development of the endemic island fox, a dwarf form of the mainland gray fox.

parks.weatherInfo: In general, the islands have a Mediterranean climate year-round. Temperatures are relatively stable, with highs averaging in the mid-60s (°F) and lows in the low-50s. However, there are seasonal differences that visitors should take into consideration when visiting the park. In addition, visitors also should be aware that ocean and weather conditions vary considerably from day-to-day and island-to-island. For more information visit: http://www.nps.gov/chis/planyourvisit/weather.htm
parks.name: Channel Islands

parks.description: Charles Pinckney was a principal author and signer of the United States Constitution. This remnant of his coastal plantation is preserved to tell the story of a "founding father," his life of public service, the lives of enslaved African Americans on South Carolina Lowcountry plantations and their influences on Charles Pinckney.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees to visit this site.
entranceFees.title: Fee-Free Site

parks.directionsInfo: The park is located on the south side of Long Point Road .7 miles from US Highway 17, or 3 miles if coming from I-526.

operatingHours.description: Park grounds are open Wednesday - Sunday, 9 am - 5 pm. The entrance gate to the parking lot will be shut and locked when grounds are closed. The historic house (visitor center) is open Friday - Sunday, 9 am - 5 pm. Updated: 6-18-2021.
operatingHours.name: Charles Pinckney National Historic Site

images.title: Historic House and Grounds
images.altText: 1828 Lowcountry cottage and grounds
images.caption: The historic house serves as the park's visitor center and features exhibits, film options, and a museum shop.

images.credit: New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation
images.title: Charles Pinckney
images.altText: Charles Pinckney portrait
images.caption: American founding father, Charles Pinckney, was a contributing author and signer of the U.S. Constitution.

images.title: Live Oak
images.altText: Live Oak
images.caption: Spanish Moss drape Live Oak in the early morning sun.

images.title: Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora)
images.altText: Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora)
images.caption: Flowering plants, like this Southern Magnolia, are remnant of historic ornamental gardens once enjoyed by former farm owners and still marveled over by modern visitors.

images.title: Corn Crib
images.altText: Corn Crib
images.caption: Snee Farm, once owned by Charles Pinckney, was a working farm for over 200 years. This corn crib, built in 1910, is one of the few remaining structures of a bygone era.

images.title: Boardwalk and Marsh
images.altText: Boardwalk and Marsh
images.caption: A .25 mile loop trail is a popular activity for visitors to enjoy the grounds and see points of cultural and natural interest along the way.

parks.weatherInfo: Winters are generally mild. Summers are hot and humid.
parks.name: Charles Pinckney

parks.fullName: Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers National Monument
parks.description: Throughout his life, Charles Young overcame countless obstacles in his ascent to prominence. In spite of overt racism and stifling inequality, Young rose through the military ranks to become one of the most respected leaders of his time. A well-rounded man with a steadfast devotion to duty, Young led by example and inspired a generation of new leaders.

emailAddresses.description: Park information email.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to enter the park when it is open to the public.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

parks.directionsInfo: "Youngsholm" is located in Wilberforce, Ohio near Wilberforce University. It is situated less than one mile west of the Wilberforce University and Central State University campuses on U.S. Route 42 at 1120 US Route 42 E.

operatingHours.description: Park grounds are open daily from dawn to dusk.  Please see the Visitor Center section for house hours of operation.  These hours are for the park grounds only.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.title: Youngsholm, June 2020
images.altText: A large grey house with dark grey shutters with a green lawn out front under a blue sky
images.caption: The front of Youngsholm, the park's visitor center

images.title: Charles Young House Boulder
images.altText: A large gray stone boulder with a bronze plaque on it indicating a national historical landmark
images.caption: The large stone boulder with Historic Plaque affixed to it, sits in the front yard of Youngsholm

images.title: Charles Young Spingarn Award
images.altText: An African American man in a military uniform holding a sabre and wearing a cap sitting in a chair
images.caption: Charles Young poses for a portrait shortly before he was awarded the NAACP Spingarn Medal.

images.title: Charles Young on his mount
images.altText: An African American man in a military uniform sitting high on a horse being saluted by a boy
images.caption: Charles Young poses for a portrait with one of his horses as he is saluted by a young, unidentified boy.

images.title: Charles Young and family
images.altText: An african american family posing for a portrait with the mother standing behind the father and kids
images.caption: Charles Young (far right) poses with his family, Ada Young (standing rear), Charles Noel (far left), and Marie Aurelia (sitting middle).

images.title: 24th Infantry in Philippine
images.altText: A long row of African American soldiers standing at attention
images.caption: The 24th Infantry Buffalo Soldiers while in the Philippines, c.1902

images.title: 25th Infantry in Montana
images.altText: Several African American soldiers standing and sitting for a casual portrait
images.caption: Buffalo Soldiers of the 25th Infantry pose for a portrait near Fort Keough, Montana, c.1890.

images.title: 9th Cavalry, K Troop
images.altText: African American soldiers sitting, kneeling and standing for a casual photo
images.caption: Troopers from the 9th Cav, K Troop posing for a group photo, c.1890.

images.title: 10th Cavalry, Troop K on the move
images.altText: Several african american soldiers on horseback parading down a dirt road.
images.caption: Buffalo Soldiers of K Troop, 10th Cavalry on the move in Chickamauga, Ga., c.1898

images.title: Harlem Hellfighters
images.altText: Several African American soldiers waving while standing and sitting on a boat's deck
images.caption: Buffalo Soldiers of the 369th regiment, Harlem Hellfighters, returning home from France during WWI.

images.title: Advancing in the jungle in the South Pacific
images.altText: Three African American soldiers holding rifles and walking amongst tall grass and brush
images.caption: Buffalo Soldiers of the 93rd Infantry advance cautiously in a jungle somewhere in the South Pacific, c.1945

parks.weatherInfo: The park lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 29 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 74 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is just under 40". Snowfall in the winter is generally light with an average total snowfall of about 22".
parks.name: Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers

parks.description: Today the river valley attracts us for so many reasons. Take a solitary walk to enjoy nature’s display, raft leisurely through the rocky shoals with friends, fish the misty waters as the sun comes up, or have a picnic on a Sunday afternoon. Get Outdoors and experience your Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area as you have never done before.

emailAddresses.description: Use this email address to submit contact the park. Once received your email will be directed to the appropriate person to assist you. If you should know the email address of the person you wish to contact please use it.

entrancePasses.description: A CRNRA Daily Park Pass allows a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) to enter the park for one day. The vehicle must park in a designated parking lot. You may purchase a CRNRA Daily Park Pass online at https://www.recreation.gov/sitepass/2626 or in person at Island Ford Visitor Center. Valid America The Beautiful Passes are also valid for parking in the park.
entrancePasses.title: CRNRA Daily Park Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Annual Park Pass allows a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) to park in any designated parking lot of the park during regular park hours for one year. You may purchase an Annual Park Pass online at https://www.recreation.gov/sitepass/2626 or in person at Island Ford Visitor Center. A valid America The Beautiful Pass are is also valid for parking in the park
entrancePasses.title: Annual Park Pass

parks.directionsInfo: To find the Island Ford Visitor Center enter the physical address, 8800 Roberts Drive, Sandy Springs, GA 30350, into your GPS unit or your favorite map software. Once you have arrived at the park entrance turn onto Island Ford Parkway and follow the signs to the park headquarters.

operatingHours.description:
Beginning Monday, May 11, 2020, Chattahoochee River NRA will reopen access to: all park trails and river access, the following parking areas - Abbotts Bridge, Medlock Bridge, Jones Bridge, two parking lots at Island Ford, Johnson Ferry North, Powers Island, Interstate North, Akers Mill, and Paces Mill In addition, entry fees are waived.

The following facilities remain closed at this time: parking areas not listed above as open,restrooms, picnic areas, including shelters, and Hewlett Lodge Visitor Center
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.title: Family Time
images.altText: Two adult Great Blue Herons stand watch over their 3 young chicks in the nest.
images.caption: Great Blue Herons are plentyful along the river. Look towards the tree tops along the river to spot their nest. If you're lucky the whole will be home.

images.title: Look Closely
images.altText: Park ranger showing a group of school children the critter on his arm.
images.caption: School children from the city enjoy visiting the park on a ranger-led hike.

images.title: Marietta Paper Mill
images.altText: Stone ruins of the Marietta Paper Mill surrounded by lush green vegatation.
images.caption: All that is left of the Marietta Paper Mill is a few stone walls in the woods. Hike to the ruins and you'll get a closeup of Sope Creek that was harnessed by the mills.

images.title: Landing A Rainbow
images.altText: Angler in waders landing a fish using a landing net.
images.caption: Fishing the Chattahoochee River can be a great way to spend an afternoon out of the office or as a diversion from rush hour traffic.

images.title: Inviting Trail
images.altText: Trail heading off under a canopy of trees.
images.caption: Trails along the Chattahoochee River are calling you to visit.

parks.weatherInfo: Summers typically consist of long spells of warm, humid weather. Average highs are in the lower 90's and overnight lows range from the upper 60's to lower 70's. Winters are more variable with highs averaging from the mid 50's to lower 60's while the lows average in the mid 30's. Oftentimes, stretches of mild weather will alternate with cold spells. Spring and Autumn seasons are characterized by much variability from day to day and from year to year.
parks.name: Chattahoochee River

parks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
parks.description: Preserving America's early transportation history, the C&O Canal began as a dream of passage to Western wealth. Operating for nearly 100 years the canal was a lifeline for communities along the Potomac River as coal, lumber, and agricultural products floated down the waterway to market. Today it endures as a pathway for discovering historical, natural, and recreational treasures.

emailAddresses.description: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal General Email Inbox

entranceFees.description: Pass is for one private, non-commercial vehicle — passenger cars, pickup trucks, RVs and vans — and is valid at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River and the Great Falls Virginia side of the Potomac River.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Vehicle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Pass is for one motorcycle and is valid at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River and the Great Falls Virginia side of the Potomac River.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Motorcycle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Pass is for one person 16 years of age or older — entering on foot or by bicycle — and is valid at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River and the Great Falls Virginia side of the Potomac River.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Bicycle or On-Foot Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: The commercial pass is valid for date of purchase plus six days at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. Please note that fees are based on vehicle capacity and not actual occupants. Fee does not include an additional charge of $10 per person.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Commercial Tour Entrance Fee (1-6 passengers)

entranceFees.description: The commercial pass is valid for date of purchase plus six days at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. Please note that fees are based on vehicle capacity and not actual occupants.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Commercial Tour Entrance Fee (7-25 passengers)

entranceFees.description: The commercial pass is valid for date of purchase plus six days at the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. Please note that fees are based on vehicle capacity and not actual occupants.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls only - Commercial Tour Entrance Fee (26+ passengers)

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one full year from the month of purchase. Permits access to Great Falls Park, Virginia and the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. The annual pass allows entrance for the pass holder and additional passengers in a single private non-commercial vehicle, or pass holder plus three adults when entering on foot or bicycle. Purchase online
entrancePasses.title: Great Falls Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: The park has numerous access points. There is no main entrance. In Washington, DC, the C&O Canal begins in Georgetown on 29th Street NW, south of M Street, and runs alongside Canal Road / Clara Barton Parkway out of DC to the west. The entrance to Great Falls is at Canal Road and MacArthur Blvd in Potomac, MD. Park Headquarters and the Williamsport Visitor Center are located off I-81 at exit 2. Cumberland Visitor Center is off I-68 at exit 43C. See the maps page for more.

operatingHours.description: The towpath is open 365 days a year.
operatingHours.name: C&O Canal Towpath

images.title: Great Falls of the Potomac
images.altText: The rushing river cascades over the rocks of the Potomac
images.caption: The area of Great Falls is one of the reasons for the C&O Canal needed to be built for boat traffic.

images.title: Bike rider along the towpath
images.altText: A single bike rider on the towpath next to the widewater section of the canal.
images.caption: The towpath offers a serene bike riding experience.

images.title: Lockhouse 16 along the Canal
images.altText: A whitewashed lockhouse sits above a stone lock with wooden crib.
images.caption: Lockhouse 16 sits atop a stone outcropping above the lock.

images.title: Hancock Visitor Center (Bowles House)
images.altText: Park sign in front of the historic Bowles House
images.caption: One of seven Park visitor centers, the Bowles House sits along an empty canal bed in Hancock.

images.title: Big Slackwater
images.altText: Fog over the Potomac River alongside the Canal towpath.
images.caption: Big Slackwater is a 3 mile stretch where canal boats entered the Potomac River to travel above Dam 4.

images.title: Charles F. Mercer Replica Canal Boat
images.altText: A replica double decker canal boat is being pulled upstream by mules.
images.caption: Mule-drawn canal boat rides are offered at Great Falls Tavern, April through October.

parks.weatherInfo: The Washington, DC, area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy. Precipitation averages 2-4” monthly, year-round. The climate gradually gets cooler and wetter further west along the canal where the elevation is higher.
parks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

parks.description: NPS helps you learn about and enjoy the Chesapeake Bay, the largest estuary in North America. Here, you can visit major league cities, colonial towns, American Indian landscapes, farms and fishing villages. You can learn to kayak, pick crabs, go fishing, tour a lighthouse, slurp oysters, and slow down to enjoy the natural beauty of the Chesapeake.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to visit the Chesapeake Bay Office. Some of the state parks, museums, wildlife refuges and other sites throughout the Chesapeake watershed may charge entrance fees. Visit FindYourChesapeake.com to find complete information about each partner site.
entranceFees.title: NPS Chesapeake Bay Office

parks.directionsInfo: The Chesapeake Bay office is located off of Aris T. Allen Blvd in Annapolis, Maryland. Traveling east on Route 50, take the exit towards Riva road and 665, Aris T. Allen Blvd. Continue on 665 to Forest drive. Our office is on the left through the first light, across from the Safeway.

operatingHours.description: Core hours at the Chesapeake Bay Office are from 9 am to 4 pm Monday through Friday and the office is closed on federal holidays. Quite frequently, the office is open for business at least one hour earlier and one hour later than core hours.
operatingHours.name: NPS Chesapeake Bay Office Hours

images.title: Cape Charles
images.altText: A view of docks and boats in the waterside town of Cape Charles VA
images.caption: Cape Charles on Virginia's lower Eastern Shore is a bayside gem with many opportunities for visitors to enjoy the water.

images.title: Calvert Cliffs
images.altText: A family walks along the beach searching for fossils at Calvert Cliffs.
images.caption: Calvert Cliffs is a well known destination for fossil hunting.

images.title: Great Falls
images.altText: A series of waterfalls and rocky conditions show the fall line on the Potomac River
images.caption: Great Falls marks the fall line of the Potomac River.

images.title: Tangier Island
images.altText: At sunset, a boater returns to the docks used by working watermen at Tangier Island.
images.caption: At sunset, a boater returns to the docks used by working watermen at Tangier Island.

images.title: Kayak Kids
images.altText: Four youngsters paddle kayaks on calm waters of the Susquehanna River
images.caption: Four youngsters paddle kayaks on calm waters of the Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania.

parks.weatherInfo: Annapolis, Maryland has a warm humid temperate climate with hot summers and no dry season. Over the course of a year, the temperature typically varies from 29°F to 86°F and is rarely below 19°F or above 91°F. The warm season lasts from May 30 to September 18 with an average daily high temperature above 77°F. The cold season lasts from November 29 to March 4 with an average daily high temperature below 50°F.
parks.name: Chesapeake Bay

parks.description: In 1863, Union and Confederate forces fought for control of Chattanooga, known as the "Gateway to the Deep South." The Confederates were victorious at nearby Chickamauga in September. However, renewed fighting in Chattanooga that November provided Union troops victory and control of the city. After the fighting, a Confederate soldier ominously wrote, "This...is the death-knell of the Confederacy."

entranceFees.description:
An entry fee is charged per person, ages 16 and older, ages 15 and under enter the park for free. The entrance ticket covers the number of individuals entering Point Park and is valid for 7 days from the time of purchase. Entrance tickets must be purchased at the fee station at the Point Park gate.    

**Annual Passes, Volunteer Passes, Senior Passes, and Access Passes are accepted at Point Park (these passes cannot be scanned in the fee machines)**
entranceFees.title: Point Park (Lookout Mountain Battlefield) Entrance Fee - Per Person

entranceFees.description: No entrance fee is charged at Chickamauga Battlefield
entranceFees.title: Chickamauga Battlefield

entranceFees.description:
There are no entrance fees for any of the reservations on Missionary Ridge. The reservations include: 

Sherman Reservation
Bragg Reservation
73rd Pennsylvania Reservation
Ohio Reservation
Iowa Reservation
De Long Reservation
Turchin Reservation
entranceFees.title: Missionary Ridge

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee at Orchard Knob Reservation.
entranceFees.title: Orchard Knob

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees at any of the sites on Moccasin Bend National Archeological District
entranceFees.title: Moccasin Bend National Archeological District

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to Signal Point Reservation
entranceFees.title: Signal Point

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee at Cravens House Reservation

entrancePasses.description:
Visitors who purchase a Point Park Annual Pass can visit Point Park on an unlimited basis throughout the year. The pass allows entry to the park for the pass owner and three other individuals. 

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: Point Park Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description:
A lifetime pass for citizens or permanent residents of the US, age 62 or older. One person can sign the pass. 

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: Lifetime Senior Pass

entrancePasses.description:
An annual pass valid 12 months from month of purchase. Two people can sign the pass. 

*current US Military Members and 4th graders are eligible for different annual passes*

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description:
A lifetime pass for citizens or permanent residents of the US who have a permanent disability, regardless of age. One person can sign the pass.

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

entrancePasses.description:
A yearly pass for citizens or permanent residents of the US, age 62 or older. One person can sign the pass. Four annual Senior Passes purchased in consecutive years can be traded in for a lifetime pass.

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Senior Pass

entrancePasses.description:
A yearly pass for students in the 4th grade. You must complete the activities at www.everkidinapark.gov and present a printed voucher to be exchanged for a pass. 

Please note that pass availability might vary from day to day. If you are planning on visiting Point Park to purchase a pass, please call the Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center at 423-821-7786 to confirm pass availability that day.
entrancePasses.title: 4th Grade Pass

parks.directionsInfo: From I-75, take exit 350 onto Battlefield Parkway (GA HWY 2) and continue to the intersection of Battlefield Parkway and LaFayette Road. Turn left onto LaFayette Road and continue for approximately 1 mile. The visitor center will be on the right. From I-24, take exit 180 onto Rossville Boulevard (US HWY 27). Continue south to the intersection of Battlefield Parkway. Drive through the intersection, continuing on the LaFayette Road. The visitor center will be on the right.

operatingHours.description: All units of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park are open during daylight hours, with the following exceptions: Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center and Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center are currently open 8:30 am to 5 pm, daily. Visitor centers are closed Dec. 25 and Jan. 1. Point Park main entrance opens at 8:30 am, daily. Cravens House is open seasonally. US Hwy 27 Picnic Area, Wilder Brigade Monument, & Signal Mountain restrooms are closed Dec.1 - March 15.
operatingHours.name: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park

parks.weatherInfo: The climate in northern Georgia is generally temperate. Short, cool winters give relief from hot summers. Most visitors enjoy this area during long, mild fall and spring seasons.
parks.name: Chickamauga & Chattanooga

parks.directionsInfo: From US I-35 drive through the towns of Davis and towards the town of Sulphur. There are a variety of destinations in the park to choose from.

parks.weatherInfo: Summers are hot and humid. Temperatures above 100ºF occur, and humidity often exceeds 50%. Winters are mild and prolonged freezes are rare. Thunderstorms are common April through July.

parks.description: A "Wonderland of Rocks" is waiting for you to explore at Chiricahua National Monument. The 8-mile paved scenic drive and 17-miles of day-use hiking trails provide opportunities to discover the beauty, natural sounds, and inhabitants of this 12,025 acre site. Visit the Faraway Ranch Historic District to discover more about the people who have called this area home.

entranceFees.description: Chiricahua National Monument is a fee free park. No entrance fee is required.
entranceFees.title: Chiricahua Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Chiricahua National Monument is located 120 miles southeast of Tucson. Take I-10 east from Tucson to the first exit for Willcox. Travel 3 miles into town to the stoplight and turn right. You will follow Arizona State Highway 186 for 32 miles to the junction of Arizona State Highway 181. Turn left and 4 miles later you will be at the Chiricahua entrance station. Maximum vehicle length is 29 feet to drive beyond the visitor center. A hiking shuttle is available daily at 9 am from the visitor center.

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24/7. Extreme weather events or fire can lead to closures of the park road.
operatingHours.name: Park

images.title: View from Massai Point
images.altText: Many rock pinnacles with a valley and mountain range in background
images.caption: Massai Point offers excellent views of the standing rocks at Chiricahua

images.title: Faraway Ranch
images.altText: A ranch house in a green field surrounds by low mountains
images.caption: Faraway Ranch preserves the heritage of early European settlers in the Chiricahua Mountains

images.title: Echo Canyon Grotto
images.altText: Children climb through rock archways
images.caption: The standing rocks at Chiricahua create natural nooks and crannies ready to be explored

images.title: Bonita Canyon
images.altText: A narrow road winds between tall oaks and rock cliffs
images.caption: Bonita Canyon Scenic Drive winds through standing rocks and rhyolite cliffs, climbing to Massai Point at 6900 ft / 2100 m.

images.title: Big Balanced Rock
images.altText: Large rock balanced on a small point
images.caption: Big Balanced Rock

parks.weatherInfo: Chiricahua National Monument ranges from 5,124 feet / 1,562 meters in elevation at the entrance station to 7,310 feet / 2,228 meters at the summit of Sugarloaf Mountain. You can enjoy the differences of four seasons. http://www.nps.gov/chir/planyourvisit/weather.htm
parks.name: Chiricahua

parks.description: No place in the Caribbean still demonstrates the architectural, economic, and political influence of Europe like Christiansted National Historic Site. Come wander through 18th century buildings in one the Caribbean's few urban parks. It is a unique experience that you will never forget.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee for adults 16 years and older is $7 USD per person,  Children under the age of 16 are free. For school groups, please call the Division of Interpretation at 340.7730.1460 ext. 232. Valid Federal passes are available and honored at the park.
entranceFees.title: Christiansted NHS Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: This annual pass covers entrance fees at national parks and national wildlife refuges and standard amenity day use fees at national forests and grasslands, and at lands and waters managed by the Bureau of Land Management, the Bureau of Reclamation, and the Army Corps of Engineers. It admits the pass owner and their accompanying passengers, or three (3) adults. The Annual Pass costs $80.00
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful – The National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass

entrancePasses.description: This is a no-fee lifetime pass for individuals with permanent disabilities. This pass will get the cardholder plus 3 additional persons age 16 and older entry to Fort Christiansvaern. Applicants must provide documentation of permanent disability and residency or citizenship.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: This pass is available only for active duty military personnel and dependents with proper identification (Common Access Card or Military ID/Form 1173). The Annual Military Pass may be obtained at the visitor booth at Fort Christiansvaern.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Pass for U.S. Military

entrancePasses.description: This pass for U.S. citizens and permanent residents age 62 and older will get the cardholder plus three (3) additional persons age 16 and older entry to Fort Christiansvaern. Passes are sold at the visitor booth in Fort Christiansvaern. The Lifetime Pass costs $80, and the Annual Senior Pass is available for $20.
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful – The National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Senior Pass - $20.00 (Annual), $80.00 (Lifetime)

parks.directionsInfo: To Christiansted National Historic Site from Henry E. Rohlsen Airport: Drive east on Route 64 to Melvin Edwards Highway (Route 66). Turn right and continue for 4.8 miles (7.2 kilometers). Continue straight onto Old Centerline Road (Queen Mary Highway), and continue straight onto the Christiansted Bypass 3.7 miles (5.9 km). Turn left onto Hospital Street. The parking lot for Christiansted National Historic Site will be on your right.

operatingHours.description: The Park is open every day from 8:30 am to 4:30 pm. The park is closed on Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. All cars must be removed from the parking lot by 4:30 p.m. or they will be towed.
operatingHours.name: Christiansted National Historic Site

images.title: Fort Christiansvaern
images.altText: fiew of the exterior of the fort
images.caption: Fort Christiansvaern was built between 1738 and 1749. It is made of brick, stone, and coral block.

images.title: Customs House
images.altText: view of the front steps of the Customs House
images.caption: A customs house has stood on this spot since the 1730s. The current building was finished in the 1842.

images.title: Fort Christiansvaern - Commandant's Quarters
images.altText: View of the interior courtyard and stairs to the quarters of the fort's Commandant.
images.caption: Fort Christiansvaern served as the residence for the Danish colony's Governor, then for the fort's Commandant and his family.

images.title: Steeple Building
images.altText: view of the Steeple Building from the street corner.
images.caption: First known as the Church of Our Lord of Zebaoth, the church was completed in 1751, and consecrated in 1753. The steeple tower was built 1793-1796.

images.title: Commerce and the Christiansted Wharf
images.altText: Ca. 1815 painting of activity at the wharf in Christiansted, St. Croix.
images.caption: The Christiansted wharf was a cosmopolitan port throughout the 18th and 19th centuries.

images.title: Young Alexander Hamilton
images.altText: Drawing of Alexander Hamilton, age 18
images.caption: Alexander Hamilton spent his youth on St. Croix, from 1765 until 1772. This drawing was made shortly after he left the island.

parks.weatherInfo: Welcome to the tropics!
parks.name: Christiansted

parks.description: Emigrants of the California Trail describe the rocks here in vivid detail as "a city of tall spires,” “steeple rocks," and "the silent city." Today, this backcountry byway attracts rock climbers, campers, hikers, hunters, and those with the spirit of adventure. There's inspirational scenery, exceptional opportunities for geologic study, and remnants of the Old West awaiting your discovery.

entranceFees.description: Entrance to City of Rocks National Reserve is free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: From Boise: take I-84 East to exit 216 (Declo); go south on Highway 77 to Conner Creek Junction; turn right (west) on Highway 77 Spur to Almo. The visitor center and the park entrance are south of the post office and businesses. From Pocatello: take I-86 West to I-84 West to exit 216 and proceed as above. From Salt Lake City: take I-84 west to exit 245 (Sublette), turn left and go west to Malta. From Malta take Highway 77. Take Highway 77 Spur to Almo.

operatingHours.description:
The National Reserve is open 365 days a year, 7 days a week, 24 hours a day.  Many roads are not maintained during the winter and may become impassable from late November through March. For current conditions visitors are encouraged to check with the Visitor Center or watch for alerts on our website and social media.

During summer the Visitor Center is open every day 8:00 am to 4:30 pm. Fall/Winter the Visitor Center is open 8:00 am to 4:30 pm Tuesday-Saturday, closed holidays.
operatingHours.name: City of Rocks National Reserve

images.title: City of Rocks Pinnacles
images.altText: Dramatic granite formations jut up from a mountainous landscape.
images.caption: City of Rocks offers sweeping vistas and awe-inspiring scenery.

images.title: North Fork Circle Creek
images.altText: Grand scenic view looking down from a high elevation. Granite spires jut up from the landscape.
images.caption: The majority of outcrops in City of Rocks and all of the pinnacles are either Almo Pluton or Green Creek Complex granite.

images.title: Twin Sisters
images.altText: Two granite pinnacles right next to each other that are similar in size and shape.
images.caption: Twin Sisters may be similar in size and shape, but one is 2.5 billion years old, the younger sister is only 28 million years old.

images.title: Window Arch at City of Rocks
images.altText: A granite arch is displayed on the horizon
images.caption: Forces of nature sculpt unexpected features in granite such as Window Arch

images.title: Replica Emigrant Wagons at City of Rocks
images.altText: Replica emigrant wagons rest unhitched at sunrise
images.caption: Nearly 250,000 California-bound emigrants traveled through City of Rocks (1843-1882)

images.title: Emigrant Signatures at City of Rocks
images.altText: Emigrant signature written with axle-grease on granite
images.caption: California-bound emigrants painted their signature on Register Rock in 1850

images.title: Climber on Morning Glory Spire
images.altText: A climber ascends a granite spire with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: Over half of the 100,000 annual visitors to City of Rocks come to experience climbing

images.title: Window Arch
images.altText: Granite arch with sunset peeking through.
images.caption: Window Arch is one of many impressive rock features found in City of Rocks.

images.title: Stormy Spring Weather
images.altText: Dark storm clouds loom over a sunny green hill covered in granite formations.
images.caption: Spring is a beautiful time to visit City of Rocks.

images.title: Silent City of Rocks
images.altText: Snowy granite pinnacles.
images.caption: Winter is a great time to experience quiet and solitude in City of Rocks.

parks.weatherInfo: City of Rocks is located in south-central Idaho within the northern edge of the Basin and Range geologic province. Outdoor recreation can be pleasant from April through October. Summers are generally dry with 10 to 15 inches of precipitation in winter and spring. Summer temperatures range widely with night time lows occasionally approaching freezing and midday highs nearing 100° F; however, the typical range of low and high temperature is 45-85. Thunderstorms are common in the summer months (June - August)
parks.name: City Of Rocks

parks.description: On forested hills surrounding the nation's capital are the remnants of a complex system of Civil War fortifications. These strategic buttresses transformed the young capital into one of the world's most fortified cities. By 1865, 68 forts and 93 batteries armed with over 800 cannons encircled Washington, DC. Today, you can visit 17 of the original sites now managed by the National Park Service.

entranceFees.description: Civil War Defenses of Washington sites are fee free.
entranceFees.title: Civil War Defenses Of Washington

entrancePasses.description: No entrance passes are required.
entrancePasses.title: Civil War Defenses of Washington

parks.directionsInfo: Please call 202-829-4650. Directions vary based on your preference of site.

operatingHours.description: Grounds open to visitors dawn to dusk
operatingHours.name: Civil War Defenses of Washington

images.caption: Fort Davis (Fall Day)

parks.weatherInfo: Civil War Defenses of Washington sites will be open. For Updates, visit the parks alert section of the website.

parks.description: Clara Barton dedicated her life and energies to help others in times of need - both home and abroad, in peacetime as well as during military emergencies. Glen Echo was her home the last 15 years of her life and the structure illustrates her dedication and concern for those less fortunate than herself.

entranceFees.description: Site entrance and parking
entranceFees.title: Entrance fee

entrancePasses.description: No fees, pass not required
entrancePasses.title: No fees, pass not required

parks.directionsInfo: By Car: Capital Beltway (I-495), Maryland outer loop exit 40 Cabin John Parkway to Clara Barton Parkway; Virginia inner loop exit 41 Clara Barton Parkway East; follow Clara Barton Parkway to MacArthur Boulevard and Glen Echo exit, left onto MacArthur Boulevard, straight across traffic circle at Goldsboro Road, next left onto Oxford Road, end of street, parking lots on the left. By Metro: Red Line to Bethesda or Friendship Heights Station, transfer to Montgomery County Ride-On Bus # 29, Glen Echo stop.

operatingHours.description: Following guidance from the CDC and recommendations from state and local public health in consultation with NPS Public Health Service officers, Clara Barton NHS is temporarily closed.

parks.description: On May 13, 1607, Jamestown was established as the first permanent English settlement in North America. Three cultures came together – European, Virginia Indian and African–to create a new society that would eventually seek independence from Great Britain. On October 19, 1781, American and French troops defeated the British at Yorktown in the last major battle of the American Revolutionary War.

entranceFees.description: Adult (16 and older) -$15; good for 7 days entrance to Yorktown Battlefield (and NPS areas at Historic Jamestowne); can be upgraded to see Preservation Virginia areas at Historic Jamestowne for an additional $10 at the Historic Jamestowne Visitor Center. parks.weatherInfo: During the summer season visitors should dress in light, comfortable clothing, wear comfortable shoes and use sunscreen. We recommended you carry a bottle of water with you. High temperatures and high humidity create higher risk of heat cramps, heat exhaustion and heatstroke. Most of the Historic site is out-of-doors and although not a great distance from an air-conditioned building, staying properly hydrated will help prevent these illnesses. During the fall visitors should have a light jacket available.
parks.name: Colonial

parks.description: Colorado National Monument preserves one of the grand landscapes of the American West. But this treasure is much more than a monument. Towering monoliths exist within a vast plateau and canyon panorama. You can experience sheer-walled, red rock canyons along the twists and turns of Rim Rock Drive, where you may spy bighorn sheep and soaring eagles.

entranceFees.description:
Allows all people in one private non-commercial vehicle entrance into the Monument.
Receipt good for 7 consecutive days.
Entrance Fees are paid at the entrance station by credit card, cash or by check. Seven day passes can also be purchased on-line at https://www.yourpassnow.com/parkpass.
entranceFees.title: Private Non-commercial Vehicle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description:
Allows driver and passenger of one motorcycle entrance to the Monument.
Receipt is good for 7 consecutive days.
Entrance Fees are paid at the entrance station by credit card, cash or by check.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description:
Allows one person, 16 years of age and older, entrance to the Monument. Typically this covers hikers and bicyclists.
Receipt is good for 7 consecutive days.
Entrance Fees are paid at the entrance station or in self-serve stations at trail heads by credit card, cash or by check.
entranceFees.title: Individual Entrance Fee (Hiker, Bicyclist)

entranceFees.description:
A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization. The entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles that can carry seven or more passengers regardless of the actual number of passengers. Possession of passes or the ages of the passengers does not affect the price charged.
Sedan - 1-6 passengers $25 + $5 per person to a maximum of $40

Possession of passes or the ages of the passengers does not affect the price charged.
Van - 7-15 passengers: $40

Organized groups such as Scouts, Rotary, Clubs, Youth Groups, Churches, Reunions, etc. that do not qualify for an Academic Fee Waiver are charged as follows:

$5.00 per person, not to exceed the equivalent commercial rate.

entrancePasses.description: Covers entrance fees for any two passholders and accompanying passengers in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle at Colorado National Monument. This pass can be purchased at either entrance to Colorado National Monument. Good for one year from purchase. This pass does not cover camping fees. Non-transferable and non-refundable.
entrancePasses.title: Colorado National Monument Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Driving Westbound on Highway I-70 towards Grand Junction, Exit 31 (Horizon Drive). Follow signs through Grand Junction to the east entrance. The visitor center and campground are 19 miles from the east entrance. Eastbound on Highway I-70 take Exit 19 (Fruita). Turn south on Highway 340 to the west entrance, which is approximately three miles from Fruita. The visitor center and campground are four miles up from the west entrance.

operatingHours.description: The Monument is open 24 hours a day year-round. Rim Rock Road is only closed for poor road conditions (snow, ice, rock fall, etc). For updates on storm or temporary closures call the park hotline at (970) 858-3617 ext 402.
operatingHours.name: Colorado National Monument

parks.weatherInfo: Spring - Daytime high temperatures 70-85 F (21-30 C), nighttime low temperature 30-50 F (-1 - +10 C). Summer - Daytime high temperatures can reach 100 F (38 C), afternoon thunderstorms common. Fall - Similar to spring temperatures, sudden changes in weather common. Snow can occur in October. Winter - Daytime highs vary from 10 - 45 F (-12 - +7 C). Snow common, patches of snow and ice stay around most of the winter.
parks.name: Colorado

parks.description: When Samuel Colt started his Hartford factory on the banks of the Connecticut River in 1847, it followed years of mismanagement and failure. Soon, demand for Colt's revolver would change his fortunes and the Colt empire was born. Following Colt's untimely death in 1862, his wife, Elizabeth Colt, would lead the company to its legendary status, and influence Hartford for over 40 years.

emailAddresses.description: General park information and requests.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit Coltsville National Historical Park, but some affiliated sites may have entrance fees. Check their websites as you plan your visit.
entranceFees.title: Coltsville Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Coltsville NHP is located in Hartford, Connecticut in the heart of the Sheldon/Charter Oak Neighborhood. See our directions page for how to get here.

addresses.line2: c/o Springfield Armory National Historic Site

images.title: Colt Armory Complex
images.altText: Blue dome atop a large factory behind a river
images.caption: The Colt Armory Complex next to the CT River with its signature Blue Onion Dome

images.title: Coltsville Dome and the Church of the Good Shepherd
images.altText: The Blue Onion Dome of the Armory and the spire of the Church against a cloudy blue sky.
images.caption: The Blue Onion Dome was rebuilt after the fire in February of 1864. Today it graces the skyline of Hartford, just as the the Church of the Good Shepherd does, reminding those who see if of the Colts and their legacy.

images.title: The Church of the Good Shepherd
images.altText: A church and trees against the backdrop of a bight blue sky and clouds.
images.caption: The Church of the Good Shepherd was built by Elizabeth Colt as memorial to her husband, Samuel Colt, and their three children who passed in infancy. It was designed by Edward Tuckerman Potter and dedicate in 1869.

images.title: Armsmear
images.altText: A tan and brown building, built in the Italian Villa style with rounded arches and balconies.
images.caption: Armsmear was the family home of Samuel and Elizabeth Colt built between 1856 and 1857. It would remain the family home, until the death of Elizabeth in 1905. Today it is a non-profit organization that provides housing for senior women of limited means.

images.title: The Caldwell Memorial Parish House
images.altText: A tan and brown building with numerous design elements meant resemble a ship, against a blue sky.
images.caption: The Caldwell Memorial Parish House was built in memory of Caldwell Colt, Elizabeth and Samuel's son. It was designed by Edward Tuckerman Potter and dedicated in 1896.

images.title: The Colt Carriage House
images.altText: A red brown building with a wooden enclosed spaced in front of trees on a cloudy day.
images.caption: The Carriage House is located in Colt Park next to the Gardner House.

images.title: Samuel Colt Statue
images.altText: A memorial statue of a young and adult Samuel Colt
images.caption: The statute was built as a memorial to Samuel by his wife, Elizabeth Colt. It was dedicated in 1906 after her passing in 1905.

images.title: Samuel Colt Statue
images.altText: A statue of a young and an adult Samuel Colt in front of a tree with a cloudy sky.
images.caption: The statue was built as a memorial to Samuel Colt by his wife, Elizabeth Colt. It was dedicated in 1906 after her passing in 1905. The statue serves as a reminder the role the Colts had in the development of the City of Hartford.

images.title: Coltsville Worker Housing
images.altText: A white stone building with multiple windows and three chimneys with green grass and a black fence.
images.caption: Twenty worker houses were built behind the Colt Firearm Armory in 1856. These houses provided a living space for the workers of the Colt Factory.

parks.weatherInfo: Hartford experiences all four seasons. It is typically hot in the summer and cold in the winter with a pleasant spring and autumn.
parks.name: Coltsville

parks.description: Astonishing biodiversity exists in Congaree National Park, the largest intact expanse of old growth bottomland hardwood forest remaining in the southeastern United States. Waters from the Congaree and Wateree Rivers sweep through the floodplain, carrying nutrients and sediments that nourish and rejuvenate this ecosystem and support the growth of national and state champion trees.

entranceFees.description: No Entrance Fee
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: From Interstate 77, Exit 5 At Exit 5 turn onto SC Hwy 48 East/Bluff Road. Following the brown and white "Congaree National Park" directional signs, travel approximately 8 miles on and then take a slight right onto Old Bluff Road. Follow Old Bluff Road for 4.5 miles to the park entrance sign, which will be on the right. Proceed one mile to the Harry Hampton Visitor Center. Parking lots will be on the right.

operatingHours.description: Congaree National Park is open 24 hours a day year-round.
operatingHours.name: Congaree Operating Hours

images.caption: View of the Congaree River during the Fall

parks.weatherInfo: Check the forecast before getting on the road. Conditions can change rapidly within the park. Flooding can happen with little or no warning, so make sure to check water levels for Cedar Creek and the Congaree River.
parks.name: Congaree

parks.description: Officially established in 1965, National Mall and Memorial Parks actually protects some of the older parkland in the National Park System. Areas within this premier park provide visitors with ample opportunities to commemorate presidential legacies; honor the courage and sacrifice of war veterans; and celebrate the United States commitment to freedom and equality.

entranceFees.description: No Entrance Fee to enter park site.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: No Passes
entrancePasses.title: No Passes

parks.directionsInfo: Parking Because of limited parking availability, public transportation is recommended. Street parking is available on Constitution Ave. during posted hours. Bicycle Sidewalks and paved paths are open to bicycles in the park. Please walk your bicycle across the footbridge to Signers Island. Public Transportation Constitution Gardens is approximately 1 mile from three Metro stops: Foggy Bottom, Farragut West

operatingHours.description: The sites of National Mall and Memorial Parks (other than the Washington Monument) are always open to the public. Restrooms, museums and elevators close in the evenings (check individual sites for hours).
operatingHours.name: Always Open

parks.weatherInfo: Washington DC gets to see all four seasons. Humidity will make the temps feel hotter in summer and colder in winter. Spring (March - May) Temp: Average high is 65.5 degrees with a low of 46.5 degrees Summer (June - August) Temp: Average high is 86 degrees with a low of 68.5 degrees Fall (September - November) Temp: Average high is 68 degrees with a low of 51.5 degrees Winter (December - February) Temp: Average high is 45 degrees with a low of 30 degrees (Source: www.usclimatedata.com)

parks.description: It was a journey of conquest filled with exploration, wonder - and cruelty. Inspired by tales of vast cities of gold, 339 European soldiers and hundreds of Aztec allies embarked on an epic journey through arid deserts and rugged mountains. They encountered rich traditions and brought new technologies. The resulting collision and combination of cultures reverberates today.

entranceFees.description: Coronado National Memorial is a Fee Free park, no entrance fee is required.
entranceFees.title: Coronado National Memorial Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: From the city of Sierra Vista continue south on Hwy 92 about 20 miles and turn right onto S. Coronado Memorial Drive. Follow Coronado Memorial Drive (it will turn into E Montezuma Canyon Rd) 5 miles to the Visitor Center.

operatingHours.description: Coronado National Memorial is a day use park. The trails, picnic area, waysides, and Montezuma Pass overlook are open each day from one half hour before sunrise to one half hour after sunset.
operatingHours.name: Park

parks.weatherInfo: Though the park shares a border with our southern neighbors, the elevation and the mountain ecosystem keep Coronado National Memorial relatively cool in the summer, and winter can bring snow. Summers are warm, with daytime temps in the 90s F (32-37 C) and low humidity in May, June, and July. The summer rainy season (monsoon) is between late June and early September. Monsoon thunderstorms can cause flash floods. Winter temps can fall below freezing at night, with highs 40-60 F (4-15 C).
parks.name: Coronado

parks.description: “…our success was complete…” -- Daniel Morgan to Nathanael Greene, January 19, 1781 A pasturing area at the time of the battle, this Revolutionary War site commemorates the place where Daniel Morgan and his army turned the flanks of Banastre Tarleton's British army. This classic military tactic, known as a double envelopment, was one of only a few in history.

entranceFees.description: It is free to visit Cowpens National Battlefield.

parks.directionsInfo: From I-85 S, take exit 83. Turn left on Hwy 110, approx. 8 miles. Turn right on Hwy 11. The park is about a half mile on the right. From I-85 N, take exit 92, turn right toward Chesnee on Hwy 11, approx.10 miles on the left. From I-26 E, take exit 5, turn left toward Chesnee on Hwy 11, approx. 20 miles on the right. From I-26 W, take I-85 North, take exit 83. Turn left on Hwy 110, approx. 8 miles. Turn right on Hwy 11. The park is about a half mile on the right.

operatingHours.description:
The visitor center parking lot is open 9:00 - 5:00, with the exception of certain federal holidays. Front gate closes at 5:00. After hours parking is located 1 mile east at the intersection of Hwy 11 and Hayes Road and is open dawn to dusk.

Staff offers outside visitor services Wednesday - Friday, 10:00 am - 3:00 pm.

parks.description: Crater Lake inspires awe. Native Americans witnessed its formation 7,700 years ago, when a violent eruption triggered the collapse of a tall peak. Scientists marvel at its purity: fed by rain and snow, it’s the deepest lake in the USA and one of the most pristine on earth. Artists, photographers, and sightseers gaze in wonder at its blue water and stunning setting atop the Cascade Mountain Range.

number of passengers. This fee is valid for 7 consecutive days with the same company and the same passengers.

entrancePasses.description: Valid only at Crater Lake National Park and Lava Beds National Monument. The Crater Lake annual pass is good for one year from the issue month. It admits the pass owner and accompanying passengers in a single, private, noncommercial vehicle or pass owner and three persons when entry is by other means.
entrancePasses.title: Crater Lake Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: From the west (Medford) - Take Hwy 62 to the West Entrance. Open year-round. From the south (Klamath Falls) - Take Hwy 97 north to Hwy 62 to the South Entrance. Open year-round. The North Entrance is on Hwy 138 and is accessed from Interstate 5 east at Roseburg or Hwy 97 south from Bend and Chemult. Winter travelers from Roseburg take Route 138 east to Route 230 south to Route 62 east to the park's west entrance. Travelers from Bend take Route 97 south to Route 62 to the park's south entrance.

operatingHours.description: Crater Lake National Park is open year-round, 24 hours a day. Some roads, trails, and facilities, however, are closed seasonally due to snow. North Entrance Road, and West and East Rim Drives close for the season on November 1 (or earlier if there is significant snowfall). Crews begin removing snow from these roads in April, but opening dates vary. The North Entrance Road and West Rim Drive tend to open in early June. The East Rim Drive typically opens in early July.
operatingHours.name: Crater Lake National Park

operatingHours.description: The park's West Entrance on Oregon Highway 62 is open year round.
operatingHours.name: West Entrance

operatingHours.description: The park's South Entrance on Oregon Highway 62 is open year round.
operatingHours.name: South Entrance

operatingHours.description: The park's North Entrance, off of Oregon Highway 138, is usually open from June through October. It is closed in the winter due to snow. Opening dates vary each year depending on snowfall.
operatingHours.name: North Entracnce
