parks.name: Eisenhower

parks.fullName: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
parks.description: Travel along El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail to experience and learn from a complicated legacy of 300 years of conflict, cooperation, and cultural exchange between a variety of empires—European and non-European alike.

entranceFees.description: There are no user or entry fees for El Camino Real. Fees may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please contact individual trail sites before visiting for more information.
entranceFees.title: Entrance fees vary site by site

parks.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail over the 404-mile U.S. historic route (thousands of additional miles in Mexico) that crosses two states.

operatingHours.description: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Beyond the United States, the trail reaches Mexico City, Mexico. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail

images.title: Kuaua Ruin in Coronado Historic Site, Bernalillo, New Mexico
images.altText: tan-colored pueblo Indian ruins with blue sky and three people
images.caption: The Tiwa pueblo of Kuaua lies in ruin at Coronado Historic Site. The site includes a rebuilt kiva that displays reproductions of original murals adorning its walls. Be sure to go to the visitor center where some of the original murals are displayed.

images.title: El Rancho de las Golondrinas, La Cienega, New Mexico
images.altText: adobe buildings including two beehive-looking ovens with people in a courtyard
images.caption: El Rancho de las Golondrinas was a historic paraje (stopping place) along El Camino Real. “The ranch of the swallows” dates from the early 1700s, and is now being used as a living history museum.

images.title: Jornada del Muerto, County Roads A013 & E070, Sierra & Doña Ana Counties, New Mexico
images.altText: shrubby desert scene with people walking under a cloud-filled sky
images.caption: Walk in the footsteps of settlers from the 1600s who had to walk along this dreaded yet unavoidable section of El Camino Real: Jornada del Muerto or Dead Man’s Journey.

images.title: Fort Selden Historic Site, Radium Springs, New Mexico
images.altText: fort ruins in the sunlight with cottonwood trees on the left
images.caption: Fort Selden was built near the town of Las Cruces in 1865 and housed troops for 25 years. The visitor center offers exhibits on frontier military life during the fort’s heyday and the grounds are self-guided.

images.title: Presidio Chapel of San Elizario, Mission Trail, El Paso, Texas
images.altText: large white chapel under blue sky
images.caption: Spanish troops built a presidio (fort) and chapel at this site during the 1780s to protect settlements in the lower Río Grande Valley downstream from El Paso, Texas.

parks.weatherInfo: Due to the length of El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
parks.name: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro

parks.fullName: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
parks.description: Explore a diverse array of histories contained within El Camino Real de los Tejas’ 150-year life, including the Spanish struggle to missionize American Indian nations, the growth of cattle ranching in the Mexican period, and the movement for Texan independence and statehood.

entranceFees.description: There are no user or entry fees for El Camino Real. Fees may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please contact individual trail sites before visiting for more information.
entranceFees.title: Entrance fees vary site by site

parks.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail over the 2,580-mile historic route that crosses 2 states, and travels into Mexico, to Mexico City.

operatingHours.description: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail

images.title: Mission San Bernardo ruins, Guerrero, Coahuila, Mexico
images.altText: Mexican mission stands in the dirt
images.caption: Construction of the mission church began in 1760 but was never completed. The outstanding ruins are virtually the only visible remains of the complex of missions established in the area. The purpose was to convert Coahuiltecan Indians to Catholicism.

images.title: El Paso de Jacinto/Paso de los Indios, Webb County, Texas
images.altText: lots of greenery along a river; sunflowers in the foreground
images.caption: Around 1746, explorer Jacinto de León discovered a ford that allowed safe passage across the Río Grande in this vicinity; it had probably been used for centuries by American Indians.

images.title: Rancho los Ojuelos, Webb County, Texas
images.altText: stone house ruins; briliant green grasses and trees on the right
images.caption: This national historic district consists of 13 stone houses (several in ruins) constructed from hewn sandstone blocks, chinked and plastered, ranging from rectangular flat roofed Colonial style buildings to hip roofed two room structures. Post-1750s.

images.title: McKinney Falls State Park, Travis County, Texas
images.altText: rock indentations in a dry creek with five people walking under clouds
images.caption: Recent research reveals that in 1716 the expedition of Domingo Ramón followed the left bank of Onion Creek along the western edge of McKinney Falls State Park to its junction with Williamson Creek. You can walk in rock indentations in the creek bed.

images.title: Mission Tejas State Park, Houston County, Texas
images.altText: trail segment indentation with leaves in it, trees along the side
images.caption: This 1.5-mile-long trail segment crosses an area that has remarkable visual integrity. The trail segment courses parallel to State Road 21 and at times crosses the highway.

parks.weatherInfo: Due to the length of El Camino de los Tejas National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
parks.name: El Camino Real de los Tejas

parks.description: The richly diverse volcanic landscape of El Malpais (el-mal-pie-EES) offers solitude, recreation, and adventure. Explore diverse geologic features such as lava flows, cinder cones, lava tube caves, and sandstone bluffs. While some may see a desolate environment, people have been adapting to and living in this extraordinary terrain for generations. Come discover the land of fire and ice!

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter El Malpais National Monument.
entranceFees.title: El Malpais National Monument Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: No roads exist through El Malpais National Monument. To explore the east side of the park, take exit 89 off I-40 and head south on Highway 117. To explore the north side of the park, take exit 81 off I-40 and head south on Highway 53. To reach the visitor center, take exit 85 off I-40 in Grants, New Mexico. After you exit, head south on Santa Fe Ave and continue straight over the freeway overpass. Take a left at the entrance sign for El Malpais Visitor Center and continue 300 yards to the parking lot.

operatingHours.description: El Malpais National Monument is open 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: El Malpais National Monument

images.title: Sandstone Bluffs Overlook
images.altText: Summer at Sandstone Bluffs Overlook
images.caption: A vast expanse of lava fields as seen from Sandstone Bluffs Overlook

images.title: Snowy Landscape
images.altText: Snow on the El Calderon Trail
images.caption: Winter exploration allows one to discover the quiet beauty of El Malpais

images.title: View from El Calderon
images.altText: Summer view from El Calderon cinder cone
images.caption: A hike to the top of El Calderon cinder cone offers one a view of the entire monument.

images.title: Wildflowers on the El Calderon Trail
images.altText: Hiking in Summer
images.caption: Enjoy a stroll along the El Calderon Trail to view beautiful wildflowers in summer.

images.title: Lava Tube Cave
images.altText: Lava Tube caving at El Malpais
images.caption: Explore lava tube caving at El Malpais National Monument

parks.weatherInfo: As a general rule, daily temperatures swing roughly 30 (F) from night lows to afternoon highs. Summer is sunny and hot with monsoon rain storms and an average high of 80 (F). Winter is cool, sunny, with potential snow storms and an average high of 45 (F). Spring and fall are generally dry with the occasional storm rain and/or snow storm. For more information on weather and current weather conditions visit https://www.nps.gov/elma/planyourvisit/weather.htm
parks.name: El Malpais

parks.description: Imagine the refreshment of finding water after days of dusty travel. A reliable waterhole hidden at the base of a sandstone bluff made El Morro (the headland) a popular campsite for hundreds of years. Here, Ancestral Puebloans, Spanish and American travelers carved over 2,000 signatures, dates, messages, and petroglyphs. Make El Morro National Monument a stopping point on your travels.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter El Morro National Monument.
entranceFees.title: El Morro National Monument Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: From Albuquerque, NM, or from the east: take Interstate 40 west to Grants. At exit 81, go south on Highway 53 for 42 miles to El Morro National Monument. From Flagstaff, AZ, or from the west: take Interstate 40 east to Gallup. At exit 20, go south on Highway 602 for about 31 miles. Turn east (left) onto Highway 53. El Morro is 25 more miles.

operatingHours.description:
Open all year, except Thanksgiving Day, December 25, and January 1. 
Trail access begins at 9:00 am and ends at 4:00 pm. Consistent with CDC guidance regarding areas of substantial or high transmission, visitors to El Morro National Monument, regardless of vaccination status, are required to wear a mask inside all park buildings.
operatingHours.name: El Morro National Monument

images.title: Ranger Recreates Historic Photograph
images.altText: A ranger recreates a historic El Morro Photograph
images.caption: Ranger Andrew recreates a historic photograph with Petroglyphs at El Morro.

images.title: El Morro in snow
images.altText: Headland in Snow
images.caption: El Morro blanketed with snow

images.title: El Morro with Sunflowers
images.altText: El Morro with Sunflowers
images.caption: El Morro with Sunflowers

images.title: Pool at El Morro
images.altText: Pool at El Morro
images.caption: A drinking hole for visitors for hundreds of years, the pool at El Morro has significant cultural and historical value.

images.title: Trail at El Morro
images.altText: Trail at El Morro
images.caption: Constructed by the CCC, the historic headland trail at El Morro offers visitors great views and the archaeological site of Atsinna.

images.title: Atsinna Pueblo
images.altText: Atsinna Pueblo
images.caption: Atsinna Pueblo sits atop the headland at El Morro

images.title: Then and Now at the Pool
images.altText: Ranger recreates a historic photo
images.caption: A ranger recreates a historic photograph at El Morro near The Pool.

parks.weatherInfo: At an elevation of 7,219 feet (2200 meters) winters can be cold and snowy. Summers are warm with afternoon thunder showers from mid-July through mid-September. Trails can close unexpectedly due to severe weather. Average snowfall: 40 inches per year. Average precipitation (snowmelt and rain): 16 inches per year. Warmest month: July, with average highs of 84 degrees and lows of 52 degrees. Coldest months: December and January, with average lows of 14-15 degrees, and average highs of 44-45 degrees.
parks.name: El Morro

parks.description: Visit the home of Eleanor Roosevelt. Here, Franklin and Eleanor entertained friends, state visitors, the press, and their associates in the tranquil and relaxed atmosphere of Val-Kill. Explore the Roosevelt saga in the homes of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt, the exhibits at the nation’s first Presidential Library, and over a thousand acres of gardens and trails.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees for guided tours of Val-Kill Cottage.
entranceFees.title: Tour of Val-Kill Cottage

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for visiting the park.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site is located on Route 9G in the Town of Hyde Park, NY.

operatingHours.description:
June 7, 2021
All buildings at Val-Kill remain closed.
Contact Station available for information, brochures, and NPS Passport Stamps.
Restrooms are available every day from 9:00 AM to 4:00 PM.
Park grounds including the parking lot and trails are available from 8:00 am to 7:00 pm.
operatingHours.name: Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site

images.title: Eleanor Roosevelt's Val-Kill
images.altText: A view of the buildings at Val-Kill
images.caption: Looking across the water at the Stone Cottage and Val-Kill Cottage

images.title: Stone Cottage at Val-Kill
images.altText: Stone Cottage at Val-Kill
images.caption: Val-Kill is a special place that serves as a window into Eleanor Roosevelt's private and public life.

images.title: Val-Kill Cottage
images.altText: Val-Kill Cottage
images.caption: Val-Kill became the nucleus of Franklin and Eleanor's overlapping network of friends and political associates. After FDR's death in 1945, Val-Kill became Mrs. Roosevelt's permanent home.

images.title: View of Val-Kill Cottage from the garden
images.altText: View of Val-Kill cottage from the garden
images.caption: Mrs. Roosevelt's favorite room was the sleeping porch on the second floor overlooking the garden.

images.title: Bridge at Val-Kill
images.altText: Bridge at Val-Kill
images.caption: Mrs. Roosevelt would hear her guests approach as they drove over the bridge.

parks.weatherInfo: Spring: Temperatures usually range from 40°F to 70°F. Rain is not uncommon. Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70° F to 100° F. Humidity can be high throughout the summer months with periods of rain. Fall: Temperatures usually range from 40° F to 70° F. Peak leaf season is mid-October. Rain is not uncommon. Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30° F to 50°F. Ice, Freezing Rain and Snow are not uncommon.
parks.name: Eleanor Roosevelt

parks.fullName: Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
parks.description: How far would you travel to find a better life? What if the journey took weeks under difficult conditions? If you answered "Whatever it takes," you echo the feelings of the 12 million immigrants who passed through these now quiet halls from 1892 to 1954. Ellis Island afforded them the opportunity to attain the American dream for themselves and their descendants. Come hear their stories.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee. All visitors must purchase ferry tickets through Statue Cruises (1-877-LADYTIX (877-523-9849) or at statuecruises.com). Please note that the Hard Hat Tour requires advanced reservations also through Statue Cruises. Please visit our 'Plan Your Visit' page for additional information.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Ellis Island is located in New York Harbor, and can only be reached by boat. Ferries are operated by Statue Cruises, and depart from Battery Park in Lower Manhattan in New York City. Ferries are also available from Liberty State Park in Jersey City, New Jersey.

operatingHours.description: Access to Liberty and Ellis Islands is by Statue Cruises ferry only. For ferry departure times and ticketing information visit statuecruises.com or call 1-877-LADY-TIX. The last entrance to the pedestal is at 4:30 PM. The Statue of Liberty's crown remains closed.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

addresses.line1: Ellis Island National Museum of Immigration

images.title: Ellis Island Museum of Immigration
images.altText: Beaux-Arts brick and limestone building with large arched windows and cupola-topped towers.
images.caption: Over 12 million immigrants were processed at Ellis Island during the peak years of 1892-1924, most through this building which opened in 1900.

images.title: Ellis Island's Registry Room
images.altText: Great Hall has terra cotta-colored tile floor, a balcony, large arched windows, and vaulted ceiling
images.caption: The Registry Room, also known as the Great Hall, is where millions of immigrants were inspected. They were required to pass both a medical and legal inspection before being allowed to enter the United States.

images.title: Ellis Island Museum of Immigration
images.altText: Brick and limestone building with maroon canopy leading to entrance.
images.caption: Visitors to the museum today arrive by ferry, just like immigrants did a century ago.

images.title: Replica Inspection Desk in the Registry Room
images.altText: Honey oak colored tall desk on tiled floor in Great Hall with arched windows and vaulted ceiling.
images.caption: Inspectors at Ellis Island would conduct the legal examination from behind desks like these a century ago.

images.title: Bird's Eye View of Ellis Island
images.altText: Artificially-expanded largely rectangular island with straight seawalls and large buildings.
images.caption: Ellis Island was expanded from just a couple acres to over 30 to make room for a large immigration processing station, that included a state of the art hospital complex.

parks.weatherInfo: It is typically colder and more windy in New York Harbor than in elsewhere in the New York City metropolitan area. Winters are cold and damp. Spring and Fall can range from chilly to warm. Summers are warm to hot and humid.
parks.name: Ellis Island
parks.designation: Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument

parks.description: America's only Nobel Prize winning playwright, Eugene O'Neill, chose to live in Northern California at the height of his writing career. Isolated from the world and within the walls of his home, O'Neill wrote his final and most memorable plays; The Iceman Cometh, Long Day's Journey Into Night, and A Moon for the Misbegotten.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for this site. Entrance is by reservation only.
entranceFees.title: Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site

entrancePasses.description: Passes are not required or sold at this site. Entrance is by reservations only.
entrancePasses.title: Eugne O'Neill National Historic Site

parks.directionsInfo: Reservations are required to visit the site. We offer a free shuttle that will pick up visitors in downtown Danville, CA. The shuttle meets at 205 Railroad Avenue outside the Museum of the San Ramon Valley. Parking is available next to the museum. Reservations can be made by calling (925)228-8860 x6422 or send your reservation request by e-mail.

operatingHours.description: Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site must be accessed through a private, gated road owned by a community of neighboring residents. In order to experience Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site, visitors need to make reservations and will be driven by a park shuttle from the Town of Danville, California. You'll receive a tour of Eugene O'Neill's "Tao House" and have time to explore the grounds before returning to Danville on the shuttle.
operatingHours.name: Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site

images.title: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California
images.altText: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California
images.caption: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California

images.title: Old Barn
images.altText: An old barn and an historic wheeled wagon sit in front of a tree-lined hill.
images.caption: The "Old Barn", a part of the Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site

images.title: Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site
images.altText: A tree is seen sitting against a small mountain background. A fence runs along the right side.
images.caption: Mountain background as seen from the park.

images.title: Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site
images.altText: A sign with the park name is sitting in a field of trees.
images.caption: The Eugene O'Neill NHS park sign.

images.title: Eugene O'Neill
images.altText: Eugene O'Neill, and older man, poses outside against a hilly background.
images.caption: Historic image of Eugene O'Neill at the Tao House property.

parks.weatherInfo: The Mediterranean climate of Danville features hot, dry summers with lower temperatures near 60º F and upper temperatures near 100º F. The heat gives way to cool, rainy winters with lows near 45º F and highs near 75º F. Fall and spring can bring rain and temperatures from 55-80º F.
parks.name: Eugene O'Neill

parks.description: Everglades National Park protects an unparalleled landscape that provides important habitat for numerous rare and endangered species like the manatee, American crocodile, and the elusive Florida panther. An international treasure as well - a World Heritage Site, International Biosphere Reserve, a Wetland of International Importance, and a specially protected area under the Cartagena Treaty.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee to the Everglades National Park is good for 7 consecutive days starting from the day of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Everglades National Park Entrance Fee- Per vehicle

entranceFees.description: The Everglades National Park charges an entry fee per person when an individual enters the main entrance station through a bike or by walking. The entrance fee is good for 7 consecutive days starting from the day of purchase. Individuals 16 years old and younger, are admitted free of charge.
entranceFees.title: Everglades National Park Entrance Fee- Per Person/Cyclist/Paddlecraft

entranceFees.description: The Everglades National Park entrance fee for motorcycles is good for 7 consecutive days starting from the day of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Everglades National Park Entrance Fee- Per Motorcycle

Entrance fees to the Everglades National Park are charged based on the seating capacity of the vehicle.

entrancePasses.description: The Annual Pass for the Everglades National Park is valid for 12 months starting from the day of purchase and is good for unlimited visits to the park during this period. These passes can be purchased at the Homestead and Shark Valley entrance stations or the Gulf Coast and Flamingo Visitor Centers. You can also purchase the senior park pass or pass for entry into all national parks at these locations.
entrancePasses.title: Everglades National Park Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Directions to Ernest Coe Visitor Center 40001 State Road 9336, Homestead, FL 33034 Visitors coming from the Miami area and points north should take the Florida Turnpike (Route 821) south until it ends merging with U.S. 1 at Florida City. Turn right at the first traffic light onto Palm Drive (State Road 9336/SW 344th St.) and follow the signs to the park. Visitors driving north from the Florida Keys should turn left on Palm Drive in Florida City and follow the signs to the park.

operatingHours.description: Everglades National Park is open 7 days a week, 24 hours a day. Park entrance is always open but staffed from 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.
operatingHours.name: Everglades National Park

images.title: Cypress Tree Sunrise
images.altText: A sunset creates a silhouette of a cypress tree with needle-like leaves that is shaped like an 'N'.
images.caption: Cypress Tree Sunrise (2020 Photo Contest)

images.title: Nine Mile Pond
images.altText: Two canoes at Nine Mile Pond during sunset.
images.caption: A meeting ground of marsh and mangrove environments. You may see alligators, wading birds, turtles, and fish.

images.title: American Alligator

images.caption: Biking is a great way to experience the quiet beauty of the Everglades.

images.caption: An aerial view of the landscape transition from Sawgrass to Florida Bay.

images.title: Camping at Long Pine Key
images.altText: Three tents are put up along the Long Pine Key campsite.
images.caption: Long Pine Key Campground is open seasonally from November through May. It is located seven miles (11 km) from the main entrance, just off the main road.

parks.weatherInfo: The climate in Florida is known to be mild and sunny.The average annual temperatures for South Florida and the Keys range from 74° to 77°F (23° to 25°C). There are two seasons at the Everglades National Park: the wet season and the dry season. The wet season runs from Mid-May to November and the dry season runs from December to mid-May.
parks.name: Everglades

parks.description: Here on Wall Street, George Washington took the oath of office as our first President, and this site was home to the first Congress, Supreme Court, and Executive Branch offices. The current structure, a Customs House, later served as part of the US Sub-Treasury. Now, the building serves as a museum and memorial to our first President and the beginnings of the United States of America.

entranceFees.description: Admission to this park site is free of charge.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: There are no park-specific passes required or sold at this location.
entrancePasses.title: Park Specific Passes

parks.directionsInfo: The main entrance of Federal Hall is located at 26 Wall Street, near the corner of Wall Street and Nassau Street in Manhattan's Financial District. The rear entrance, which is wheelchair accessible, is located at 15 Pine Street, near the intersection of Pine Street and Nassau Street. It is highly recommended that all visitors use mass transit when traveling to Federal Hall.

operatingHours.description:
Federal Hall is open year-round.
Our hours of operation during are: Monday through Friday from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m, closed on Saturday and Sunday.
This site is also closed on the following federal holidays: Thanksgiving, Christmas Day and New Year's Day. 
The site may also close due to inclement weather. Please check for alert notifications on this website.
operatingHours.name: Hours of Operation

images.title: Federal Hall Interior
images.altText: “Large crowd inside the rotunda of Federal Hall National Memorial”
images.caption: Thousands of visitors each year visit Federal Hall National Memorial

parks.weatherInfo: http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?CityName=New+York&state=NY&site=OKX&lat=40.7198&lon=-73.993#.Vqj8OvkrJlZ
parks.name: Federal Hall

parks.description: Immerse yourself in an enchanting collage of coastal life and history. Rhythmic waves, high dunes, ancient maritime forests, historic landmarks and glimpses of wildlife, Fire Island has been a special place for diverse plants, animals and people for centuries. Far from the pressure of nearby big-city life, dynamic barrier island beaches offer solitude, camaraderie, and spiritual renewal.

entranceFees.description: There are no entrance fees for Fire Island National Seashore but plan to pay parking and/or transportation fees for most sites.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Fire Island National Seashore Headquarters are located in Patchogue, New York, on Long Island. Fire Island National Seashore Headquarters: Via Long Island Expressway/I-495: Take Exit 61 (Patchogue-Holbrook Road) to Waverly Ave. Head south on Waverly Ave to West Ave. Turn right onto Laurel Street. Via NY-27: Take Exit 52 onto Waverly Ave. Head south on Waverly Ave to West Ave. Turn right onto Laurel Street.

operatingHours.description:
Fire Island National Seashore encompasses five National Park Service sites on Fire Island, and headquarters and the William Floyd Estate on Long Island. Headquarters, the Fire Island Lighthouse, and Wilderness Visitor Center are open year-round. The William Floyd Estate on Long Island, and Watch Hill and Sailors Haven on Fire Island are open seasonally. 

Please be sure to check the hours of operations and the exceptions tab for each site you plan to visit.
operatingHours.name: Fire Island National Seashore

images.title: View of Fire Island Lighthouse from Great South Bay
images.altText: The Fire Island Lighthouse against a vibrant sunset.
images.caption: People from around the world come to visit the Fire Island Lighthouse.

images.title: Salt marsh trail at Watch Hill
images.altText: A boardwalk trail through lush green salt marsh glistens in sunset light.
images.caption: A boardwalk trail welcomes visitors to a salt marsh at Watch Hill.

images.title: The Wilderness Visitor Center in winter
images.altText: A brown hexagonal building covered in snow stands behind a beachside dune.
images.caption: The Wilderness Visitor Center welcomes visitors to the Otis Pike High Dune Wilderness on the east end of Fire Island.

images.title: Old Mastic House at William Floyd Estate
images.altText: A view from a meadow of the historic Old Mastic House
images.caption: A view of the Old Mastic House from the grounds of the William Floyd Estate

images.title: Fire Island Wilderness
images.altText: Grasses and shrubs cover the undulating backdune habitat of Fire Island's wilderness.
images.caption: Unparalleled opportunities for solitude and recreation can be found in New York State's only federally designated wilderness, the Otis Pike Fire Island High Dune Wilderness.

images.title: View of primary dune from Sunken Forest overlook
images.altText: View of ocean and primary dune with boardwalk winding up to the Sunken Forest overlook.
images.caption: Get one of the best boardwalk views on a walk through the Sunken Forest - a more than 350 year-old, globally rare ecosystem.

parks.weatherInfo: Spring: Temperatures may range from high 30s to low 50s (F). Rain and sun are equally common. Summer: Temperatures usually range from 65 F to 90 F. Fall: Temperatures from 70 F in early autumn to 40 F later in the season may be expected. Winter: Temperatures in the 30s (F) are common, with below freezing temperatures possible.
parks.name: Fire Island

parks.description: First Ladies National Historic Site consists of two properties in downtown Canton, Ohio - the home of First Lady Ida Saxton-McKinley and a small visitor center with an exhibit and film. Come learn about how the position of First Lady has evolved over time to include a public role.

entranceFees.description: Fee is only charged for Saxton House tours.
entranceFees.title: General Adult

entranceFees.description: Fee is only charged for Saxton House tours.
entranceFees.title: Senior

entranceFees.description: 17 years old and under. Fee is only charged for Saxton House tours.
entranceFees.title: Child

parks.directionsInfo: The First Ladies National Historic Site is located in downtown Canton, Ohio. Free parking is available behind the Saxton House or at our gated lot on the corner of Market Avenue South and 3rd Street SW. Please begin your visit at the education center at 205 Market Avenue South.

operatingHours.description: From May 1- October 31 First Ladies National Historic Site's Education & Research Center will be open Tuesday-Saturday (closed Sunday and Mondays). We offer guided tours of the Saxton House at 10:00am, 12:00pm, and 2:00pm. Tours have a capacity of twelve people per tour. Tours begin at the Education Center. Reservations are not available at this time. Face coverings are required to tour the home.
operatingHours.name: Summer Hours: May 1- October 31

images.title: First Ladies National Historic Site
images.altText: a front view of the Ida Saxton McKinley House
images.caption: This was the longtime residence of William and Ida McKinley.

images.title: Saxton McKinley House Piano
images.altText: A piano in the Saxton McKinley Home
images.caption: Ida Saxton's original piano is just one of many items belonging to President McKinley and First Lady Ida McKinley.

images.title: Saxton McKinley Home
images.altText: Close up view of home entrance.
images.caption: The Saxton McKinley Home is significant as the only residence with direct historical ties to President William McKinley remaining in his hometown of Canton.

images.title: The education center features rotating exhibits.
images.altText: Historic gowns in the education center.
images.caption: Learn about the role of the first lady at our education center.

images.title: Front Door of the Education Center
images.altText: The front of the education center.
images.caption: The education center is is the historic City National Bank building.

parks.weatherInfo: The weather at First Ladies National Historic Site is typical of Northeastern Ohio: four distinct seasons. Spring's rain and warming temperatures bring new leaves on trees and blooming wildflowers. Summer temperatures range from 49 to 95 degrees F and can be humid. Fall temperatures can range from low 70s during the day to freezing during the night. Fallcolor peaks mid-October. Winter weather conditions can rapidly change. Temperatures vary from mid-30s to below zero.
parks.name: First Ladies

parks.description: Famous as the First State to ratify the Constitution, Delaware was born out of a conflict among three world powers for dominance of the Delaware Valley. From this beginning, the region developed a distinct character that tolerated diversity in religion and national origin and valued independence.

emailAddresses.description: We appreciate your patience as we are receiving an increase in inquiries and will respond as quickly as we can.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to visit First State National Historical Park. Some partner sites may charge a small fee for special programs.
entranceFees.title: First State Fees

entrancePasses.description: First State National Historical Park does not sell or accept park passes, because we are a fee-free park.
entrancePasses.title: First State Passes

parks.directionsInfo: First State National Historical Park is made up of six individual sites throughout Delaware and southeastern Pennsylvania that explore early settlement through the ratification of the US Constitution. Please visit the individual pages for directions or hours of operation.

operatingHours.description: The Brandywine Valley is open sunrise to sunset and is free to access.
operatingHours.name: Brandywine Valley

operatingHours.description: This site is free to visit and no reservations are required.
operatingHours.name: Fort Christina

operatingHours.description:
Old Swedes Historic Site is open on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays 11:00am to 3:00pm. 

Tours are available by reservation. Old Swedes Historic Site is a partner organization to the National Park Service and does not receive NPS funds. As such, they cannot honor National Parks Annual Passes. You can book your tour by visiting their website. 

Tours: $8 per individual, $15 for two individuals, $3 per student (ages 6-15), free for children 5 and under.
operatingHours.name: Old Swedes Historic Site

exceptions.name: Closed Martin Luther King Jr. Day

operatingHours.description:
Tours are 45 minutes in length in order to allow for proper cleaning between tour groups. Admission is free and open to the public but a reservation is required. Tours for the New Castle Court House Museum are: Wednesdays through Saturdays at 10:00 a.m., 11:15 a.m., 1:15 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. Sundays at 1:00 p.m., 2:15 p.m. and 3:30 p.m.

The museum is closed on state holidays.
operatingHours.name: New Castle Court House Museum

operatingHours.description:
Tours are 45 minutes in length in order to allow for proper cleaning between tour groups. Admission is free and open to the public but a reservation is required everyday except Tuesday, and Wednesday. Tours for the John Dickinson Plantation are:Thursdays through Saturdays at 10:00 a.m., 11:15 a.m., 1:15 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. 

The site is closed on state holidays.
operatingHours.name: John Dickinson Plantation

operatingHours.description:
The Dover Green is open sunrise to sunset. 

The First State Heritage Park offers tours of The Dover Green and is open 9:00am to 4:30pm, Monday through Friday. 

The Old State House has the cancellation stamps for this site and has tours available by reservation on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 10:00am, 11:15am, 1:15pm and 2:30pm on Sunday at 1pm, 2:15pm and 3:30pm. You can make a reservation by calling: 302-744-5054
operatingHours.name: The Dover Green

images.title: Brandywine Valley
images.altText: Rolling agricultural hills on a bright sunny day.
images.caption: The Brandywine Valley unit is most known for its recreational opportunities.

images.title: John Dickinson Plantation
images.altText: A view of the front of the John Dickinson House on the Plantation.
images.caption: John Dickinson is most famously known as the "Penman of the Revolution" at this site, visitors learn the stories of the many residents: tenant farmers, indentured servants, free and enslaved Black men, women, and children and the Dickinson family.

images.title: Fort Christina

images.caption: This site commernmates the Swedes original landing and the fort that once stood in the area.

images.caption: Old Swedes Historic Site contains burials that can be traced back to the original settlement of the Swedes.

images.title: New Castle Court House
images.altText: Pews line the side of the room leading to the English style court room.
images.caption: The New Castle Court House Museum was the first court of Delaware and has seen a variety of significant moments in history.

images.title: The Dover Green
images.altText: Red, yellow, and green leaves lay on the grass in front of a colonial building.
images.caption: Each fall, an 18th Century Market Fair is recreated to commemorate the original purpose of The Green.

parks.name: First State

parks.description: On Tuesday morning, September 11, 2001, the U.S. came under attack when four commercial airliners were hijacked and used to strike targets on the ground. Nearly 3,000 people tragically lost their lives. Because of the actions of the 40 passengers and crew aboard one of the planes, Flight 93, the attack on the U.S. Capitol was thwarted.

entranceFees.description: No entrance fee
entranceFees.title: No entrance fee

parks.directionsInfo: The entrance to the memorial is located on US Route 30/Lincoln Highway. Traveling east on the PA Turnpike take exit 110 - Somerset and follow the signs. Traveling west on the PA Turnpike take exit 146 - Bedford. GPS Address: 6424 Lincoln Highway, Stoystown, PA 15563. Please note mapping programs may note alternate entrances, but the only entrance to the memorial is located on US Route 30. For more details follow the link to our website

operatingHours.description: Park grounds and trails are open 7 days a week, 365 days a year, from sunrise to sunset. Harsh winter weather may result in delayed openings and closures. Occasionally, the gates may be closed, prohibiting entrance to the grounds, when adverse weather occurs or is predicted, to allow road crews to work safely to clear all roads within the national memorial. Call 814-893-6585 for weather-related updates.
operatingHours.name: Memorial Grounds

parks.weatherInfo: Fall-Winter Cooler weather starts in September with warm days and cool nights. The first snowfall of the season occurs by mid-October and extends through late March to mid-April. Daytime temperatures range in the mid-20s to 30s, with periodic warming in the 40s and 50s. The average annual snowfall is approximately 80 inches for Somerset County. Spring-Summer May is more predictable for warmer weather with daytime temperatures in the 60s and 70s. July and August are also mild with highs in the 80s-90s
parks.name: Flight 93

parks.description: Beneath a grassy mountain valley in central Colorado lies one of the richest and most diverse fossil deposits in the world. Petrified redwood stumps up to 14 feet wide and thousands of detailed fossils of insects and plants reveal the story of a very different, prehistoric Colorado.

entrancePasses.title: Florissant Fossil Beds Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Visitors traveling north/south on I-25: Exit at US 24 West, travel 35 miles to town of Florissant, then follow signs two miles south on Teller County Road 1 to the Visitor Center. Visitors traveling from town of Cripple Creek: Follow Teller County Road 1 north for 16 miles.

parks.description: April 14, 1865. President Lincoln is assassinated at Ford’s Theatre. Discover how a nation handled grief and loss, how everyday people experienced a national tragedy, and how we have remembered a fallen leader. Today, in partnership with Ford’s Theatre Society, live dramatic productions highlight Lincoln’s love of the theatre, and the power of stories to connect us to ourselves and our history.

entranceFees.description: No entrance fee to enter site, though free tickets ARE required.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: Tickets for timed entry to visit Ford's Theatre are required and may be reserved online at Ford's Theatre Society Calendar. $3 reservation fee per ticket.
entrancePasses.title: Advanced Ticket Reservation

parks.directionsInfo: Ford's Theatre National Historic Site is located on 10th Street between E and F streets. The site is within walking distance of the Metro stops at Metro Center and Gallery Place. Parking garages and metered street parking are located nearby.

operatingHours.description: Ford's Theatre and the Ford's Theatre Museum is reopening with a modified schedule on October 14, 2020. The site will be open Wednesdays-Sundays, with site entry times at 10 and 11 a.m., 12 noon, and 2, 3, and 4 p.m. Advance reservations are required, and will be available online at www.fords.org each week on Friday for the following Wednesday-Sunday. Visits are limited to 45 minutes total and include the Theatre and Museum. The Petersen House and the Aftermath exhibits remain closed at this time.
operatingHours.name: Theatre Hours

images.caption: Where a nations destiny was met.

images.caption: Where President Lincoln was shot

images.title: Peterson House

images.caption: Place where Lincoln died.

parks.weatherInfo: Washington DC gets to see all four seasons. Humidity will make the temps feel hotter in summer and colder in winter. Spring (March - May) Temp: Average high is 65.5 degrees with a low of 46.5 degrees Summer (June - August) Temp: Average high is 86 degrees with a low of 68.5 degrees Fall (September - November) Temp: Average high is 68 degrees with a low of 51.5 degrees Winter (December - February) Temp: Average high is 45 degrees with a low of 30 degrees (Source: www.usclimatedata.com)
parks.name: Ford's Theatre

parks.description: Fort Bowie witnessed almost 25 years of conflict between the Chiricahua Apache and the US Army, and remains a tangible connection to the turbulent era of the late 1800s. Explore the history of Fort Bowie and Apache Pass as you hike the 1.5 mile trail to the visitor center and old fort ruins. Today, this peaceful landscape stands in stark contrast to the violence that once gripped this land.

entranceFees.description: Fort Bowie National Historic Site is a fee free park. No entrance fee is required.
entranceFees.title: Fort Bowie Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: From Willcox, AZ / points west on I-10: drive 23 miles east of Willcox on Interstate 10 to the the town of Bowie. Exit at the first Bowie exit and drive through the town. Follow the signs for Fort Bowie National Historic Site and turn south on Apache Pass Road. Drive 13 miles to the Fort Bowie Trailhead (the last mile of the road is unpaved). Be prepared to walk the three miles round trip to the ruins and back to your car.

operatingHours.description: The park is open every day from sunrise to sunset. Visitor Center hours change with the seasons. Check our Operating Hours page for more information: http://www.nps.gov/fobo/planyourvisit/hours.htm
operatingHours.name: Park

images.caption: San Simon Valley can be seen just beyond the ruins of the cavalry barracks.

images.title: Mountain howitzer
images.altText: Close up of a canon barrel
images.caption: The mountain howitzer is a symbolic relic from the active days of Fort Bowie

images.title: Fort Bowie landscape and ruins

images.caption: Fort Bowie was once a bustling frontier military fort. Today, the ruins offer a place of reflection.

images.title: Fort Bowie Cemetery

images.caption: Fort Bowie cemetery is accessed via the Fort Bowie Trail, and in addition to many US troops buried here, some Apache/Indeh are buried here as well.

images.title: Heliograph demonstration
images.altText: A group gathers as a ranger displays the heliograph equipment
images.caption: The heliograph was an important communications tool in the late 1880s. Stationed on top of high desert peaks, sunlight was reflected off mirrors in coded patterns to send a message miles away.

parks.name: Fort Bowie

parks.description: Fort Davis is one of the best surviving examples of an Indian Wars' frontier military post in the Southwest. From 1854 to 1891, Fort Davis was strategically located to protect emigrants, mail coaches, and freight wagons on the Trans-Pecos portion of the San Antonio-El Paso Road and on the Chihuahua Trail.

entranceFees.description: Per Person Fee over 15 years of age. 7 Day pass
entranceFees.title: Option #1 Fort Davis Entrance Fee - Per Person

entranceFees.description: All visitors within a non-commercial vehicle included. Visitors under 16 years of age are always Free. Per person fee may be more affordable for two adults. 7 day pass.

entranceFees.description: This fee is for 2 adults on one motorcycle. Per person fee may be more affordable for one adult. 7 day pass.

entrancePasses.description: You can buy an annual pass to Fort Davis National Historic Site for $35.00. This pass will admit the pass owners and three other adults to the Fort for 12 months from the month of purchase.

parks.directionsInfo: We are approximately 2.5 hours south of Midland/Odessa starting on I-20 to HWY 17, 3.5 hours North West of Del Rio starting on HWY 90 to HWY 118, 4 hours east of El Paso starting on I-10 to HWY 118 and 7 hours west of San Antonio starting on I-10 to HWY 17.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer Temperatures average a High of 95 and low of 65. Winter Temperatures average a High of 60 and a low of 20. Wind is very common and heavy rainfall is very sporadic.

parks.description: Brigadier General Ulysses S. Grant was becoming quite famous as he wrote these words following the surrender of Confederate Fort Donelson on Sunday, February 16, 1862. The Union victory at Fort Donelson elated the North, and stunned the South. Within days of the surrender, Clarksville and Nashville would fall into Union hands. Grant and his troops had created a pathway to victory for the Union.

entranceFees.description: Fort Donelson does not charge for entrance or interpretive fees.
entranceFees.title: No fees

entrancePasses.description:
Passes are not needed at Fort Donelson National Battlefield, as we have no fees.

parks.directionsInfo: The main entrance is located at 120 Fort Donelson Park Road, in Dover Tennessee. It is advised to start a visitor experience here. Brochures and information are available at this location. Physical address for the park's Fort Heiman unit, in Calloway County, Kentucky: 682 Fort Heiman Road, New Concord, Kentucky. This site is not staffed daily, but exhibits and information are available for visitors.

parks.weatherInfo: Fort Donelson National Battlefield traditionally experiences mild to moderate winters and hot summers with an average high of 90 degrees in the summer and 40 in winter; average lows in the winter are 30 degrees but single digits are not unusual. Rainfall in the area averages 53 inches a year with an additional 6 inches of ice/snow and violent thunderstorms can take place at any time of year.
parks.name: Fort Donelson

parks.description: Welcome to Fort Dupont Park in Washington DC! At 376-acres, the wooded park was once home to earthen fort built to protect the capital during the Civil War. Today, visitors can see the fort's earthworks and escape to the great outdoors. Activities include picnics, nature walks, biking, gardening, environmental education, music, and ranger-led programs.

parks.description: Fort Foote was constructed in 1863 atop Rozier's Bluff to strengthen the ring of fortifications that encircled Washington, D.C. Two of the Guns that protected Washington are still there along with the remains of the fort's earthworks.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees associated with the park.
entranceFees.title: Fort Foote Park

parks.directionsInfo: From the Beltway (I495/I95), take Exit 3, Indian Head Highway south (MD210/Indian Head Highway) and drive for approximately 3.5 miles to Old Fort Road. Turn right for 1 mile to Fort Foote Road S, turn left. Follow the winding road through the residential area to entrance sight on the left for the fort. If driving north on MD210/Indian Head Highway turn left onto the 2nd Old Fort Road you come to (Old Fort Rd cross 210 twice). There will be a McDonald's on your left at the correct traffic light.

operatingHours.description: The park is open daily from 8:00 am to sunset. Note, at times the gate does not open until 9:00 am.  You may park on the street and walk into the park.
operatingHours.name: Fort Foote Park

parks.weatherInfo: Summers are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. Please carry water while participating in physical activity and be prepared to take shelter from lightning. Winters are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly.
parks.name: Fort Foote

parks.description: Georgia's fate was decided in 1742 when Spanish and British forces clashed on St. Simons Island. Fort Frederica's troops defeated the Spanish, ensuring Georgia's future as a British colony. Today, the archeological remnants of Frederica are protected by the National Park Service.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to enter Fort Frederica National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Directions from Torras Causeway: at end of causeway, get in left lane. Follow left lane to traffic light. Go straight at light. Follow Sea Island Road to Frederica Road. Turn left at traffic light onto Frederica Road. Follow Frederica to roundabout. Take second exit of roundabout (still on Frederica). Go approximately 1 mile. Turn left onto park entrance road. Across from Wesley United Methodist Church. For detailed directions, clink the link below.

operatingHours.description:
Park & Grounds Closed:

Thanksgiving
Christmas Day
New Year's Day
operatingHours.name: Fort Frederica National Monument Visitor Center & Grounds

operatingHours.description: Bloody Marsh is roughly where the site of the last battle of the Spanish invasion of Georgia took place on July 7th. Though casualties were relatively light, it would rob the Spanish of their enthusiasm and lead to their abandonment of their campaign. Located 7 miles south from the front gates of the town of Frederica, this relatively minor engagement ended the Spanish threat to the Georgia colonies.
operatingHours.name: Bloody Marsh Site

images.altText: Artifacts found at Frederica

images.title: Soldiers of the 42nd Regiment of Foote
images.altText: Reenactors performing as the original redcoats who served at Frederica
images.caption: Soldiers of the 42nd Regiment of Foote

images.title: 100 year old grapevine at Frederica
images.altText: A large grapevine draped among the Live Oaks
images.caption: 100 year old grapevine at Frederica which still produces "Summer Grapes"

images.title: Fort Frederica at Sunset
images.altText: The shadow of the ruin of Fort Frederica highlighted by a sunset along the Frederica River.
images.caption: Nature and History combine in a beautiful setting at Fort Frederica

images.title: Fort Frederica's Visitor Center during Azalea Season
