parks.weatherInfo: The site enjoys mild climate from fall through early summer, followed by hot, humid summers.
parks.name: Fort Frederica

parks.description: Originally established as a private fur trading fort in 1834, Fort Laramie evolved into the largest and best known military post on the Northern Plains before its abandonment in 1890. This “grand old post” witnessed the entire sweeping saga of America’s western expansion and Indian resistance to encroachment on their territories.

entranceFees.description: Effective January 1, 2015 admission to Fort Laramie National Historic Site is free!
entranceFees.title: Free Admission

parks.directionsInfo: The park is located in southeast Wyoming approximately 125 miles southeast of Casper, 100 miles north of Cheyenne and 55 miles west of Scottsbluff, Nebraska. From Interstate 25, take exit 92 to US Highway 26, proceed east to the town of Fort Laramie; turn right on State Route 160 and travel three miles to the park entrance. From westbound US 26, proceed west from Scottsbluff, Nebraska to the town of Fort Laramie; turn left on State Route 160 and continue three miles to the park entrance.

operatingHours.description: The park grounds are open from dawn until dusk every day of the year. Some historic buildings may be closed in winter. Post trader store and cavalry barracks are open daily - weather permitting.
operatingHours.name: Park grounds and historic buildings

images.title: Ruins of the 1873 Post Hospital
images.altText: Ruins of the 1873 Post Hospital at dawn.
images.caption: Sunrises and sunsets are extraordinarily beautiful when set against the many historic structures the site.

images.title: Parade Ground from the Porch of "Old Bedlam"
images.altText: View of the parade ground from the porch of "Old Bedlam".
images.caption: A fall view of the parade ground from "Old Bedlam" the oldest surviving structure at Fort Laramie and in the state of Wyoming, constructed in 1849.

images.title: Post Trader at Work
images.altText: Living history interpreter portraying the Post Trader.
images.caption: In the summer living history interpreters bring the post to life, including the Post Trader in the refurnished 1849 store.

images.title: Fur Trade Fort Laramie Event
images.altText: Living history interpreter explaining the life of a trapper/trader to young visitors
images.caption: Special attention is given to helping our young visitors understand the past at Fort Laramie National Historic Site.

images.title: Arial View of Fort Laramie NHS From the South
images.altText: Aerial view of Fort Laramie NHS from the South
images.caption: Overview of Fort Laramie as it exists today with many of the historic buildings fully restored and refurnished and numerous other ruins and foundations.

images.title: Tipis Across Laramie River in Fall
images.altText: Two tipis across the Laramie River from the fort in fall
images.caption: Tipis were a common scene at Fort Laramie from 1834-1872.  At times, during treaty negotiations dozens of tipis could be found here.

images.title: Fall colors on the Parade Ground
images.altText: Ash and cottonwood trees show their fall colors next to an open grass field.
images.caption: Fall colors paint the parade grounds near Old Bedlam.

images.title: Powder Magazine in Winter
images.altText: Ruins of a concrete structure with snow on top.
images.caption: Ruins of the powder magazine within the winter snows.

images.title: Morning Fog at the Old Holtclaw Tract
images.altText: A deer looking up in morning fog near the shelter belt at the old Holtclaw Tract homestead.
images.caption: Morning fog north of Fort Laramie

images.title: 11th Kansas Ride Past the Cavalry Barracks
images.altText: A group of mounted individuals ride hors near a concrete historic structure.
images.caption: Riding past the Cavalry Barracks

images.title: Three Affiliated Tribes Ride at Cavalry Barracks
images.altText: Native American people riding horses - some in traditional regalia - in front the Cavalry Barracks.
images.caption: Riding toward the parade ground

images.title: Independence Day Salute
images.altText: Rangers in living history clothing fire a salute with Springfield rifles for Independence Day.
images.caption: A salute to each state of the union in 1876.

parks.weatherInfo: Fort Laramie has mild weather for Wyoming. While summer days can be quite hot (over 100F/37C), average highs are in the 80s and 90s (30-35C) with cool nights and low humidity. Winters are often bitterly cold and windy with subzero wind chills. The region is semi-arid with a distinct winter dry season. About 70% of annual precipitation falls as thunderstorms during the spring and early summer. Breezy days are common year-round and peak in the winter when wind speeds can approach hurricane-strength.
parks.name: Fort Laramie

parks.description: Discover a complete and authentic army post from the 1860s -1870s! This well-preserved fort on the Santa Fe Trail shares a tumultuous history of the Indian Wars era. The sandstone constructed buildings sheltered troops who were known as the Guardians of the Santa Fe Trail.

emailAddresses.description: This e-mail address is monitored during park operating hours by a member of the ranger division. Most messages will be answered within 24 hours. Inquiries directed to facilities and maintenance staff may take additional time to receive a response, especially on weekends.

entranceFees.description: There is no charge for any of the park's activities.
entranceFees.title: Free Admission

parks.directionsInfo: Fort Larned National Historic Site is located on KS Hwy 156, six miles west of Larned, Kansas.

operatingHours.description: Staff begin closing the grounds and visitor center at 4:30 p.m. The parking lot gate is closed and locked for the night at 5 p.m.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds and Historic Buildings

images.title: Artillery Demonstration
images.altText: Men in 19th century U.S. Army uniforms fire a reproduction period cannon.
images.caption: Volunteers demonstrating the use of a mountain howitzer during one of Fort Larned's living history weekends.

images.title: Aerial Photo of Fort Larned
images.altText: Sandstone army buildings arranged in a square around parade ground.
images.caption: The historic sandstone buildings at Fort Larned date to 1868

images.title: Blacksmith Demonstrations at Fort Larned
images.altText: Man in leather apron hammering hot steel in blacksmith shop.
images.caption: The blacksmith demonstration is one of the most popular living history demonstrations.

images.title: Flag Retreat
images.altText: Men in 19th century U.S. Army uniforms lower an American flag.
images.caption: Volunteers help recreate the U.S. Army flag lowering ceremony known as Retreat.

images.title: Visitors in the Barracks
images.altText: Man in 19th century U.S. Army uniform interacts with visitors in period barracks.
images.caption: A volunteer shows visitors how soldiers lived during the 1860s at Fort Larned.

images.title: Visiting Santa
images.altText: Three young children having their picture taken with Santa Claus in a period room.
images.caption: Young visitors get their picture taken with Santa during the fort's Christmas Past event.

images.title: Buffalo Soldiers
images.altText: African American men in 19th century cavalry uniforms on horseback.
images.caption: Buffalo Soldier re-enactors help bring Fort Larned's history to life.

parks.weatherInfo: Central Kansas has a four-season climate. Winter tends to be cold and dry, with average daytime highs below 40F (4C). Foehn winds blowing across the Great Plains from the Southwest periodically raise temperatures above 80F (27C). Unsettled warmer air, higher winds, and severe weather arrive in the spring and often last through early July. Late summer days hover above 90F (32C) and readings over 100F (38C) are not uncommon. Fall is variable but generally milder with showers changing to snow and ice later.
parks.name: Fort Larned

parks.description: Fort Matanzas National Monument preserves the fortified coquina watchtower, completed in 1742, which defended the southern approach to the Spanish military settlement of St. Augustine. It also protects approximately 300 acres of Florida coastal environment containing dunes, marsh, maritime forest, and associated flora and fauna, including threatened and endangered species.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee for visiting any portion of Fort Matanzas.  However, the ferry service to the historic fort requires boarding passes.
entranceFees.title: Fort Matanzas Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: A free ferry service takes passengers to Fort Matanzas at half past every hour.  Each tour leaves the dock at half past every hour.  First at 9:30am and the Last at 3:30pm.  Boarding passes are issued from the Visitor Center on a first come basis.
entrancePasses.title: Ferry Passes

parks.directionsInfo: Fort Matanzas is 14 miles south of Saint Augustine on State Route A1A.

operatingHours.description:
The outdoor areas at the Fort Matanzas Visitor Center Area are open from 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Public restrooms, nature trails, fishing access, and basic visitor information and orientation services are available.

Ferry Service to Historic Fort Matanzas operates Wednesdays - Sundays 9:30 a.m. - 3:30 p.m. Reservations are required on a first come first served basis.  Passes are available at the Visitor Center.  The ferry services does not operate on Monday or Tuesday.

No oversized parking is available.
operatingHours.name: Operating Hours

images.title: Fort Matanzas
images.altText: Fort Matanzas, a fortified watch tower made form coquina.
images.caption: Fort Matanzas sits on Rattlesnake Island in the middle of the Matanzas River.

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: Two story building with stone base and wood second floor, oak trees, grass, two signs.
images.caption: Here you can find information about the fort tour, exhibits, park movie, passport stamp, and more.

images.title: Nature Trail
images.altText: A nature trail boardwalk with seating area.
images.caption: Follow an elevated boardwalk through some pristine Florida barrier island habitat.

images.title: Soldier's Quarters
images.altText: Wooden bunks and uniform items in the soldier's quarters.
images.caption: The few enlisted soldiers at Fort Matanzas shared a small, sparse room as living space.

images.title: Protecting the riverway
images.altText: The cannon of Fort Matanzas point toward the river's inlet.
images.caption: Fort Matanzas protected the southern river approach to Saint Augustine.

images.title: Recreational Opportunities
images.altText: People wading in the river and relaxing on the beach.
images.caption: More the half-a-million people visit Fort Matanzas each year to enjoy both the river and ocean beaches.

parks.weatherInfo: Summers are hot and humid with afternoon thundershowers. Sunscreen, a hat, UV protective sunglasses, and are recommended. Drink plenty of water. Winters are cool to mild with some cold spells, especially with wind from the north or off the water. Fall and spring are temperate with temperatures around 70F-80F (21C-26C). During danger of lightning, the fort will be closed and ferry service will be suspended. June-November is hurricane season so check for tropical storms before visiting.
parks.name: Fort Matanzas

parks.fullName: Fort McHenry National Monument and Historic Shrine
parks.description: by the dawn's early light, a large red, white and blue banner? Whose broad stripes and bright stars... were so gallantly streaming...over Fort McHenry! The valiant defense of the fort during the Battle of Baltimore on September 13-14, 1814 inspired Francis Scott Key to write the words that became the U.S. national anthem. The fort's history holds many other stories too, from the Civil War to WWII.

entranceFees.description:
The entrance fee to the Historic Zone (including the Star Fort) is $15.00 per adult 16 years of age and older. Children 15 and younger are free. Entrance passes can not currently be purchased at the park Visitor and Education Center. However, all passes can be purchased online at recreation.gov.

All 'America the Beautiful' Interagency Passes are accepted. All passes cover admission for the pass holder and three additional guests ages 16 and older. These passes can be purchased at recreation.gov as well.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

entrancePasses.description: The America the Beautiful Interagency Annual Pass may be purchased by anyone and is valid for one year following the month of purchase. The pass covers entrance fees for the pass holder and three adult guests.
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful: Interagency Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Senior Lifetime Pass is a lifetime pass for American citizens ages 62 and over. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. Senior Lifetime Passes do not expire.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Senior Lifetime Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Senior Annual Pass is an annual pass for U.S. seniors aged 62 or older. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. Senior Annual Passes are valid for one year from the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Senior Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Access Pass is a lifetime pass for any citizen or permanent resident of the U.S. who has been medically determined to have a permanent disability. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. Access Passes do not expire.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: The Interagency Military Pass is an annual pass for current U.S. military members and their dependents with a valid U.S. Department of Defense CAC card or DoD Form 1173 for proof of identification.The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. The pass is valid for one year from the month that it is issued.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Military Pass

entrancePasses.description:
The Interagency 4th Grade Annual Pass is for 4th graders including home-schooled and free-choice learners. The pass covers the admission of the pass holder and three adult guests. The pass is valid from September through August of the year that the student is in the 4th grade.

Students may obtain a pass with a printed voucher from the Every Kid in a Park website. A paper voucher must be presented in order to receive a pass.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency 4th Grade Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: The park is three miles southeast of the Baltimore Inner Harbor and just off I-95. Follow the brown Fort McHenry directional signs along all major routes to the park. From I-95 northbound, take Exit 55 Key Highway and follow Fort McHenry signs.

operatingHours.description:
Regular Hours: Park Grounds and Parking lot: 9:00am - 6:00pm

Star Fort and Visitor Center restrooms: 9:00am - 5:45pm

Visitor Center exhibits and gift shop remain closed. Limited indoor exhibits inside historic Star Fort.
Orientation film can be seen online- https://www.nps.gov/fomc/learn/photosmultimedia/index.htm
operatingHours.name: Fort McHenry National Monument and Historic Shrine

images.title: Fort McHenry National Monument and Historic Shrine
images.altText: Fort McHenry
images.caption: Blue Angels fly over Fort McHenry

parks.weatherInfo: Temperatures and weather in the spring and fall months tend to be mild. Ice, snow, and freezing temperatures can occur during winter. Extreme heat can occur during the summer months. Inclement weather may impact park hours of operation year round. Refer to the park alerts or call ahead to confirm operating hours.
parks.name: Fort McHenry

parks.description: Fort Monroe National Monument has a diverse history spanning the American story from American Indian presence, Captain John Smith's journeys, first arrival of enslaved Africans in English North America, a safe haven for freedom seekers during the American Civil War, and a bastion of defense for the Chesapeake Bay through the 21st Century. Visit and witness the on-going preservation work in action.

entranceFees.description: Day use visitation of the grounds and Casemate Museum.
entranceFees.title: Individual Fort Monroe Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: From I-64 East or West take Exit 268 (169 East Mallory St/Ft. Monroe) (Going East: Last Exit prior to Hampton Roads Bridge Tunnel, going West: first Exit after it.) Top of Exit Left at light onto S Mallory St (0.1 mile). Right at 2nd light onto E Mellen St. Continue crossing a small bridge (0.6 mile). Continue straight at light (Left fork) onto Ingalls Rd (0.5 mile). Left onto Ruckman Rd towards fort Main Gate, pass through fort walls Right onto Bernard Rd, angled parking on Left (0.2 mile).

operatingHours.description: Fort Monroe is managed and operated in partnership between the National Park Service, Fort Monroe Authority, and US Army offering daily public access as well as commercial and residential leasing. National Park Service lands are open as indicated here.
operatingHours.name: Fort Monroe

operatingHours.description: The beaches at Fort Monroe are open to the public all year from sunrise to sunset. Only the first two coves at Outlook Beach have Life guards. Please use caution when entering the water.
operatingHours.name: Beaches

images.title: Fort Monroe Aerial View
images.altText: Aerial View of Fort Monroe
images.caption: A unique perspective only available from the air brings the entire scope of Fort Monroe into focus in one image.

images.title: Fort Monroe with USS Kearsarge
images.altText: Fort Monroe in foreground with USS Kearsarge in background.
images.caption: Fort Monroe's Flagstaff is the first US flag the sailors of the USS Kearsage see when returning to the waters of Hampton Roads.

images.title: Fort Monroe Flagstaff Bastion
images.altText: sun setting over the moat of Fort Monroe
images.caption: Brilliant colors of the setting sun offer unique views of the largest stone fortification ever built in the United States.

images.title: Algernourne Oak: Standing Sentinel
images.altText: sunrise over the Parade Ground illuminates Algernourne Oak.
images.caption: The rising sun illuminates Algernourne Oak as it stands sentinel over the Parade Ground as it has done for almost 500 years.

images.title: Osprey Perches on Live Oak
images.altText: an Osprey dries its wings perched on a live oak.
images.caption: An Osprey, once endangered, dries its wings in the on-shore breeze while perched on a live oak.

parks.weatherInfo: Spring: Temperatures range from 40 F to 70 F with rain being common. Summer: Temperatures range from 75 F to 100 F with rain and sun equally common. On very sunny days, be prepared with plenty of water. Fall: Temperatures usually range from 40 F to 65 F. Hurricanes are more likely to threaten the are at this time of year. If planning a visit during this time, please be mindful of the storm activity. Winter: Temperatures range from 40 F to 50 F on average with snow being uncommon.
parks.name: Fort Monroe

parks.description: The battle at Fort Necessity in the summer of 1754 was the opening action of the French and Indian War. This war was a clash of British, French and American Indian cultures. It ended with the removal of French power from North America. The stage was set for the American Revolution.

entranceFees.description:
Entrance to the park is free, including all facilities and public programs. 
America the Beautiful - National Parks and Federal Recreation Lands Passes are NOT available at Fort Necessity.
entranceFees.title: Fort Necessity NB Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: The main unit of the park is located 11 miles east of Uniontown, Pennsylvania on U.S. Highway 40. The visitor center, reconstructed Fort Necessity, Mount Washington Tavern and picnic area are located in the main unit of the park.

operatingHours.description: Entrance to Fort Necessity National Battlefield is allowed from sunrise until sunset.  The park visitor center and Mount Washington Tavern museum have specific hours.  Please see the listing for each facility.
operatingHours.name: Fort Necessity National Battlefield

operatingHours.description: Open daily from sunrise to sunset.
operatingHours.name: Braddock Grave

operatingHours.description: Jumonville Glen is open May 1 through October 31 from sunrise to sunset
operatingHours.name: Jumonville Glen

images.title: Fort Necessity
images.altText: Circular stockade in the middle of a meadow. Dramatic clouds build in the blue sky.
images.caption: The small circular stockade of Fort Necessity served as a supply depot for George Washington's Virginia Regiment during their 1754 campaign.

images.title: Fort Necessity in Winter
images.altText: cabin and stockade casting shadows on the snow
images.caption: Fort Necessity National Battlefield is open year round.

images.title: Fort Necessity
images.altText: Fort Necessity and the Great Meadow with trail and tree in the foreground
images.caption: Fort Necessity was the site of George Washington's first military experience at the beginning of the French and Indian War

parks.weatherInfo: Weather varies considerably within each season. Be prepared with layered clothing. Precipitation is common throughout the year. Spring: Temperatures usually range from 25°F to 70°F. On average, May is the wettest month. Summer: Temperatures usually range from 50°F to 80°F. July is the warmest month. Fall: Temperatures usually range from 30°F to 70°F. Fall foliage is at its peak around mid-October. Winter: Temperatures range from 15°F to 40°F. January is the coldest month.
parks.name: Fort Necessity

parks.description: From its vantage point overlooking the spectacular Golden Gate, Fort Point defended the San Francisco Bay following California's Gold Rush through World War II. Its beautifully arched casemates display the art of 3rd system brick masonry and interacts gracefully with the Golden Gate Bridge.

entranceFees.description: There is no charge to visit Fort Point.
entranceFees.title: Entry to Fort Point is FREE!

parks.directionsInfo: Fort Point is located at the south anchorage of the Golden Gate Bridge at the end of Marine Drive on the Presidio of San Francisco. By car take Highway 101 N or S, exit at the Golden Gate Bridge toll plaza at south end of bridge. From S turn right at end of exit ramp, or from N go straight on Merchant Drive. Turn left onto Lincoln Boulevard. Take a left onto Long Avenue and follow onto Marine Drive.

operatingHours.description: The days in which Fort Point is open varies throughout the year. Fall through Spring the fort is generally open Friday through Sunday. During the summer season the fort is open 5 days a week most years. The timing of the shift in days is not consistent from year to year but generally occurs in October and May. Hours are 10 am to 5 pm. Closed on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day. Visit our web site for current open days.
operatingHours.name: Fort Point National Historic Site

images.title: Fort Point from Marine Drive
images.altText: Fort Point with visitors approaching on road in front and Golden Gate Bridge above.
images.caption: Fort Point offers stunning views from under the south end of the Golden Gate Bridge.

images.title: Fort Point Sunset View
images.altText: Golden sunset light on the roof of Fort Point with Golden Gate Bridge and bay behind.
images.caption: Visitors can enjoy winter sunsets from the top of Fort Point.

images.title: Brick Casemates
images.altText: Arched red brick casemates extend into the distance at Fort Point.
images.caption: Fort Point is known for its masterful masonry work.

images.title: Civil War Days at Fort Point
images.altText: A cannon stands in front of Civil War re-enactors talking to the public.
images.caption: Visitors can interact with Civil War re-enactors twice in January and August at the Fort.

images.title: Fort Point Lighthouse
images.altText: View of Fort Point lighthouse through red brick arches
images.caption: Fort Point has a historic lighthouse mounted on its top.

parks.weatherInfo: Fort Point is typically cold and windy throughout the year. Fog is especially common in the summer months. Come prepared with layers and windbreakers for maximum comfort.
parks.name: Fort Point

parks.description: For much of the 19th century, masonry fortifications were the United States’ main defense against overseas enemies. However, during the Civil War, new technology proved its superiority to these forts. The Union army used rifled cannon and compelled the Confederate garrison inside Fort Pulaski to surrender. The siege was a landmark experiment in the history of military science and invention.

entranceFees.description: Admission fee per person aged 16 years and older, valid for 7 consecutive days. Credit or Debit Cards Only. Digital passes can be purchased at https://www.recreation.gov/sitepass/2699
entranceFees.title: Fort Pulaski Entrance Fee - Per Person (16 years and older)

entranceFees.description: Admission fee per person aged 15 years and younger, good for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Fort Pulaski Entrance Fee - Per Person (15 years and younger)

entrancePasses.description: The Fort Pulaski Annual Pass covers the pass holder and three additional people for admission to the monument for one full year. Credit or Debit Cards Only. Digital passes can be purchased at https://www.recreation.gov/sitepass/2699
entrancePasses.title: Fort Pulaski Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: From Interstate I-95, take Exit 99 onto Interstate I-16 East (James L Gillis Memorial Hwy) for 7 miles. Take Exit 164A onto Interstate I-516 East toward US-80 East. Take Exit 3 (US-17 S/US-80 E) toward US-80 East. Turn left onto Ocean Highway, Ogeechee Rd (US-17 N, US-80 East). Bear right onto West Victory Drive (US-80 East). Continue on US-80 East for 13 miles. GPS Coordinates for Fort Pulaski National Monument: N32° 01.680 W080° 53.525

operatingHours.description: Fort Pulaski National Monument is open year round from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 pm, except for New Years, Thanksgiving, and Christmas Days. Last entry into the park is at 4:30 pm. Historic Fort Pulaski is open 9:00 a.m. to 4:30 pm and the Visitor Center is open from 9:00 am to 5:00 pm.
operatingHours.name: Fort Pulaski National Monument

images.title: The Battered Walls of Fort Pulaski
images.altText: The red masonry walls of Fort Pulaski still show battle damage over 150 years later.
images.caption: A walk along the outside of Fort Pulaski reveals damaged walls over 150 years after the Civil War.

images.title: The Casemates of a Fort
images.altText: The brick of the fort glow in the late afternoon light. The arches inside the fort reveal a cannon i
images.caption: Fort Pulaski shows off its classic arched architecture and cannon.

images.title: The Cockspur Island Lighthouse
images.altText: The white masonry Cockspur Island lighthouse sits in the Savannah River.
images.caption: The Cockspur Island Lighthouse still stands guard over the south channel of the Savannah River and Fort Pulaski.

images.title: The Sentinel
images.altText: A great blue heron stands watch on top of the fort's brick walls.
images.caption: A great blue heron stands on the top of Fort Pulaski like a lonely sentinel.

images.title: The Ladies of a Fort
images.altText: Two women dressed in mid nineteenth century civilian attire watch through looking glasses
images.caption: Volunteer living historians play an important role for the National Park Service and Fort Pulaski National Monument.

images.title: Night Cannon Firing at Fort Pulaski
images.altText: The night sky is illuminated as a cannon fires at Fort Pulaski
images.caption: Artillery demonstrations are an important part of the interpretation program at Fort Pulaski.

parks.weatherInfo: Savannah has a humid sub tropical climate with over two hundred days of sunshine each year. Summers are typically hot, bright and humid with afternoon thunderstorms common. Temperatures often range from the lower 70s to the mid 90s F. Spring and autumn can be quite pleasant with temperatures ranging from the upper 50s into the 80s F. The winter months are usually dry. Temperatures can be cooler than one would expect, ranging from the upper 30s through the 60s F generally, though sudden cold snaps can occur.
parks.name: Fort Pulaski

parks.description: Fort Raleigh National Historic Site protects and preserves known portions of England's first New World settlements from 1584 to 1590. This site also preserves the cultural heritage of the Native Americans, European Americans and African Americans who have lived on Roanoke Island.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee collected at Fort Raleigh National Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: Fort Raleigh National Historic Site is located on the northern end of Roanoke Island, north of the town of Manteo, NC.

operatingHours.description: The grounds are open for visitation 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.title: First Light of Freedom
images.altText: Back of the monument commemorating the Roanoke Island Freedmen's Colony
images.caption: Commemorating the Roanoke Island Freedmen's Colony

images.title: Thomas Hariot Trail
images.altText: Tree standing next to the maritime forest path of the Thomas Hariot Trail
images.caption: Venture through a maritime forest

images.title: Crucible Artifact
images.altText: Pieces of a crucible left behind by the 1585 English expedition
images.caption: Shards unearthed here provide clues to the English expedition of 1585

images.title: Waterside Theatre
images.altText: Stage of the Waterside Theatre with a view of the Roanoke Sound in the background
images.caption: Home of The Lost Colony drama performed every summer

parks.weatherInfo: Weather on the Outer Banks varies seasonally and daily. Please check the National Weather Service at http://www.weather.gov/mhx/ for up-to-date weather forecast information.
parks.name: Fort Raleigh

parks.description: Promises made and broken! Who deserves to be free? The fight for freedom! Soldiers fighting settlers! Each of these stories is a link in the chain of events that encircled Fort Scott from 1842-1873. All of the site's structures, its parade ground, and its tallgrass prairie bear witness to this era when the country was forged from a young republic into a united transcontinental nation.

entranceFees.description: The site does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

parks.directionsInfo: Fort Scott National Historic Site is located in downtown Fort Scott, Kansas. U.S. Highways 69 and 54 intersect here. Fort Scott is about 90 miles south of Kansas City and 60 miles northwest of Joplin, Missouri. It is 4 miles from the Kansas-Missouri border. Signs directing visitors to Fort Scott are posted on highway 69 for visitors coming from the north and the south and on highway 54 for visitors coming from the east and the west.

operatingHours.description:
Park Visitor Center and historic building hours listed under 'Visitor Centers'. 
Visitors may walk the park grounds, walkways and parking lot from ½ hour before sunrise until ½ hour after sunset, except during periods of snow, ice or other inclement weather conditions that make the grounds unsafe.
operatingHours.name: Fort Scott National Historic Site

images.title: Sunflowers at Fort Scott
images.altText: A field of sunflowers next to a stone building.  Wood frame structures in background.
images.caption: A field of sunflowers adds a splash of color to a view of the parade ground at Fort Scott.

images.title: Post Hospital
images.altText: Picture of the post hospital with the parade ground and trees in the background.
images.caption: Picture of the Post Hospital

images.title: Officers Quarters at Sunset
images.altText: Wood frame structures with stairs next to a stone walkway. Structures reflect afternoon sunlight.
images.caption: Officers quarters at Fort Scott bathed in the light of the afternoon sun.

images.title: Dragoons on the Prairie
images.altText: Four soldiers on horseback in a line riding through prairie grass
images.caption: Soldiers on horseback patrolling the prairie

images.title: Laundry Day
images.altText: Women dressed as laundresses with laundry buckets and scrub boards
images.caption: High school students dressed as laundresses demonstrate laundry methods of the 1840s

images.title: Symbols of Sacrifice
images.altText: Picture of rows of flags across the parade ground with trees in the background.
images.caption: Image of flags from the Symbols of Sacrifice event.

parks.weatherInfo: Spring and autumn are pleasant with mild temperatures. Summers are generally hot and humid, while winters are mild with periods of cold weather, snowfall, and ice storms. Thunderstorms, some severe, are common throughout the spring and summer. During periods of severe weather, visitors should seek shelter, as the area is prone to lightning strikes Visitors are advised to check the weather prior to traveling.
parks.name: Fort Scott

parks.description: Explore life on the edge of frontier and Indian Territory through the stories of soldiers, the Trail of Tears, scandals, outlaws, and lawmen who pursued them. From the establishment of the first Fort Smith on December 25, 1817, to the final days of Judge Isaac C. Parker's jurisdiction over Indian Territory in 1896, Fort Smith National Historic Site preserves almost 80 years of history.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee is for individual admittance into the exhibits inside the visitor center building. Your receipt will be good for seven days from the time of purchase. There is no fee for viewing the grounds.
entranceFees.title: Entrance walk in - per person

entrancePasses.description: The annual pass allows the pass holder and 3 adults (16 and older) free entrance to all the exhibits in the visitor center. The pass is valid for 12 months from the month of purchase, expiring the last day of that month.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Smith National Historic Site Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: From Interstate 40 Eastbound: Exit at Roland, and drive six miles on highway 64 to downtown Fort Smith. From Interstate 40 Westbound & from North I 540 & Fayetteville, take Interstate 40 westbound to I 540 south. Exit west on Rogers Ave. and continue to downtown. In the downtown area: On Rogers or Garrison Ave turn south at 4th St. Turn right onto Garland Ave. At the end of the next block is the entrance to the main parking lot. Parking is also available on Third Street.

operatingHours.description: Park grounds are open from 30 min before sunrise and 30 minutes after sunset.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds and Trails

operatingHours.description: The Commissary is considered the oldest building in Fort Smith. The Gallows is a replica built on the site of the original gallows.
operatingHours.name: Gallows and Commissary

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: Aerial view of visitor center
images.caption: The former barracks, courthouse, and jail serves as the park's visitor center

images.title: Commissary and Supply Wagon
images.altText: Commissary and Supply Wagon
images.caption: In 1845, Fort Smith was converted to a supply depot. With this mission, Fort Smith became one of the busiest supply posts in the southwest.

images.title: Entrance sign
images.altText: Entrance sign in snow
images.caption: Entrance sign along the river trail on a snowy day.

images.title: Foundations of First Fort Smith
images.altText: Foundations of first Fort Smith and Arkansas River
images.caption: Foundations of the first Fort Smith with Arkansas River in the background

images.title: Jail Wagon and Gallows
images.altText: Jail Wagon and Gallows
images.caption: A jail wagon like this one was use the transport prisoners to the Federal Courthouse 6th Street.

images.title: Supply Wagon and Visitor Center
images.altText: Supply Wagon and visitor center
images.caption: Supply Wagon and visitor center

parks.weatherInfo: Fort Smith weather includes four distinct, yet temperate seasons. Spring and fall are usually mild while late summer is hot and humid. During winter months, temperatures occasionally dip into the teens. Forecast often changes dramatically due to surrounding weather influences. Arkansas's central location allows weather systems from all directions to influence its climate. The area is prone to flash flooding and river flooding in rainy seasons.
parks.name: Fort Smith

parks.description: For centuries, the Oneida Carrying Place, a six mile portage connecting the Mohawk River and Wood Creek, served as a vital link for those traveling by water from the ocean to the Great Lakes. When Europeans arrived, nations fought for control of the carry, the homelands of the Six Nations Confederacy, and the rich resources of North America. In this struggle, Fort Stanwix would play a vital role.

entranceFees.description: All activities and tours are free.
entranceFees.title: Free

entrancePasses.description: All activities and tours are free.
entrancePasses.title: No Pass Required for Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: Take I-90 (NY Thruway) to Exit 33 (Verona-Rome). Turn Right onto Rt. 365 E. Follow Rt. 365, veering left as Rt. 365 merges with Rt 69 at the fork in the road. This will take you over an arterial bridge into the City of Rome. Fort Stanwix NM will be across Erie Blvd. on the right side of James Street.

operatingHours.description: The historic fort at Fort Stanwix National Monument is open for limited hours in accordance with COVID-19 CDC guidance.
operatingHours.name: Historic Fort

images.title: Which Adventure Will You Choose?
images.altText: A park ranger directs a group of children thorugh the fort.
images.caption: From ranger tours, to walking trails, to exploring history, there's plenty to do at Fort Stanwix!

images.title: Celebrate the Park! Fort Stanwix at 40 & the NPS Centennial!
images.altText: Children dance, jump, and skip on the parade ground of reconstructed Fort Stanwix.
images.caption: The park is gearing up for the National Park Service Centennial. Find out what's going on and what's already been done!

images.title: Objects From the Past: Museum Collection
images.altText: Small boxes in rows contain small artifacts, including broken pipes and glass bottles.
images.caption: Learn more about the objects in the park's museum collection.

images.title: Uncovering the Past at Fort Stanwix
images.altText: A woman digs in a carefully excavated hole.
images.caption: What evidence of the past has been found at Fort Stanwix? Stop through to find out!

images.title: Fort Stanwix: History Happened Here!
images.altText: Soldiers stand in a neat row holding their muskets.
images.caption: Discover the vital role that Fort Stanwix/Schuyler, the fort that "never surrendered" played in the American Revolution.

parks.weatherInfo: The Park lies within a temperate zone and experiences four full seasons. Summer can become very hot and humid. Snow is common as late as May and as early as October. The fort area can become muddy in all seasons. With most activities outdoors, good closed-toe walking shoes and low heels are advised. Air conditioning and heating is limited to park visitor center most times in the year. Water and extra layers of clothing in all seasons are always recommended!
parks.name: Fort Stanwix

parks.fullName: Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park
parks.description: Two forts stand at the entrance of Charleston Harbor. Patriots inside a palmetto log fort, later named Fort Moultrie, defeated the Royal Navy in 1776. As Charleston blazed a path towards secession to preserve slavery, construction on a new fort, Fort Sumter, proceeded. The Confederacy fired on the US garrison of Fort Sumter on April 12, 1861 opening the Civil War, which redefined American freedom.

entranceFees.description: There is an entrance fee for Fort Moultrie which can be purchased in advance at https://www.recreation.gov/sitepass/2704. Adults 16 and older are $10. Children 15 and younger are free. All America the Beautiful passes are accepted. A this time, to purchase an America the Beautiful  pass, we can only accept cash.
entranceFees.title: Fort Moultrie Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description:
The park concessioner charges a fee for the ferry ride to Fort Sumter. This is the only way to get to the fort. Ferry boats depart from 2 locations: the Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center in Charleston; and Patriots Point in Mount Pleasant. Please go to https://www.fortsumtertours.com for the latest prices. Prices are subject to change.

Concessioner does not honor the America the Beautiful-National Parks and Federal Lands Pass.
entranceFees.title: Transportation Fee for Concession Ferry Ride to Fort Sumter

entranceFees.description:
The Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center, located at 340 Concord Street in Charleston is the primary departure point for the ferries to Fort Sumter. Museum exhibits, park rangers and a museum store are on site. This visitor education center is free to visit.

There is a cost for the concession ferry ride to Fort Sumter which is separate from the Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center.
entranceFees.title: Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center

entrancePasses.description: Annual Pass for Fort Moultrie valid for pass holder and three additional adults. Valid for one year from purchase date. The Fort Moultrie Pass is available for purchase at https://www.recreation.gov/sitepass/2704. Fort Moultrie is currently not accepting cash for entrance fees.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Moultrie Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Fort Sumter is accessible by ferry boat. Boats depart at scheduled times from two sites. The primary departure point is the Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center, 340 Concord Street, Charleston. Boats depart from Patriots Point, 40 Patriots Point Boulevard, Mount Pleasant. There is a fee for the concession-operated ferry. Fort Moultrie is accessible by car at 1214 Middle Street, Sullivan's Island. A park entrance fee is charged for the park. Details at: https://www.nps.gov/fosu/planyourvisit/directions.

operatingHours.description: Fort Moultrie represents the entire history of static seacoast defenses in the United States, from the American Revolution through World War II. The site includes a visitor center with museum exhibits. The Fort Moultrie Visitor Center is open daily 9:00 am-5:00 pm during daylight saving time, and 9:00 am-4:00 pm during eastern standard time. The fort itself is open until 5:00 pm all year. There is an entrance fee for the park.
operatingHours.name: Fort Moultrie

operatingHours.description: The Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center at Liberty Square, 340 Concord Street, Charleston, is the primary departure point for ferry boats to Fort Sumter. This visitor education center is free. There is a fee for the concession-operated ferry to Fort Sumter.
operatingHours.name: Fort Sumter and the Liberty Square Visitor Education Center

images.title: Fort Moultrie
images.altText: A row of cannon with Fort Moultrie in the background. A US flag is flying in the fort.
images.caption: Fort Moultrie spans 171 years from 1776-1947

images.title: Fort Sumter
images.altText: Fort Sumter with a US flag flying above the fort with dock in the foreground
images.caption: Fort Sumter is located on an island in Charleston Harbor and is only accessible by boat.

images.title: Fort Sumter Cannon
images.altText: Civil War cannon sitting on carriage pointing towards firing hole in brick wall
images.caption: Fort Sumter cannon sitting on cannon carriage under a brick casemate

images.title: Inside Fort Moultrie Today
images.altText: Center of image is round metal and glass signal light with grassy hills hills in background
images.caption: Interior View of Fort Moultrie featuring the World War II signal light with grass hills and black concrete gun bateries

images.title: Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center
images.altText: A three-story brick structure with a staircase in front and water in the background
images.caption: The Fort Sumter Visitor Education Center is the primary departure point for the ferries to Fort Sumter.

parks.weatherInfo: Mild winters. Hot and humid during the summer.
parks.name: Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie

parks.description: Exposed to the wind, within a sweeping valley of short grass prairie, amid the swales of the Santa Fe Trail, lie the territorial-style adobe remnants of the largest 19th century military fort in the region. For forty years, 1851-1891, Fort Union functioned as an agent of political and cultural change, whether desired or not, in New Mexico and throughout the Southwest.

entranceFees.description: There is NO FEE to enter Fort Union National Monument. Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: Fees

parks.directionsInfo: Fort Union National Monument is located in the Northeastern portion of the state of New Mexico. 8 miles off of Interstate I-25 on State Highway NM 161. New Mexico: From Albuquerque (156 miles), Santa Fe (94 miles) or Las Vegas, NM (28 miles) take I-25 North, exit 366 at Watrous, 8 miles on NM 161. Colorado: From Denver (313 miles), Colorado Springs (243 miles) or Raton (95 miles) take I-25 South, exit 366 at Watrous, 8 miles on NM 161.

operatingHours.description:
The monument grounds and visitor center are generally open 7 days a week, from 8:00 AM - 4:00 PM during the winter season and from 8:00-5:00 PM during the summer season. The summer season runs from Memorial Day to Labor Day.
The monument is closed Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, New Year's Day
operatingHours.name: Fort Union National Monument Operating Hours

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.title: Big Skies Over Officers Row
images.altText: Panorama of Officers Row
images.caption: Blue skies and billowing clouds frequently add to the incredible viewshed that surrounds the monument grounds.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.title: Freezing Fog in Mechanics Corral
images.altText: Wagons encrusted in frost
images.caption: One of the most photographed areas of the monument, the Mechanics Corral onced serviced wagons that travelled along the Santa Fe Trail.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.title: Sunflower in Enlisted Barracks
images.altText: Sunflower in Enlisted Barracks
images.caption: Located deep within the Mora Valley, Fort Union National Monument contains a vast array of plant and animal life.

images.title: Remnants of the Past
images.altText: Moon in sky above adobe remnants
images.caption: Located on the monument grounds is the world's largest collection of Territorial-Style adobe remanants.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.title: Fort Union NM Visitor Center
images.altText: Fort Union Visitor Center Sign
images.caption: Completed in 1960, the Visitor Center at Fort Union was one of the first built during the "MIssion 66" program for the National Park Service. It was designed by the internationally known architect Cecil Doty.

parks.weatherInfo: Fort Union is situated at 6,760 feet above sea level. Daytime temperatures between June and September may exceed 90 degrees Fahrenheit. Winter temperatures often drop below 32 degrees Fahrenheit. Temperatures may vary within 50 degrees in a 24-hour period. During the winter, it is not uncommon for the temperatures to drop below 0°F (-18°C.) During the summer, expect high temperatures, intense sunlight and extreme low humidity.
parks.name: Fort Union

parks.fullName: Fort Union Trading Post National Historic Site
parks.description: Between 1828 and 1867, Fort Union was the most important fur trade post on the Upper Missouri River. Here, the Assiniboine and six other Northern Plains Tribes exchanged buffalo robes and smaller furs for goods from around the world, including cloth, guns, blankets, and beads. A bastion of peaceful coexistence, the post annually traded over 25,000 buffalo robes and $100,000 in merchandise.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Fort Union Trading Post National Historic Site - Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance to Fort Union Trading Post NHS

parks.directionsInfo: Located on North Dakota Highway 1804 right at the Montana and North Dakota state line. From Williston, ND, approximately 25 miles to the southwest via ND Highways 2 & 1804. From Sidney, MT, approximately 25 miles to the northeast, via MT Highways 200 & 58. Commercial flights and rental cars are available in both Williston, ND and Sidney, MT. Amtrak passenger train service and rental cars are available in Williston, ND.

operatingHours.description: Park Hours for 2021 are 9:00 am to 5:00 pm, CDT
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.title: River View of Fort Union
images.altText: View from Missouri River bottoms of Southwest bastion
images.caption: Viewing Fort Union Trading Post from the Missouri River bottoms one can imagine how grandiose the site would appear to weary steamboat travelers.

images.title: Twilight View of the Bourgeois House
images.altText: Candles illuminate the Bourgeois House porch at dusk
images.caption: Volunteer reenactors relax on the Bourgeois House porch

images.title: Fort Union Trading Post Courtyard
images.altText: Courtyard of Fort Union Trading Post with Bourgeois House, Tipis and US Flag
images.caption: Ranging from employee housing, workshops, storage warehouses, domestic animal pens and horse corrals, the courtyard housed the world at Fort Union.

images.title: Fort Union and the Missouri River Valley
images.altText: View of Fort Union and the Missouri River looking south
images.caption: Visitors hiking the scenic Bodmer Trail experience a historical view of Fort Union, and the same view painted by Karl Bodmer in 1833.

parks.weatherInfo: Weather in western North Dakota can be harsh, with extremes in temperature and sudden, violent storms. Be prepared for rapidly changing conditions. Summers are warm with average high temperatures in the 80s-90s May through September. Winters are cold with average lows in the single digits December through February. Wind is considerable year-round. Conditions can change quickly. Travelers should be aware of the potential for violent thunderstorms in the summer and the possibility of blizzards.
parks.name: Fort Union Trading Post

parks.description: Located on the north bank of the Columbia River, in sight of snowy mountain peaks and a vibrant urban landscape, this park has a rich cultural past. From a frontier fur trading post, to a powerful military legacy, the magic of flight, and the origin of the American Pacific Northwest, history is shared at four unique sites. Discover stories of transition, settlement, conflict, and community.

entranceFees.description:
Visitors ages 16 and up. Fee applies to one individual. Receipt allows re-entry for seven days. 

Pay entrance fees online at https://www.recreation.gov/camping/gateways/2708
entranceFees.title: Reconstructed Fort Vancouver Entrance Fee - Per Adult

entranceFees.description: Visitors ages 15 and under.
entranceFees.title: Reconstructed Fort Vancouver Entrance Fee - Per Child

entranceFees.description: Free during open hours.
entranceFees.title: Pearson Air Museum Entrance Fee - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Free during open hours.
entranceFees.title: McLoughlin House Entrance Fee - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Free during open hours.
entranceFees.title: Fort Vancouver Visitor Center Entrance Fee - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Allows free entry for passholder and up to three adults to Fort Vancouver National Historic Site. The pass is valid for one year from date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Vancouver Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: From I-5, take the Mill Plain Boulevard exit (Exit 1-C) and head east. Turn south onto Fort Vancouver Way. At the traffic circle, go east on Evergreen Boulevard and follow signs to the Fort Vancouver Visitor Center. From I-205, go west on Highway 14 about six miles, then take I-5 north. From I-5, take the Mill Plain Boulevard exit (Exit 1-C) and head east. At the traffic circle, go east on Evergreen Boulevard and follow signs to the Fort Vancouver Visitor Center.

operatingHours.description:
Fort Vancouver Visitor Center, the reconstructed Fort Vancouver and Pearson Air Museum, located in Vancouver, Washington. 

All park facilities are closed on major holidays, including Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, New Year's Eve, and New Year's Day.

Summer hours are in effect from Memorial Day to Labor Day. Winter hours are in effect from Labor Day to Memorial Day. During winter hours, park facilities will be open 9 am to 4 pm.
operatingHours.name: Fort Vancouver National Historic Site

operatingHours.description: McLoughlin House Unit of Fort Vancouver National Historic Site, located in Oregon City, Oregon. The house is closed seasonally from mid-December to mid-February. The McLoughlin House is currently closed until spring 2021 as it undergoes rehabilitation. However, during opening hours, visitors can learn about the site and shop at the McLoughlin Memorial Association Bookstore at the neighboring Barclay House.
operatingHours.name: McLoughlin House Unit

images.title: Fort Vancouver Garden
images.altText: Fort Vancouver Garden
images.caption: The garden at the reconstructed Fort Vancouver showcases the many plants that were grown at the historic Fort Vancouver.

images.title: Black Powder Demonstrations at Fort Vancouver NHS
images.altText: Black Powder Demonstrations at Fort Vancouver NHS
images.caption: The military history at Vancouver Barracks is told through living history demonstrations, including historic weapons demonstrations.

images.title: Fort Vancouver
images.altText: Fort Vancouver
images.caption: A walk through the reconstructed Fort Vancouver is a highlight of any trip to Fort Vancouver National Historic Site.

images.title: McLoughlin House
images.altText: McLoughlin House
images.caption: The McLoughlin House in Oregon City is a unit of Fort Vancouver National Historic Site. Here, visitors learn about Dr. John McLoughlin and the early history of Oregon state.

images.title: Pearson Air Museum
images.altText: Pearson Air Museum
images.caption: At Pearson Air Museum, visitors learn about the history of Pearson Field and early aviation in the Pacific Northwest.

parks.weatherInfo: Fort Vancouver National Historic Site is located in a mild, temperate climate. However, in the case of severe weather, park alerts posted on the park's website will provide information about emergency closures.
parks.name: Fort Vancouver

parks.description: Built to defend the river approach to Washington, DC, Fort Washington has stood as silent sentry for over 200 years. As technologies advanced so did Fort Washington, from the brick and stone of the 19th century to the concrete and steel of the 20th century. Joining the National Park Service in 1946, the park continues to protect the Potomac River.

entranceFees.description:
Fort Washington no longer has an entrance fee.  

There is still a reservation fee for the Reserved Picnic Areas, www.recreation.gov
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: From I-95/495 take exit 3, Indian Head Highway South/MD 210. Travel about 4 miles to Fort Washington Road, turn right. The park is located at the end of the road. From Waldorf, MD: MD228 to Indian Head Highway/MD210 North. Turn left onto Old Fort Road. Continue to end of road, at the stop sign turn left onto Fort Washington Road, continue to park entrance.

operatingHours.description:
The park grounds are open until sunset throughout the year.

The park entrance gate opens at 6:30 am every day during the summer months.  Beginning in October the gate opens at 6:30 am Monday through Friday and at 8:30 am Saturday and Sunday.
operatingHours.name: Fort Washington Park grounds

operatingHours.description: Park Gate is opened May through October at 6:30 am.  November through April the gate opens at 8:30 am.
operatingHours.name: Park Entrance Gate

images.title: Fort Washington Volunteers firing a cannon
images.altText: Fort Washington Volunteers firing a cannon
images.caption: Fort Washington Guard fires one of the park's cannons.  Demonstrations are presented during the summer months April-October.

images.title: Entrance to Fort Washington
images.altText: Entrance way into historic Fort Washington
images.caption: Fort Washington Entrance

images.title: Picnic Area A at Fort Washington Park
images.altText: Picnic Area at Fort Washington Park
images.caption: Picnic Area A is one of the areas available to reserve.

images.title: Park has a variety of wildlife
images.altText: photo of three white tailed deer
images.caption: Doe with two fawns

parks.weatherInfo: Summers are generally hot and humid, with daytime highs frequently above 90 degrees Fahrenheit and scattered afternoon thunderstorms. Please carry water while participating in physical activity and be prepared to take shelter from lightning. Winters are generally cold, with nighttime lows frequently near freezing and occasional snowfall. Weather during spring and fall is generally moderate, but can change quickly.
parks.name: Fort Washington

parks.description: Some of the world's best preserved fossils are found in the flat-topped ridges of southwestern Wyoming's cold sagebrush desert. Fossilized fishes, insects, plants, reptiles, birds, and mammals are exceptional for their abundance, variety, and detail of preservation. Most remarkable is the story they tell of ancient life in a subtropical landscape.

entranceFees.description: Free
entranceFees.title: Fossil Butte Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: By car: Travel 9 miles west of Kemmerer, Wyoming on U.S. Highway 30. There is a highway sign near mile post 44; turn right onto Lincoln County Road 300. The Historic Quarry Trail is approximately 1/2 mile on the right. Continue west on County Road 300 for approximately 3 miles to Chicken Creek Road which provides access to the visitor center, scenic drive, Nature Trail and picnic area. Closest airports: Rock Springs, Wyoming (130 miles); Salt Lake City, Utah (150 miles)

operatingHours.description:
Visitors may enter the park any day sunrise to sunset, but visitor services and motor vehicle access vary throughout the year. 
Camping is not available.
operatingHours.name: Fossil Butte National Monument

images.title: Fossils on the Ridge
images.altText: Fish fossils, Knightia eocaena, exposed near cliff
images.caption: Knightia eocaena, the most abundant vertebrate fossil in the world, lies exposed near cliff face.

images.title: Cockerellites liops, a Common Fossil Fish
images.altText: a well preserved fossil fish, Cockerellites liops
images.caption: Fossils from the Green River Formation are known for their excellent preservation, abundance, and diversity. Cockerellites liops is one of the common fishes found here.

images.title: Palm Frond
images.altText: fossil palm frond
images.caption: Fossil palm fronds and other plants indicate a climate similar to the Gulf Coast states.

images.title: The Limestone Ridges, Remnants of Ancient Fossil Lake, Contrast the Green, Early Summer Landscape.
images.altText: A scenic view of Fossil Basin in early summer; yellow limestone, red mudstones and green vegetation
images.caption: Early Summer Beauty in the High Desert of Southwestern Wyoming

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: visitor center with Fossil Butte in the background
images.caption: The visitor center is nestled in a sagebrush landscape beneath Fossil Butte. Over 300 fossils are on exhibit.

images.title: Moonrise Over Fossil Butte
images.altText: The moon rises just to the right of snow-covered Fossil Butte.
images.caption: Fossil Butte is the most noticeable landmark of the park and where the monument got its name.

parks.weatherInfo: Expect a variety of weather conditions no matter what time of year you visit. Spring, fall and winter can be very cold; expect snow and winter conditions. Spring: Day time temperatures usually range from 30 F to 65 F Summer: Day time temperatures range from 60 F to 90 F Fall: Day time temperatures range from 45 F to 70 F Winter: Day time temperatures range from -20 F to 30 F
parks.name: Fossil Butte

parks.description: These words by President Franklin Delano Roosevelt ushered the United States into World War II and defined what it is to be an American. Stop by this secluded memorial and begin to understand the Roosevelt legacy.

entranceFees.description: No Entrance Fee to enter park site
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: No Passes
entrancePasses.title: No Passes

parks.directionsInfo: GPS Coordinates: 38.883625, -77.043868 Address: 400 West Basin Drive SW, Washington, D.C. Nearest Intersection: West Basin Drive SW & Ohio Drive. SW

operatingHours.description: There are no Rangers on duty at this site (except for special events). The United States Park Police are on duty 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Always Open

images.title: Franklin Delano Roosevelt
images.altText: Picture of FDR in a wheel chair within his memorial
images.caption: From Adversity to Presidency

parks.weatherInfo: Washington DC gets to see all four seasons. Humidity will make the temps feel hotter in summer and colder in winter. Spring (March - May) Temp: Average high is 65.5 degrees with a low of 46.5 degrees Summer (June - August) Temp: Average high is 86 degrees with a low of 68.5 degrees Fall (September - November) Temp: Average high is 68 degrees with a low of 51.5 degrees Winter (December - February) Temp: Average high is 45 degrees with a low of 30 degrees (Source: www.usclimatedata.com)
parks.name: Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial

parks.description: Frederick Douglass spent his life fighting for justice and equality. Born into slavery in 1818, he escaped as a young man and became a leading voice in the abolitionist movement. People everywhere still find inspiration today in his tireless struggle, brilliant words, and inclusive vision of humanity. Douglass's legacy is preserved here at Cedar Hill, where he lived his last 17 years.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: Visitors can reserve tickets for guided tours of the historic house.
entranceFees.title: House Tour Reservation

parks.directionsInfo: The site can be reached by car, public transportation, or on foot. See the directions page of the website for more detailed information.

operatingHours.description:
Hours apply to the grounds. 

The visitor center and historic home are closed to the public at this time, so no guided tours of the historic home are available.
operatingHours.name: Frederick Douglass National Historic Site

images.title: Cedar Hill
images.altText: Visitors take photos in front of a historic house
images.caption: Rangers guide daily tours of the historic house at scheduled times.

images.title: The Growlery
images.altText: A tiny stone cabin surrounded by fall foliage
images.caption: Frederick Douglass retreated to this stone cabin to read, write, and think in seclusion.

images.title: View of Washington, D.C.
images.altText: View of downtown Washington, D.C., including the Washington Monument and U.S. Capitol
images.caption: Frederick Douglass's view from Cedar Hill continues to impress visitors today.

images.title: Bust of Frederick Douglass
images.altText: A plaster bust of Frederick Douglass
images.caption: Hundreds of original objects, such as this bust, furnish the historic house.

parks.weatherInfo: Winter: Temperatures usually range from 30 to 50 F. There is occasional snow. Spring: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Rain is common. Summer: Temperatures usually range from 70 to 90 F. Humidity is usually high. Be prepared and drink plenty of water. There is a water fountain in the visitor center. Fall: Temperatures usually range widely from 40 to 70 F. Humidity can remain high in the earlier part of the season.
parks.name: Frederick Douglass

parks.fullName: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
parks.description: Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903) is recognized as the founder of American landscape architecture and the nation's foremost parkmaker. Olmsted moved his home to suburban Boston in 1883 and established the world's first full-scale professional office for the practice of landscape design. During the next century, his sons and successors perpetuated Olmsted's design ideals, philosophy, and influence.

entranceFees.description: No entrance fee required.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: No entrance passes required.
entrancePasses.title: No Entrance Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Site is located on the southwest corner of Warren and Dudley Streets in Brookline, south of Route 9, near the Brookline Reservoir. Site is 0.7 miles from the Brookline Hills MBTA stop on the Green Line, D Branch.

operatingHours.description: Site hours vary between seasons.
operatingHours.name: Hours vary by season.

operatingHours.description: Fairsted's restored landscape is open from dawn to dusk, 365 days a year. Grounds guides are available outside the visitor center.
operatingHours.name: Grounds Hours

images.title: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
images.altText: Fairsted
images.caption: Fairsted, the home and office of landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted. Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site.

images.title: Drafting Table
images.altText: Dark wood box with four shallow drawers on large wooden table with blueprint
images.caption: A box of colored pencils and a draftsmen's handbook sit on a table in the drafting room. These materials reflect the period during which Frederick Law Olmsted, Jr. was the senior partner in the Brookline, MA landscape architecture firm.

images.title: The Hollow
images.altText: A shaded bench and plants in a sunken garden surrounded by bushes
images.caption: Landscape Architect Frederick Law Olmsted designed the Hollow on his Brookline, MA property to be a peaceful, picturesque sunken garden.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer: Warm temperatures, average high temperature around 80 degrees Fahrenheit, often with humidity. July and August bring the hottest temperatures. Fall: Cooler temperatures, mean temperatures between 45 and 65 degrees Fahrenheit, sometimes rainy. Peak fall foliage is in mid-October. Winter: Cold, with snow, average low temperature around 25 degrees Fahrenheit. Spring: Cold to cool temperatures, average mean temperatures between 40 and 60 degrees Fahrenheit.
parks.name: Frederick Law Olmsted

parks.description: Fredericksburg, Chancellorsville, Wilderness, and Spotsylvania--this is America's battleground, where the Civil War roared to its bloody climax. No place more vividly reflects the War's tragic cost in all its forms. A town bombarded and looted. Farms large and small ruined. Refugees by the thousands forced into the countryside. More than 85,000 men wounded; 15,000 killed--most in graves unknown.

entranceFees.description: Fredericksburg & Spotsylvania is a fee free park
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description:
The Fredericksburg and Chancellorsville Visitor Center each offer a unique 22-minute film. The films cost $2.00 (free for ages 10 and under, $1.00 for adults 62 and over). 

Tickets can be purchased at the museum store.
entranceFees.title: Visitor Center Films

parks.directionsInfo: Fredericksburg and Spotsylvania National Military Park manages 4 battlefields and multiple historical sites across multiple counties. The park is located approximately 50 miles south of Washington DC. Different battlefields and historical sites are accessible via I-95 and VA Route 3. For directions and physical addresses for each of our sites, please visit the Directions & Transportation section of our website.

operatingHours.description: Park grounds are open from sunrise to sunset daily, with the exception of extreme weather incidents. Building hours vary by building and season.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.title: Jackson Flank Attack Site
images.altText: Fog near rolling hills with sun rising in background
images.caption: Fredericksburg & Spotsylvania is now characterized by dynamic landscapes as well significant Civil War battles that took place on the same ground

images.title: Chatham in the Fall
images.altText: Trees with fall colors in front of large brick manor house
images.caption: When visiting Fredericksburg & Spotsylvania, be sure to explore our numerous historic structures, such as Chatham Manor pictured here

images.title: Cannon Firing Demonstration
images.altText: Cannon crew in the process of a firing demonstration
images.caption: Check out our Special Events page for information about special tours, lectures, programs, and living history demonstrations

images.title: Fredericksburg National Cemetery
images.altText: Monument in national cemetery illuminated by candles
images.caption: Thousands of visitors join us every year for our Memorial Day Illumination of the National Cemetery

images.title: Ranger Programs
images.altText: Two NPS rangers and a number of visitors hold candles during evening ceremony
images.caption: Get the most out of your battlefield experience by taking a guided ranger program!

parks.weatherInfo: The regional climate is characterized by mild winters and warm, humid summers. The mean annual temperatures is 56 degrees Fahrenheit. The average summer temperature is 75 degrees Fahrenheit. Daytime highs during the summer can reach the 90s, and nighttime lows are in the lower 60s. Daytime highs in the winter are typically in the upper 40s, and nighttime lows in the middle 20s. Precipitation is well distributed throughout the year, with the minimum amount in August and the maximum in February.
parks.name: Fredericksburg & Spotsylvania

parks.description: In 1961, a small interracial band of “Freedom Riders” challenged discriminatory laws requiring separation of the races in interstate travel. They were attacked by white segregationists, who firebombed the bus. Images of the attack appeared in hundreds of newspapers, shocking the American public and spurring the Federal Government to issue regulations banning segregation in interstate travel.

entranceFees.description: Freedom Riders National Monument does not have a fee for entry.
entranceFees.title: Freedom Riders National Monument

parks.directionsInfo: Directions to the Bus Burning Site, from Atlanta and Points East: From I-20, take exit 179 toward AL-202 E/US-78/Coldwater. Merge onto Alabama State Highway 202. Turn right onto Old Birmingham Hwy. The Bus Burning site is located on the right. Limited parking is available at the burn site with entry from the Old Birmingham Hwy. There is no authorized parking or pedestrian activity along State Route 202. For directions to the Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot, click on link below.

operatingHours.description: Please visit the Freedom Riders National Monument Interim Visitor Center, located at the Calhoun County Chamber of Commerce (1330 Quintard Avenue).
operatingHours.name: Interim Visitor Center

operatingHours.description: The historic Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot, located at 1031 Gurnee Avenue, is open to the public on Fridays from 12:00 pm to 5:00 pm and on weekends between 10:00 am and 5:00 pm.
operatingHours.name: Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot

images.title: Greyhound Mural

images.caption: Greyhound mural at the Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot.

images.caption: The Anniston Greyhound Bus Depot at Freedom Riders National Monument in Anniston AL, site of an attack on Freedom Riders in May of 1961.

parks.weatherInfo: Temperatures can soar to extremes of heat and humidity in the summer and fall to a damp, wet, cold in the winter. During the summer season visitors should dress in light, comfortable clothing, wear comfortable shoes and use sunscreen. Drink plenty of fluids to maintain hydration. In the spring and fall, visitors should have a light jacket available as temperatures can drop suddenly. Winter temperatures can be unpredictable, ranging from mild to extremely cold
parks.name: Freedom Riders

parks.description: Albert Gallatin is best remembered for his thirteen year tenure as Secretary of the Treasury during the Jefferson and Madison administrations. In that time he reduced the national debt, purchased the Louisiana Territory and funded the Lewis & Clark exploration. Gallatin's accomplishments and contributions are highlighted at Friendship Hill, his restored country estate.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee at Friendship Hill National Historic Site.   Activities that require a permit may have a fee.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Friendship Hill NHS is located on PA 166 three miles north of Point Marion, Pennsylvania.

operatingHours.description: The Park Grounds and Trails are open daily from sunrise to sunset, all year. Please note: While the park is open Sunrise to Sunset - the Gallatin House Visitor Center may be closed.
operatingHours.name: Friendship Hill Grounds and Trails

images.title: Gallatin House - Stone House and well
images.altText: Gallatin house
images.caption: Friendship Hill was the country home of Albert Gallatin

parks.weatherInfo: Weather varies considerably within each season. Be prepared with layered clothing. Precipitation is common throughout the year. Spring: Temperatures usually range from 25°F to 70°F. On average, May is the wettest month. Summer: Temperatures usually range from 50°F to 80°F. July is the warmest month. Fall: Temperatures usually range from 30°F to 70°F. Fall foliage is at its peak around mid-October. Winter: Temperatures range from 15°F to 40°F. January is the coldest month.
parks.name: Friendship Hill

parks.fullName: Gates Of The Arctic National Park & Preserve
parks.description: This vast landscape does not contain any roads or trails. Visitors discover intact ecosystems where people have lived with the land for thousands of years. Wild rivers meander through glacier-carved valleys, caribou migrate along age-old trails, endless summer light fades into aurora-lit night skies of winter. It remains virtually unchanged except by the forces of nature.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Gates of the Arctic.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Gates of the Arctic is a wilderness park, with no roads or trails into the park lands, so visitors must fly or hike into the park. Access begins in Fairbanks, Alaska & there are several small airlines that provide daily flights into the communities of Bettles, Anaktuvuk Pass, and Coldfoot. Most visitors access the park by air taxi or hike in from the Dalton Highway or from the village of Anaktuvuk Pass. River crossings are necessary from both locations.

operatingHours.description: No closed times or seasons for Gates of the Arctic National Park & Preserve. Visitor Center hours vary greatly by location and season. See Visitor Center Hours for more information!
operatingHours.name: Park & Preserve are always open

parks.weatherInfo: The climate of Gates of the Arctic National Park & Preserve is generally classified as arctic and sub-arctic, with exceptionally cold winters, relatively mild summers, low annual precipitation, and generally high winds. The weather is influenced by many different systems, and can change rapidly.!!
parks.name: Gates Of The Arctic

parks.description: The Gateway Arch reflects St. Louis' role in the Westward Expansion of the United States during the nineteenth century. The park is a memorial to Thomas Jefferson's role in opening the West, to the pioneers who helped shape its history, and to Dred Scott who sued for his freedom in the Old Courthouse.

entranceFees.description:
The entrance fee is $3.00 per person. Entry is free for children under 16 and America the Beautiful pass holders. The tram ride, movie and riverboat cruises are an additional fee for adults and children.
Admission to the Museum Under the Gateway Arch is free.

parks.description: Spanning 27,000 acres from Sandy Hook in New Jersey to Breezy Point in New York City, the park is both the gateway from the ocean into New York Harbor, and the gateway to the National Park Service for millions of visitors every year. Gateway offers green spaces and beaches alongside historic structures and cultural landscapes. Every day, Gateway is open for you to explore, envision, and enjoy!

entranceFees.description: Gateway has no entrance fees, but charges parking fees from the Saturday before Memorial Day through Labor Day.  Access Pass holders and Senior Pass holders will receive a 50% discount off of parking fees.
entranceFees.title: Gateway Parking fees- Sandy Hook daily

entranceFees.description: Gateway has no entrance fees, but charges parking fees at Sandy Hook from the Saturday before Memorial Day through Labor Day.  Access Pass holders and Senior Pass holders will receive a 50% discount off of beach parking.

entranceFees.description: Gateway has no entrance fees, but charges parking fees for Jacob Riis park from the Saturday before Memorial Day through Labor Day.  Access Pass holders and Senior Pass holders will receive a 50% discount off of beach parking.

entranceFees.description: Gateway has no entrance fees, but charges for parking at Jacob Riis Park from the Saturday before Memorial Day through Labor Day.  Access Pass holders and Senior Pass holders will receive a 50% discount off of beach parking.

entrancePasses.description: Golden Access Passes are free, and offer lifetime access to citizens and permanent residents who have been medically determined to have a permanent disability.  Golden Access Pass holders will receive a 50% discount for parking at both Sandy Hook and Jacob Riis Park.  You can obtain these passes at any Gateway visitor center as well as at other national parks.

parks.directionsInfo: Gateway is located in two states; NJ and NY, and has three units: Jamaica Bay, Sandy Hook and Staten Island. You can access most of our park by car and public transportation. Please visit our website for specific directions to all of our units

Includes Bergen Beach, Floyd Bennett Field, Fort Tilden, Frank Charles Park, Hamilton Beach, Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge, Canarsie Pier, Jacob Riis Park, North Channel Bridge, Plumb Beach and Spring Creek


All of our buildings are currently closed in response to New York and New Jersey’s Executive Orders to close all non-life sustaining operations to curb the spread of COVID-19.

operatingHours.description:
The Staten Island unit includes Fort Wadsworth, Great Kills and Miller Field.
