parks.description: For thousands of years, groups of nomadic people used the caves of the Gila River as temporary shelter. In the late 1200's, people of the Mogollon Culture decided it would be a good place to call home. They built rooms, crafted pottery and raised children in the cliff dwellings for about twenty years. Then the Mogollon moved on, leaving the walls for us as a glimpse into the past.

entranceFees.description: As of August 2019 Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument is a fee free park.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: Active duty military, retired military, Gold Star families and their dependents may qualify for this pass. Covers entrance or standard amenity fees at Federal Recreation sites for the pass holder and occupants of a single, private, non-commercial vehicle OR the pass holder and 3 persons over the age of 16 where per person fees are charged. Must show proof of military or dependent status.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Military Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: For US citizens and permanent residents medically determined to have a permanent disability that severely limits one or more major life activities. Free entrance for the pass holder and occupants of a single, private, non-commercial vehicle OR the pass holder and three persons (16 or older) where per person fees are charged. Disability documentation is required.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Access Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Passenger vehicles can drive north of Silver City, New Mexico to the monument on NM Hwy 15. The 46 mile trip can take up to two hours due to the narrow and mountainous curving nature of the road. Large RVs and vehicles pulling trailers should NOT use NM Hwy 15. From Silver City, take US Highway 180 to Santa Clara. Turn left onto NM Hwy 152 and drive to San Lorenzo. At San Lorenzo, turn left onto NM Hwy 35 and follow it to its termination at NM Hwy 15. Turn right on NM Hwy 15 and follow signs to the park.

operatingHours.description: The National Monument and Visitor Center are open all year and are closed only for Thanksgiving Day (the 4th Thursday of November), Christmas Day (December 25) and New Year's Day (January 1).
operatingHours.name: Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument

images.title: Looking Back in Time
images.altText: View of Mogollon dwelling rooms within a cave.
images.caption: Tularosa Phase Mogollon people made these caves their home in the late 1200's.

images.title: Winter Solstice Sunrise at Gila Cliff Dwellings
images.altText: Sunrise view of Gila Cliff Dwellings with brilliant sky.
images.caption: Visitors enjoy panoramic views of the canyon and dwellings at Gila Cliff Dwellings.

images.title: A Place to Call Home
images.altText: Cliff Dwellings walls and rooms with narrow catwalk
images.caption: Most of the dwellings walls are original. Some even preserve a builder's fingerprints that are over 700 years old.

images.title: Mogollon Cliff Dwelling with T Door
images.altText: Exterior view of Mogollon Cliff Dwelling
images.caption: The T-shaped door suggests trade between Mogollon and Ancestral Puebloan.

images.title: View of the Gila River Valley near Gila Cliff Dwellings NM
images.altText: Distant view of Gila river valley and mountains beyond.
images.caption: The Oldest Wilderness Area in the United States Awaits.

images.title: Gila National Forest Approach to Gila National Monument in Winter
images.altText: Light snowfall on red rock cliffs along river.
images.caption: Winter wonderland along the Gila River

images.title: Eroded Cliffs Along the Gila River
images.altText: Eroded cliffs reflecting off a river
images.caption: As the first designated Wilderness Area, the Gila offers endless opportunites peaceful reflection.

parks.weatherInfo: Weather is extremely variable. Summers are usually in the 90s F but approach 100° F. Winters have occasional snow or temperatures near 0° F. Thunderstorms are common in the summer and early fall, usually in the afternoon. Thunderstorms and lightning may cause temporary closures of the monument.
parks.name: Gila Cliff Dwellings

parks.description: Covering 3.3 million acres of rugged mountains, dynamic glaciers, temperate rainforest, wild coastlines and deep sheltered fjords, Glacier Bay National Park is a highlight of Alaska's Inside Passage and part of a 25-million acre World Heritage Site—one of the world’s largest international protected areas. From sea to summit, Glacier Bay offers limitless opportunities for adventure and inspiration.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to enter Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve lies west of Juneau, Alaska, and can only be reached by plane or boat. The only road in the area merely connects the small town of Gustavus and its airfield to park headquarters at Bartlett Cove (10 miles). Alaska Airlines provides daily jet service from Juneau to Gustavus in the summer months. Year-round scheduled air service is also provided by a variety of small air taxis and charters. The Alaska Marine Highway ferries also provide regular service from Juneau.

operatingHours.description:
There are no entrance gates at Glacier Bay National Park, so we are technically open 24-hours a day; however,  services may be extremely limited depending on the time of your visit.
The main visitor season is from late-May through early-September with the peak being the month of July. Check below to see hours for specific facilities, and read the exceptions that detail seasonal changes in hours.
Park Headquarters is open year round M-F 8:00 AM to 4:30 PM.
operatingHours.name: Glacier Bay Operating Hours and Seasons

images.title: Cruising Glacier Bay
images.altText: Cruising Glacier Bay
images.caption: Passengers line the deck to enjoy the icy scene at Margerie Glacier

images.title: Iceberg on the shore
images.altText: Icebergs, calved from tidewater glaciers are a common sight in Glacier Bay National Park.
images.caption: Icebergs, calved from tidewater glaciers are a common sight in Glacier Bay National Park.

images.title: Pan ice in Tarr Inlet
images.altText: Pan ice in Tarr Inlet
images.caption: Glacier Bay offers a rare glimpse into the Ice Age

images.title: Beachcombing Brown Bear
images.altText: Beachcombing Brown Bear
images.caption: Brown bears frequently forage along the shoreline of Glacier Bay

images.title: Sheltered waters of Glacier Bay
images.altText: Sheltered waters of Glacier Bay
images.caption: Glacier Bay is a paradise for wilderness aficionados.

images.title: Camping in the Glacier Bay backcountry
images.altText: Camping in the Glacier Bay backcountry
images.caption: Glacier Bay provides endless possibilities for wilderness camping.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer temperatures average 50° to 60° F (10° to 15° C). Rain is the norm in lush southeast Alaska. It is best to be prepared to enjoy the park in any kind of weather, especially rain. Suggested clothing includes waterproof boots, rain gear, a hat, gloves, wool or pile layers or a warm coat. Good rain gear is essential here. April, May and June are usually the driest months of the year. September and October tend to be the wettest.
parks.name: Glacier Bay

parks.description: Come and experience Glacier's pristine forests, alpine meadows, rugged mountains, and spectacular lakes. With over 700 miles of trails, Glacier is a hiker's paradise for adventurous visitors seeking wilderness and solitude. Relive the days of old through historic chalets, lodges, and the famous Going-to-the-Sun Road. Explore Glacier National Park and discover what awaits you.

entranceFees.description: This is a entrance fee for all persons traveling in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van). The permit is non-transferable. Visitors can enter the park at any time, if the entrance station is not staffed, a self-registration area is available for purchasing a 7-day park permit.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee by car - 7 day permit

entranceFees.description: This is a per person entrance fee for a visitor traveling on foot, bicycle, or for individuals traveling together in a vehicle as a non-commercial, organized group. The permit is non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee by single entry

entranceFees.description: This is a per motorcycle entrance fee. The permit is non-transferable.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee by motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Glacier National Park is instituting an online reservation system (ticketed entry) for the Going-to-the-Sun Road corridor between the park’s West and St. Mary Entrances from May 28 to September 6, 2021.
entranceFees.title: Going-to-the-Sun Road Entry Reservation Ticket

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for one year from the month of entry and admits the purchaser and passengers in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or the pass holder and his/her immediate family (spouse, children, parents) when entry is by other means (foot, bicycle) into the park. It is nontransferable, nonrefundable, and does not cover camping fees.
entrancePasses.title: Glacier National Park Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Glacier National Park is located in the northwest corner of Montana along the spine of the Rocky Mountains. By Car you can access Glacier via Highway 2, which runs along the southern boundary of the park. You can reach the east side of the park via Highway 89. The nearest airports are in Kalispell and Great Falls, Montana

operatingHours.description: Glacier National Park is open 24 hours a day 365 days of the year. An entrance fee is required, even when the entrance stations are not staffed. Instructions are available at each entrance for self-payment.
operatingHours.name: Glacier National Park

images.title: Flowers along Going-to-the-Sun Road
images.altText: A bright landscape image with steep peaks in the background and bright flowers in the foreground.
images.caption: Fireweed are common along Going-to-the-Sun Road in late summer.

images.title: Logan Pass at Sunset
images.altText: A shadow stretches across a sprawling alpine meadow under a perfectly clear sky.
images.caption: Logan Pass is one of the most beautiful, and busy, destinations in the park.

images.title: St. Mary Falls
images.altText: A double waterfall blurs over layered rocks.
images.caption: Glacier National Park is sculpted by water.

images.title: Lobby of the Lake McDonald Lodge
images.altText: Looking down into the lobby of the Lake McDonald Lodge from the balcony
images.caption: Lobby of the historic Lake McDonald Lodge

images.title: East Side Sunset
images.altText: Jagged peaks rise out of a forested valley and an empty road curves off into the distance.
images.caption: Going-to-the-Sun Road in the St. Mary Valley

images.title: Going-to-the-Sun Road Morning
images.altText: Large mountains rise into morning clouds with green flanks leading down to a field of purple flowers
images.caption: Flowers grow thick along Going-to-the-Sun Road.

images.title: St. Mary Falls
images.altText: A double waterfall blurs over layered rocks.
images.caption: Glacier National Park is sculpted by water.

images.title: Mountains Beyond Lake McDonald
images.altText: January snows blanket Glacier's rugged winter landscape under cloudy skies at sunset.
images.caption: Winter in Glacier is a little quieter than summer.

parks.weatherInfo: Glacier's weather is highly variable and can be extreme. Expect warm sunny summer days and in the winter the temperatures can fall well below freezing. Glacier's geography, straddling the Continental Divide, sets the stage for clashes of two very different climates. Warm, wet Pacific air moves in from the west, and cold dry Arctic air from the northeast. They meet at the Divide.
parks.name: Glacier

parks.description: Encompassing over 1.25 million acres, Glen Canyon National Recreation Area offers unparalleled opportunities for water-based & backcountry recreation. The recreation area stretches for hundreds of miles from Lees Ferry in Arizona to the Orange Cliffs of southern Utah, encompassing scenic vistas, geologic wonders, and a vast panorama of human history.

emailAddresses.description:
Glen Canyon Information.
This inbox is checked weekly.

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle and all its passengers
entranceFees.title: 1-7 Day Vehicle Entrance

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial motorcycle and its riders.
entranceFees.title: 1-7 Day Motorcycle Entrance

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual when entering on foot or bicycle. Individuals 15 years of age and younger are admitted free.
entranceFees.title: 1-7 Day Individual Entrance

entranceFees.description: Admits one single private vessel. If a Senior Pass is presented at time of purchase, the boat entrance fee is $15.00 and good for 1-7 Days.
entranceFees.title: 1-7 Day Boating Entrance

entranceFees.description: Admits one single private vessel on the same trailer as a vessel paying full entry fees
entranceFees.title: 1-7 Day Boating Entrance additional vessel

entrancePasses.description: Allows unlimited entry to Glen Canyon for 12 months from date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Glen Canyon National Recreation Area Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Allows unlimited entry to Glen Canyon for one vessel for one calendar year. If a Senior Pass is presented at time of purchase, the annual vessel sticker fee is $25.
entrancePasses.title: Glen Canyon National Recreation Area Annual Vessel Sticker

parks.directionsInfo: There are multiple districts in Glen Canyon very far away from each other. Avoid a two hundred mile detour and make sure you know which district you are going to before you begin travelling here.

operatingHours.description: Glen Canyon National Recreation Area is open 24 hours per day, year-round. If there is not a person manning the entrance station, you may pay your entrance fee at the automated booth. Launch ramps are open all day, unless closed due to low water.
operatingHours.name: Glen Canyon Open Hours

exceptions.name: Dangling Rope Marina closed in winter

operatingHours.description: Dangling Rope Marina closes mid-November until March 1 every year.
operatingHours.name: Dangling Rope Marina

operatingHours.description: Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and Rainbow Bridge National Monument Headquarters, located in Page, Arizona. This building is only partially open to the public, but sells passes year-round. Open weekdays 7am-4pm, closed weekends and Federal Holidays. Call 928-608-6200 for more information.
operatingHours.name: Park Headquarters

images.title: Enjoy Lake Powell
images.altText: Woman raises her arms while standing in front of a sandstone butte
images.caption: Spending time on Lake Powell near Tower Butte can make anyone excited.

images.title: Horseshoe Bend
images.altText: Green river winds through high cliffs.
images.caption: The Colorado River makes a 270 degree turn at Horseshoe Bend. Watch your step at the 1000 foot drop!

images.title: Glen Canyon Dam
images.altText: A concrete dam plugs high canyon walls. Buildings and wires on the sides.
images.caption: Glen Canyon Dam is the country's second largest gravity arch dam. Take a tour from the Carl Hayden Visitor Center.

images.title: So Many Ways to Find Your Park
images.altText: Three kayaks on the lake.
images.caption: If motorized recreation isn't your thing, take a kayak and paddle through the high side canyons of Lake Powell.

images.title: Lonely Dell Ranch at Lees Ferry Historic District
images.altText: Log cabin and fences with a wooden wagon.
images.caption: Glen Canyon isn't just houseboats and wakeboards. Come down to Lees Ferry Historic District to relive pioneer times when crossing the river was a major undertaking.

parks.weatherInfo: The weather in Glen Canyon National Recreation Area is usually typical for the high deserts. Summers are extremely hot with little, if any, shade. Winters are moderately cold with night time lows often below freezing. Spring weather is highly variable and unpredictable with extended periods of winds. Fall weather is usually nice and mild, a great time to beat the heat (and the crowds!).
parks.name: Glen Canyon

parks.description: Glen Echo Park began in 1891 as a National Chautauqua Assembly "to promote liberal and practical education." By 1911, it transformed into DC's premier amusement park until it closed in 1968. Since 1971, the National Park Service has owned and operated the site and today, with the help of the Glen Echo Park Partnership for Arts and Culture, offers year-round cultural and recreational activities.

entranceFees.description: No entrance, no parking fee for the grounds, some activities, classes, dances, shows, Carousel rides will have fees for those activities or events.
entranceFees.title: Glen Echo Park Entrance fee

entrancePasses.description: no entrance pass, no entrance fee
entrancePasses.title: no entrance pass, no entrance fee

parks.directionsInfo: By Car: Capital Beltway (I-495), Maryland outer loop exit 40 Cabin John Parkway to Clara Barton Parkway; Virginia inner loop exit 41 Clara Barton Parkway East; follow Clara Barton Parkway to MacArthur Boulevard and Glen Echo exit, left onto MacArthur Boulevard, straight across traffic circle at Goldsboro Road, next left onto Oxford Road, end of street, parking lots on the left. By Metro: Red Line to Bethesda or Friendship Heights Station, transfer to Montgomery County Ride-On Bus # 29, Glen Echo stop.

operatingHours.description: The grounds of Glen Echo Park are open daily from 6 a.m. to 1 a.m. (the next day).  No overnight parking.
operatingHours.name: Glen Echo Park Grounds and Parking Lot

images.title: Busy Day outside Carousel
images.altText: groups of families, adults and children strolling in Glen Echo Park near Carousel Building
images.caption: Glen Echo Park and the Dentzel Carousel are enjoyed by children and adults.

images.title: Dancing in the Bumper Car Pavilion
images.altText: outdoor scene of open dance pavilion illuminated and evening dance crowd inside.
images.caption: Evening Dance in the Bumper Car Pavilion

images.title: Labor Day Art Show in Spanish Ballroom
images.altText: people walking around large room during art show
images.caption: Visitors enjoy the Labor Day Art Show which highlights pieces created by students from the Glen Echo Park art programs.

images.title: Glen Echo Park Junior Rangers working on booklet.
images.altText: three children seated at a picnic table working on a Glen Echo Park Junior Ranger Booklet.
images.caption: Completing the Glen Echo Park Junior Ranger Booklet to earn the Junior Ranger Badge.

images.title: Glen Echo Picnic area
images.altText: people gathered at picnic tables enjoying a lunch in Glen Echo Park
images.caption: Glen Echo Park has a large picnic area with many tables, restrooms and a playground.

parks.weatherInfo: Weather for Washington, D.C. and Bethesda, Maryland areas.
parks.name: Glen Echo

parks.fullName: Gloria Dei Church National Historic Site
parks.description: Before Pennsylvania there was New Sweden. Discover this last historic link to a forgotten past. Visit the church's pastoral surroundings and its burial ground of patriots and ordinary citizens alike.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter the site, and reservations are not required. However, you may wish to confirm visiting hours prior to your arrival by contacting the rector at 215-389-1513.
entranceFees.title: Gloria Dei Church fee

parks.directionsInfo: The Gloria Dei Church is accessed from Christian Street in South Philadelphia. As in any city, use your street smarts and do not leave any valuables visible in your car. Several SEPTA bus routes serve the vicinity of the site. Visit the website for more information.

operatingHours.description: Gloria Dei is an active religious congregation, and home to the parish minister.  The church building is open Tuesday through Sunday from 9am to 4pm.  Services are held on Sundays at 10am.  The churchyard and grounds are open daily from sunup to sundown.
operatingHours.name: Gloria Dei Church hours

images.title: Steeple of the Gloira Dei Church
images.altText: A color photo of the Gloria Dei Church steeple during a sunset in Philadelphia.
images.caption: The church building at Gloria Dei 'Old Swedes' has been in use since 1700, making it the oldest church building in Pennsylvania and the second oldest in the United States.  The steeple was completed in 1703.

images.title: Gloria Dei Chuch yard
images.altText: A color photo of the Gloria Dei Church yard showing tombstones with the church in the background.
images.caption: Gloria Dei Church was designated as a National Historical Site in 1942. The Gloria Dei congregation owns and maintains the church and the related buildings, its ministry and the grounds.

images.title: Interior of the Gloria Dei Church
images.altText: A color photo of the interior of Gloria Dei Church showing the pulpit and a stained glass window.
images.caption: Situated above the pulpit is the only stained glass window in the church building.  Created in the mid 1800s, the window is the earliest example of American stained glass among the 3600 windows in the Philadelphia region.

images.title: Model of a ship hanging inside Gloria Dei Church
images.altText: A color photo of a model tall ship hanging inside Gloria Die Church.
images.caption: Hanging from the ceiling of Gloria Dei are models of the two ships that brought the first Swedish colonists to North America in 1638, the "Kalmar Nyckel" and the "Fogel Gryp."

images.title: The Gloria Dei Church c.1850
images.altText: A 19th century photograph of the Gloria Dei Church, with the cemetery in the foreground.
images.caption: This 1850s photograph shows a bird's-eye view of the Gloria Dei Church, with the cemetery in the foreground and the masts of ships visible in the background.

parks.weatherInfo: Summers are typically hot and muggy, fall and spring are generally mild, and winter is cold. Snowfall is highly variable, with some winters bringing only light snow and others bringing several major snowstorms, with the normal seasonal snowfall standing at 22.4 in (57 cm). Precipitation is generally spread throughout the year, with eight to twelve wet days per month.
parks.name: Gloria Dei Church

parks.description: Experience a park so rich it supports 19 distinct ecosystems with over 2,000 plant and animal species. Go for a hike, enjoy a vista, have a picnic or learn about the centuries of overlapping history from California’s indigenous cultures, Spanish colonialism, the Mexican Republic, US military expansion and the growth of San Francisco. All of this and more awaits you, so get out and find your park.

entranceFees.description: With the exception of the entrance fee for Muir Woods National Monument and the cost of the ferry to visit Alcatraz Island, there is no fee to visit lands of Golden Gate National Recreation Area.
entranceFees.title: Visiting Golden Gate is free except for Alcatraz Island and Muir Woods National Monument.

parks.directionsInfo: Golden Gate National Recreation Area has many sites that span over 60 miles of mostly coastal areas north and south of San Francisco. Park areas can be reached by Highways 1, 101 and 280 from the north and south San Francisco Bay Area, and by Highway 80 from the East Bay. To access park headquarters at Fort Mason, please use the entrance at Franklin and Bay Streets in San Francisco.

operatingHours.description: Although this urban park is accessible 24 hours a day in most areas, most parking lots are open between sunrise to sunset.
operatingHours.name: Parking Lots

operatingHours.description:
These areas are open from 6 a.m. until 1 hour after sunset.


Marin County: 
- Conzelman Rd (west, between traffic circle and Field Rd.)
- Kirby Cove (except registered campers with permits)
- Muir Beach
- Muir Beach Overlook
- Stinson Beach


San Francisco County
- Fort Point (north of the gate and adjacent areas)
- China Beach
- Fort Mason – Black Point Stairway to Van Ness Ave.
- Lands End
- Sutro Heights Park
operatingHours.name: Day Use Areas

operatingHours.description:
Muir Woods National Monument is open daily with hours varying throughout the year. Please check the Muir Woods National Monument park website for the most current, up to date information. 

In accordance with CDC, state, and local public health guidance related to COVID-19, these hours and availability of programs may vary.
operatingHours.name: Muir Woods National Monument

operatingHours.description:
The Point Bonita Lighthouse is open Sundays and Mondays between 12:30 pm and 3:30pm unless otherwise noted. 

In accordance with CDC, state, and local public health guidance related to COVID-19, these hours may vary.
operatingHours.name: Point Bonita Lighthouse (beyond the tunnel)

operatingHours.description: The Nike Missile Site in the Marin Headlands is open Fridays and Saturdays from 12:30 to 3:30 pm for demonstrations and programs, unless otherwise posted.
operatingHours.name: Nike Missile Site

operatingHours.description: On the first Saturday of the month Battery Townsley is open between 1:00pm to 4:00pm for demonstrations and programs.
operatingHours.name: Battery Townsley

operatingHours.description:
Fort Point National Historic Site is open Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays from 10:00 am to 5:00 pm unless otherwise noted. 

In accordance with CDC, state, and local public health guidance related to COVID-19, these hours and availability of programs may vary.
operatingHours.name: Fort Point National Historic Site

images.title: Morning Fog at Crissy Field
images.altText: White buildings with red roofs at Crissy Field with blue bay and Golden Gate Bridge and fog behind.
images.caption: Visiting Crissy Field is an ever changing experience as the fog comes in and dissipates.

images.title: Spring Flowers at Mori Point
images.altText: Mori Point view north with yellow an blue flowers, the blue-green Pacific Ocean and Mt. Tamalpais.
images.caption: View north from Mori Point showing abundant spring flowers and Mt. Tamalpais in the background.

images.title: Stinson Beach from Bolinas Ridge
images.altText: View over the Pacific from Bolinas Ridge; Stinson Beach, Bolinas Lagoon and head in mid-ground.
images.caption: Bolinas Ridge offers outstanding panaramas of the Pacific Coast, here including Stinson Beach and Lagoon.

images.title: Storm over the Golden Gate
images.altText: Orange Golden Gate Bridge with waves crashing in foreground and storm clouds behind.
images.caption: The Golden Gate Bridge is an iconic attraction year-round.

images.title: Marin Headlands and Rodeo Beach
images.altText: View south with family on road in foreground and Rodeo Beach and cove in front of Point Bonita.
images.caption: Trails in the Marin Headlands offer a fun and spectacular hiking experience for all.

images.title: Montgomery Street Barracks, Presidio of San Francisco
images.altText: Row of red brick barracks with white-columned porches where infantry soldiers lived.
images.caption: The Presidio offers an outdoor museum of military architecture over the centuries.

images.title: Alcatraz Island from Crissy Field
images.altText: Closeup shot of Alcatraz Island showing lighthouse and prison with yellow flowers on slope in front.
images.caption: Visitors can learn about the complex layered history of Alcatraz Island.

parks.weatherInfo: Winter is characterized by sporadic rain and cool weather punctuated by brilliant sunshine. In winter the grass greens. Trees and flowers dormant through winter start blooming in late February or early March and last until May or June. By July, summer fog predominates in most coastal areas of the park. Grasses and plants have now turned to the golden brown and muted grays characteristic of California summer and fall. September and October skies are clear and sunshine is abundant everywhere in the park.
parks.name: Golden Gate

parks.description: One of the greatest technological achievements of the 19th century, the completion of the first transcontinental railroad across the United States. Visitors to the park can see the location of the Last Spike Site, 1869 railroad construction features, walk or drive on the original railroad grade, and get an up close view of Victorian era replica locomotives.

entranceFees.description:
The per vehicle fee covers all occupants in a single private vehicle. The fee will allow visitors access to all resources to the public; including auto tours, walking trails, films, exhibit area, ranger guided programs, other seasonal activities. 

If visitors have any of the America the Beautiful Inter-agency passes, these will cover the pass holder and anyone that is in their personal vehicle. 

During the warmer summer season usually all of the resources are available. Check with our staff for times
entranceFees.title: Golden Spike Private Vehicle Fee

entranceFees.description:
The motorcycle fee admits the driver and one passenger. The fee will allow visitors access to all resources to the public; including auto tours, walking trails, films, exhibit area, ranger guided programs, other seasonal activities. 

If visitors have any of the America the Beautiful Inter-agency passes, these will cover the pass holder and anyone that is in their personal vehicle. 

During the colder winter season the per vehicle fee is reduced and some activities may be unavailable.
entranceFees.title: Golden Spike Motorcycle Fee

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car. This pass is typically used for bicyclists, and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free.
entranceFees.title: Per Person Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description:
This is an annual pass that covers entrance fees at Golden Spike National Historical Park for the pass holder and occupants within a single noncommercial vehicle OR the pass holder and three persons (16 and older) where per person fees apply. This pass is available to anyone 16 or older.

The Agencies are NOT responsible for misplaced, lost or stolen cards. 

The pass can be signed by two pass holders.
entrancePasses.title: Golden Spike National Historical Park Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Golden Spike National Historical Park is 32 miles west of Brigham City, Utah. Travelers on I-15: use exit 365 and drive west on Utah 13 and 83 through Corinne (follow brown directional signs) to Golden Spike Drive. Turn left and follow signs to the visitor center (8 miles). Southbound travelers on I-84: use Howell exit 26 and drive south on Utah 83 (follow brown directional signs) to Golden Spike Drive. Turn right and follow signs to the visitor center (8 miles). Lat/Long 41.617410,-112.550986

operatingHours.description:
The park is open year around, seven days a week. The Visitor Center is open year around with the exception of Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, and New Years Day. 

Seasonal closures of Visitor Center may occur due to weather events, seasonal operations adjustments and  unforeseen circumstances.
operatingHours.name: Standard Visitor Center Operating Hours

images.title: Winter View from Big Fill Trail
images.altText: Sunny Winter View from the Big Fill Trail
images.caption: Winter View from Big Fill Trail

images.title: Golden Spike Park Entrance Sign
images.altText: Winter View of Golden Spike Entrance Sign
images.caption: Winter View of Golden Spike Entrance Sign

images.title: Golden Spike National Historical Park Visitor Center
images.altText: The Flag flies over Golden Spike National Historical Park's Visitor Center, with trees and monument
images.caption: Golden Spike's Visitor Center is the best the best place to start your exploration of this unique piece of American History.

images.title: The Golden Spike
images.altText: An exact replica of the Golden Spike
images.caption: The original solid gold spike was only on site for the ceremony for a brief moment, but the symbolism of the engineering feat lives on

images.title: The Big Fill
images.altText: The Big Fill is a 400 foot long 80 foot high mound of packed earth that bridged a ravine
images.caption: Visitors can explore fifteen miles of the historic grade that was prepared for track by the two railroad companies

images.title: Replica Locomotives Jupiter and #119
images.altText: Two replica victorian age steam locomotives face each other on the original railroad grade
images.caption: Connect with the history by viewing the site's replica steam locomotives in action

images.title: View of Replica Locomotives Jupiter and 119 at the Last Spike Site
images.altText: Sunset view of locomotives Jupiter and 119 at the Last Spike Site
images.caption: View of Replica Locomotives at the Last Spike Site

parks.weatherInfo: Golden Spike National Historical Park is located in a high desert environment in the Promontory Mountains near the north end of the Great Salt Lake. The temperatures can reach over 100 degrees in the summer and dip into single digits in the winter, with much of the park blanketed in snow. Visitors are recommended to check forecasts before coming to our site and come prepared for changing weather conditions.
parks.name: Golden Spike

parks.description: From 1794 to 1966, the U.S. Army on Governors Island was part of the social, political, and economic tapestry of New York City. Today, the island is a vibrant summer seasonal venue of art, culture, and performance against the backdrop of two centuries of military heritage and the skyline of one of the great cities of the world. The island is open to the public, May 1st thru Oct 31st

entranceFees.description: Governors Island National Monument does not charge an entrance fee. The Trust for Governors Island does charge a $2 fee to ride the ferry. Seniors pay $1 and children are free. All ferries before Noon on weekends are free.
entranceFees.title: No park entrance fees

parks.directionsInfo: Governors Island is located in New York Harbor, 1/2 mile from the southern tip of Lower Manhattan and 400 yards west of the end of Brooklyn's Atlantic Avenue and Red Hook waterfront. It is accessible only via ferry. Ferry service from Manhattan is the main way to access the island. During the summer public access season, the ferry departs from Battery Maritime Building at 10 South Street, at South and Whitehall Streets (next to the Staten Island ferry terminal). Check www.govisland.com for ferry schedules.

operatingHours.description: Governors Island is open to the public on a summer seasonal basis. The 2018 public access season extends until October 31, 2018. Hours reflect access to the inside areas of Fort Jay and Castle Williams. Outside access is 1-2 hours after our facilities close. Visit https://govisland.com/visit-the-island/ferry for the latest schedule for access to Governors Island outdoor areas.
operatingHours.name: Governors Island Outdoor Areas

operatingHours.description: The inner courtyard and exhibit rooms are open to the public 7 days a week. Upper Levels and roof are accessible only by ranger guided tours (11:30 am, 1:30 pm, 3:30 pm) daily.
operatingHours.name: Castle Williams

operatingHours.description: The inner court yard displays, magazine, ravelin, and officer barracks porches, are open for your exploration 7 days a week. Tours available Saturday and Sunday 12:00 PM and 2:00 PM.
operatingHours.name: Fort Jay

images.title: Fort Jay gate house and moat.
images.altText: Bridge over dry moat leading into a gated fort.
images.caption: An early spring morning view of Fort Jay. The gate house is the oldest structure on Governors Island dating back to 1794.

images.title: Castle Williams at Governors Island National Monument
images.altText: Front of sandstone brick fort with arched entrance way.
images.caption: Castle Williams at Governors Island National Monument was constructed in 1811 and was a pioneering design in American fortifications.

images.title: Ranger guided tour of Castle Williams at Governors Island National Monument
images.altText: A park ranger talking to a group of visitors inside a large stone room in a fort.
images.caption: Ranger-led tours of Castle Williams show the pioneering features of fortification architecture that would be used in other masonry forts constructed in the 1800s.

images.title: Manhattan from Fort Jay
images.altText: Manhattan Skyline stands behind the barracks of Fort Jay
images.caption: History frames our understanding of the present

images.title: Manhattan from Castle Williams
images.altText: Canon and Manhattan Skyline from top of castle
images.caption: A civil war era canon sitting upon the top of Castle Williams juxtaposes the new and old, with the glimering shine of Manhattan in the background

parks.weatherInfo: During the summer public access season from May to September, the weather is typical of the mid-Atlantic region. Thunderstorms can come quickly with short downpours. There may be extended periods of heat or humidity that might last a week or more. The island is generally a few degrees cooler than the city due to the fairly constant breeze.
parks.name: Governors Island

parks.description: Located in Arizona, Grand Canyon National Park encompasses 277 miles (446 km) of the Colorado River and adjacent uplands. The park is home to much of the immense Grand Canyon; a mile (1.6 km) deep, and up to 18 miles (29 km) wide. Layered bands of colorful rock reveal millions of years of geologic history. Grand Canyon is unmatched in the vistas it offers visitors from the rim. Open 24 hours.

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle and all its passengers. Organized groups are not eligible for the vehicle permit.
entranceFees.title: Grand Canyon National Park Vehicle Permit

entranceFees.description: Admits one single, private, non-commercial motorcycle and its passenger(s).
entranceFees.title: Grand Canyon National Park Motorcycle Permit

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual when entering by foot, bicycle, park shuttle bus, Grand Canyon Railway and private rafting trip. Individuals 15 years old and younger are admitted free of charge.
entranceFees.title: Grand Canyon National Park Individual Permit

entrancePasses.description: Valid for twelve months from the date of purchase, for unlimited visits to Grand Canyon National Park. It admits the purchaser and any accompanying persons in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or the purchaser and accompanying immediate family (spouse, children, parents) when entry is by other means (train, shuttle, bicycle, and foot).
entrancePasses.title: Grand Canyon National Park Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: South Rim: Open all year, is located 60 miles north of Williams, Arizona (via route 64 from Interstate 40) and 80 miles northwest of Flagstaff (via route 180). Grand Canyon lies entirely within the state of Arizona. North Rim: Closed for the Winter between December 1 and May 15. The North Rim is located 30 miles south of Jacob Lake on Highway 67; the actual rim of the canyon is an additional 14 miles south. Jacob Lake, AZ is located in northern Arizona on Highway 89A, not far from the Utah border.

operatingHours.description:
South Rim Grand Canyon Village Area is open with some visitor services and overnight accommodations.
Note: State Route 64, (Desert View Drive), is open a distance of 25 miles (40 km) from Grand Canyon Village to Desert View. There is a turnaround at Desert View. The East Entrance to the park at Desert View remains CLOSED. You must use the South Entrance near the town of Tusayan to enter and exit the park.
operatingHours.name: South Rim

operatingHours.description: The North Rim has a short season. Facilities and lodging are usually open May 15 through October 15, each year. Lodging and Camping Reservations are strongly recommended. The North Rim is over 8000 feet/2438 m. in elevation. Individuals with respiratory or heart problems may experience difficulties. Walking at this elevation can be strenuous. The North Rim is closed to all vehicles between December 1st and May 15th, and no visitor services are available.
operatingHours.name: North Rim

operatingHours.description: Beginning April 8, 2021, visitors traveling to Grand Canyon National Park will be able to enter the park through the East Entrance at Desert View. The East Entrance is reached by traveling on SR 64, via Cameron, Arizona, Note: at this time, visitor services are not available at Desert View, The general store, food services, gas station, and the campground are closed. The nearest services are in Grand Canyon Village, 25 miles (40 km) to the west.. Desert View services will open as soon as staffing allows.
operatingHours.name: Desert View - East Entrance

images.title: Grand Canyon Mather Point Sunset on the South Rim
images.altText: The canyon glows orange as people visit Mather Point, a rock outcropping that juts into Grand Canyon
images.caption: People come from all over the world to view Grand Canyon's sunset

images.title: Grand Canyon National Park: View from Cape Royal on the North Rim
images.altText: The Cape Royal viewpoint curves into the distance and closer rock formations jut into the canyon.
images.caption: A popular outdoor site for weddings and receptions, Cape Royal Amphitheater is located 23 miles (37 km) from the North Rim developed area.

images.title: Grand Canyon National Park: Desert View Watchtower (South Rim)
images.altText: The Desert View Watchtower looms 70 feet into the air over a vast and dramatic view of the canyon.
images.caption: The Watchtower is located at Desert View, the eastern-most developed area on the South Rim of Grand Canyon National Park.

images.title: Looking down the Colorado River from Nankoweap at river mile 53
images.altText: Tall canyon walls frame the wide Colorado river weaving back and forth.
images.caption: A view down the Colorado river from Nankoweap in Marble canyon.

parks.weatherInfo: This weather varies with cold winters and mild pleasant summers, moderate humidity, and considerable diurnal temperature changes at the higher elevations, with hot and drier summers at the bottom of the Grand Canyon along with cool damp winters. Summer thunderstorms and winter snowfall adds to the weather variety in this region.
parks.name: Grand Canyon

parks.description: Take a lonely and rocky two-track road in a 4x4 to the edge of the Grand Wash Cliffs. Find a stunning solitary vista deep into the Grand Canyon. Relax in the shade of ponderosas at Mt. Trumbull. Touch ancient waters at Pakoon Springs in one of the driest places in the world. Parashant is remote. There are no crowds here. Be equipped to leave pavement, cell service, and the 21st century behind.

emailAddresses.description: General questions

entranceFees.description:
No entrance fees or permits are required for general public activities except for winter access to the Kelly Point Road. 

Permits are required for commercial activities, either a Commercial Use Authorization on NPS lands or a Special Recreation Permit on BLM lands. Other activities such as hunting licenses and ORV vehicle licensing are subject to Arizona state regulations.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

entrancePasses.description: No permits or fees are required for general visitor activities. Visits to this monument require special planning and awareness of potential hazards such as unmarked rugged roads, venomous animals, extreme heat, and flash floods. Bring plenty of water, food, extra gasoline and at least two spare tires. High clearance vehicles are recommended.
entrancePasses.title: Passes

parks.directionsInfo: The monument is located in the northwest corner of Arizona, bordering Nevada to the west and near the southern border of Utah. There are no paved roads or visitor services within the monument's million-plus acres. Visitors should be prepared for travel on rugged dirt roads. Traveling with an appropriate high clearance vehicle equipped with all-terrain tires. The spare tire should also be all-terrain rated. The monument has entry roads from Nevada, Utah and Arizona.

operatingHours.description: The monument is open 24 hours a day 365 days of the year. There are no facilities or visitor contact areas within the monument boundaries.
operatingHours.name: Operating Hours & Seasons

images.title: Hudson Point
images.altText: Near a cliff edge the sun sets in the distance.
images.caption: The sun sets behind the Pakoon Basin.

images.title: Driving the sage flat
images.altText: A UTV drives down a road surrounded on both sides by sage
images.caption: Visitors enjoy exploring the roads on the monument.

images.title: Camping sunset
images.altText: The sun sets behind a grove of ponderosa trees lighting up an orange tent with a warm glow
images.caption: Campsites on the monument are primitive as there is no designated campground.

images.title: Waring Ranch
images.altText: Looking across a long narrow stockpond. Green grass slopes towards the water.
images.caption: Areas such as Waring Ranch give a glimpse into ranching operations in the early and mid-20th century

images.title: Fall sunset
images.altText: The setting sun sits above trees and shrubs adorned with hues of orange, red and green.
images.caption: Sunrise and sunsets hallmark the vast landscapes of the monument.

parks.weatherInfo: Parashant is split between low elevation Mojave Desert on the west side and high elevation pinyon/juniper/ponderosa highlands on the east side. Expect sun on average 310 days per year. The summer months of June through September are very hot on the west side with highs above 100°F daily (80°F+ at night) below 2,500 feet. The high elevation east side is ~15°F cooler. Expect heavy afternoon monsoon storms June - September. Roads often stay muddy/icy above 5,500 feet December - February.
parks.name: Grand Canyon-Parashant

parks.description: Travel into the past to discover the present. Explore the partnership of the Grand Portage Ojibwe and the North West Company during the North American fur trade and the NPS today. Follow pathways into a distant time. Experience the sights and smells of a bustling depot reconstructed in its exact location. Hear the beat of the drum echo over Gichigami - Lake Superior.

entranceFees.description:
Grand Portage National Monument is fee free.  This includes visiting the heritage (visitor) center and the historic depot (great hall, kitchen, canoe warehouse, gatehouse, stockade and picnic grounds.

Camping at Fort Charlotte requires a free camping reservation for the two back country campsites.  To preserve the campsites, no more than nine campers may occupy a campsite at one time.
entranceFees.title: Grand Portage National Monument is fee free.

parks.directionsInfo: Traveling northeast or southwest on MN Hwy 61 visitors will see signs alerting the approach to Grand Portage National Monument. A right turn exit lane or left turn from Hwy 61 at the Grand Portage Trading Post will take visitors onto Casino Road. Turn left at the first stop sign from Casino Road to Mile Creek Road. About 3/4 mile on Mile Creek Road, look for the large wooden entrance sign. Turn left up the short hill into the Heritage Center parking lot.

operatingHours.description: The Grand Portage National Monument grounds and trails are open from sunrise to sunset daily. Historic Depot is open from 9am-5pm daily from Memorial Day through late October. Heritage Center is open daily from 8:30am-4:30 pm daily except for holidays noted on Visitor's Center page.
operatingHours.name: Grand Portage National Monument

operatingHours.description: Historic reconstruction of the fur trade depot. Includes: Great Hall, Kitchen, Canoe Warehouse, Ojibwe Village, Voyageur Encampment and Three Sisters and Kitchen Historic Heirloom Gardens.
operatingHours.name: Historic Depot

images.title: Mount Rose Trail overlooks Historic Depot & Grand Portage Bay
images.altText: Stockade fence and log building overlooking Lake Superior
images.caption: Beautiful scenary welcomes Fall visitors to Grand Portage.

images.title: Ojibwe Village (Anishinaabe Odena)
images.altText: Birch bark lodges among trees.
images.caption: The Ojibwe Village is located in the Historic Depot

images.title: Seneca Sunflowers Canoe Warehouse
images.altText: Sunflowers blossoms in front of log building
images.caption: Colorful blossoms in the Three Sister's Garden

images.title: Historic Depot, Hat Point
images.altText: Three log buildings with Lake and point of land in background.
images.caption: Fall is a great time to hike the Mount Rose Trail

images.title: Historic Depot From Mount Rose
images.altText: Log buildings, stockade fence and dock near Lake.
images.caption: Fall is a great time to hike to the mount Rose overlook.

parks.weatherInfo: Short, warm summers and long, cold winters define the climate of northern Minnesota. Average range of summer temperature is from 55°F to 78°F in July and average range of winter temperatures is from –11°F to 12°F in January. Average annual precipitation in Grand Portage, MN is about 32 inches.
parks.name: Grand Portage

parks.description: Rising above a scene rich with extraordinary wildlife, pristine lakes, and alpine terrain, the Teton Range stands as a monument to the people who fought to protect it. These are mountains of the imagination. Mountains that led to the creation of Grand Teton National Park where you can explore over two hundred miles of trails, float the Snake River, and enjoy the serenity of this remarkable place.

entranceFees.description: Park entrance fee for 7 days for a private, non-commercial vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Grand Teton Entrance Fee - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Park entrance for 7 days per private motorcycle.
entranceFees.title: Grand Teton Entrance Fee - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Park entrance fee for 7 days for each visitor 16 years and older entering by foot, bicycle, ski, etc.
entranceFees.title: Grand Teton Entrance Fee - Hiker/Biker

entrancePasses.description: Pass is valid for one year through the month of purchase. Park Annual Pass provides entrance to pass holder and accompanying passengers in a single private non-commercial vehicle to Grand Teton National Park. Purchase your pass at one of Grand Teton's park entrances and permits desks at the Craig Thomas Discovery and Visitor Center and the Colter Bay Visitor Center.
entrancePasses.title: Grand Teton Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Grand Teton National Park is located in northwestern Wyoming; north of the town of Jackson, Wyoming and south of Yellowstone National Park. BY CAR: Salt Lake City, Utah is approximately 300 miles and about 5-6 hours from the park Denver, Colorado is approximately 550 miles and about 8-10 hours from the park BY AIR: Grand Teton National Park is unique in that it is the only national park that has a commercial airport within its border, Jackson Hole Airport (JAC).

operatingHours.description: Visitors may enter the park at any time, but visitor services and motor vehicle access vary throughout the year.
operatingHours.name: Grand Teton National Park

images.title: North Fork Cascade Canyon
images.altText: Backpackers in North Fork Cascade Canyon, Grand Teton behind
images.caption: Backpackers in North Fork Cascade Canyon approaching Paintbrush Divide.

images.title: Winter Sunrise on the Teton Range
images.altText: Winter sunrise on snow-covered Teton Range
images.caption: Winter sunrise on snow-covered Teton Range

images.title: Grizzly Bear
images.altText: Grizzly bear running through dry grass with shrubs behind
images.caption: Grizzly bears are found throughout Grand Teton National Park

images.title: Lake Solitude with the Cathedral Group
images.altText: Lake Solitude with the high Teton Peaks beyond during summer
images.caption: Lake Solitude is a favorite hiking destination in the park.

images.title: Oxbow Bend and Mount Moran
images.altText: Oxbow Bend on the Snake River during fall with golden aspens and Mount Moran in the background.
images.caption: Mount Moran at Oxbow Bend is a classic autumn view.

images.title: Visitors at the Snake River Overlook
images.altText: Mother in pink shirt, child in orange shirt, the Snake River below and the Teton Range beyond.
images.caption: The Snake River Overlook is a where Ansel Adams took his iconic image of the Teton Range.

images.title: John Moulton Barn at Mormon Row
images.altText: Historic Moulton Barn with visitors and the Teton Range beyond.
images.caption: Two Moulton brothers built adjacent icon barns on Mormon Row. John's barn is pictured. T.A., his brother, built a barn just to the south.

images.title: American Pika (Ochotona princeps)
images.altText: American Pika perched on a granite boulder
images.caption: American Pika live in rockfall areas.

images.title: Moose
images.altText: Bull moose with large antlers walking through fall grasses
images.caption: In the fall, bull moose antlers have lost their velvet readying for the rut.

images.title: Schwabacher Landing
images.altText: beaver pond at Schwabacher landing reflecting the Teton Range in early summer
images.caption: The beaver ponds near Schwabacher Landing can produce beautiful reflections of the Teton Range.

images.title: Arrowleaf Balsamroot
images.altText: yellow arrowleaf balsamroot blooms with Teewinot Peak towering beyond
images.caption: Arrowleaf Balsamroot is a bright splash of color during early summer.

parks.weatherInfo: Grand Teton National Park has long, cold winters—snow and frost are possible any month. April, May, & June - Mild days and cool nights alternate with rain and snow. July & August - Warm days and cool nights prevail, with afternoon thundershowers common. September, October, & November - Sunny days and cold nights alternate with rain and occasional snowstorms. December to April - Between storms the days are sunny and nights are frigid. Snow blankets the mountains and valley.
parks.name: Grand Teton

parks.description: Wide open spaces, the hard-working cowboy, his spirited cow pony, and vast herds of cattle are among the strongest symbols of the American West. Once the headquarters of a 10 million acre cattle empire, Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site preserves these symbols and commemorates the role of cattlemen in American history.

entranceFees.description: Grant-Kohrs Ranch is a fee-free site.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

parks.directionsInfo: Arriving from the east: Take Interstate 90, exit 187. Drive through town, approximately 2.5 miles. Turn left onto Grant Circle and enter the park. Arriving from the west: Take Interstate 90, exit 184. Turn right. Drive approximately 3/4 of a mile. Turn right on to Grant Circle and enter the park.

operatingHours.description: Hours for the main historic area of Grant-Kohrs Ranch, the Visitor Center and Interpretive Ranger programs.
operatingHours.name: Historic Area Operating Hours

images.title: The Ranch House
images.altText: A front view of the ranch house.
images.caption: The front portion of the ranch house was originally built by Canadian fur trader Johnny Grant in 1862.

images.title: The Ranch House
images.altText: A view of the rear of the ranch house.
images.caption: The rear portion of the ranch house was an addition put on by Conrad Kohrs in 1891.

images.title: Deer Lodge Mountain
images.altText: Deer Lodge Mountain rises up over the pastures of Grant-Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site.
images.caption: Deer Lodge Mountain, and the rest of the Flint Creek Range, directly influence the weather in the valley below.

images.title: Reveal
images.altText: Fenced green pasture in front, 3 ranch buildings across center, blue sky with large white clouds.
images.caption: Many people are surprised by the first glimpse of the historic ranch buildings.

images.title: Cattle Herd Moving
images.altText: Herd of cattle moving from back right to front left in front of historic buildings
images.caption: The ranch cattle herd contains Hereford, Shorthorn and Texas Longhorn, which were popular breeds during the Open Range Cattle Era

images.title: Cowboy on Horseback with Cattle
images.altText: Historic buildings surround fenced pasture, cattle being moved by cowboy on horseback toward viewer.
images.caption: The American Cowboy developed during the Open Range Era and became a cultural icon.

parks.weatherInfo: Spring: Temperatures can fluctuate greatly. Sub-freezing temperatures in the morning can give way to mild days. Snow in early spring, rain in late season. Summer: Temperatures can average 70-80 F, but can reach highs of 100 F. Rain rare. Dry and hot. Fall: Temperatures can fluctuate greatly. Sub-freezing mornings can give way to mild days. Rain in early fall likely. Winter: Temperature can fall to -30 F, with highs of 10-20 F. Snow is possible. Cold weather gear is highly recommended.
parks.name: Grant-Kohrs Ranch

parks.description: From the 13,063-foot summit of Wheeler Peak, to the sage-covered foothills, Great Basin National Park is a place to sample the stunning diversity of the larger Great Basin region. Come and partake of the solitude of the wilderness, walk among ancient bristlecone pines, bask in the darkest of night skies, and explore mysterious subterranean passages. There's a whole lot more than just desert here!

entranceFees.description: Great Basin National Park has no entrance fees.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

parks.directionsInfo: From the East or West: From U.S. Highway 6 & 50, turn south on Nevada State Highway 487 and travel 5 miles to Baker, NV. In Baker turn west on Highway 488 and travel 5 miles to the park. From the South (Utah): Travel north on Utah State Highway 21 through Milford, UT and Garrison, UT, Highway 487. Turn west on Highway 488 in Baker and travel 5 miles to the park. From the South (Nevada): Travel north on U.S. Highway 93. No public transportation is available to, or in, Great Basin National Park.

operatingHours.description: Park Grounds and Trails
operatingHours.name: Great Basin National Park

images.title: Wheeler cirque
images.altText: blue sky with green trees in mountain cirque
images.caption: Trail to ancient bristlecone pine trees.

images.title: Bristlecone at night
images.altText: Bristlecone pine tree with a dark blue sky behind it with a bright Jupiter shining
images.caption: Planets like Jupiter shine bright at Great Basin

images.title: Lehman Caves Grand Palace Parachute formation
images.altText: Brown and tan cave formation in the shape of a parachute
images.caption: Lehman Caves of Great Basin National Park offers incredible views of a rare subterranean world.

images.title: Milky Way at Great Basin National Park
images.altText: Colorful Milky Way over the red lit Lehman Caves Visitor Center
images.caption: Come see the Milky Way at Great Basin National Park. Remember to check the moon phase.

images.title: Great Basin Visitor Center
images.altText: Tan and green Visitor center with mountains in the background.
images.caption: Great Basin Visitor Center just six miles from the park entrance

images.title: Alpine Flowers
images.altText: White, yellow,, and pink alpine flowers.
images.caption: Flowers grow even at the high altitudes of the Great Basin National Park

images.title: Golden Eagle
images.altText: Golden Eagle flying with wings spread wide
images.caption: Wildlife is abundant at Great Basin National Park including birds, deer, fish, and mountain lion.

images.title: Snow Covered Mountains
images.altText: Snow covered mountains with brown trees in the foreground
images.caption: Snow can come early, even in the fall at Great Basin.

images.title: Comet NEOWISE
images.altText: Ancient bristlecone with comet NEOWISE in the background
images.caption: Great Basin National Park offers truly dark-skies that rarely seen within the United States.

parks.weatherInfo: There is almost an 8,000 ft (2,400 m) difference in elevation between Wheeler Peak and the valley floor. Weather conditions in the park vary with elevation. In late spring and early summer, days in the valley may be hot, yet the snow pack may not have melted in the higher elevations. The Great Basin is a desert, with low relative humidity and sharp drops in temperature at night. In the summer, fierce afternoon thunderstorms are common. It can snow any time of the year at high elevations.
parks.name: Great Basin

parks.description: The River gradually widens as it picks up the waters of 17 tributaries on its way to Great Egg Harbor and the Atlantic Ocean. Established by Congress in 1992, nearly all of this 129-mile river system rests within the Pinelands National Reserve. This National Park Service unit is unusual in that local jurisdictions continue to administer the lands.

entranceFees.description: The Great Egg Harbor River is fee free. For details and information, visit, http://www.rivers.gov/rivers/great-egg-harbor.php.
entranceFees.title: Great Egg Harbor River Fees

parks.directionsInfo: Estell Manor Park, where visitors can see the Great Egg Harbor National Scenic and Recreational River, is located 3.5 miles South of Mays Landing, New Jersey, off of Route 50. It is approximately 17 miles west of Atlantic City. There is a stamper for Passport Stamp Books at the Fox Nature Center, and a stamp can be obtained at the mailing address provided below.

operatingHours.description: The Great Egg Harbor River is a 55.0-mile-long (88.5 km) river in southern New Jersey in the United States. It is one of the major rivers that traverse the largely pristine Pinelands, draining 308 square miles (800 km2) of wetlands into the Atlantic Ocean at Great Egg Harbor, from which it takes its name. At river location in Estell Manor Park - please check (609) 625-1897 for hours.
operatingHours.name: Great Egg Harbor River Hours

addresses.line1: Great Egg Harbor National Scenic and Recreational River

images.title: Great Egg Harbor River
images.altText: Still river in the winter with leafless trees on either side
images.caption: Great Egg Harbor River downstream from Mill Street (New Jersey Route 559) in Mays Landing, New Jersey

images.title: Gibson Creek
images.altText: Sun setting over the river.
images.caption: Gibson Creek

images.title: Floating Classrooms
images.altText: School group examines a fish held by the instructor.
images.caption: Students learn about river resources on a floating classroom.

images.title: Haley's Comet over the Great Egg Harbor River
images.altText: Bright white comet in the early night sky reflects over the river.
images.caption: Haley's Comet over the Great Egg Harbor River

images.title: Great Egg Harbor River
images.altText: Winding river surrounded by grasslands on a cloudy day.
images.caption: The Great Egg Harbor River

images.title: Tuckahoe Osprey
images.altText: Medium sized Osprey in a next along the river
images.caption: Tuckahoe Osprey

parks.weatherInfo: Temperate, with a moderating influence of the Atlantic Ocean.
parks.name: Great Egg Harbor River

parks.description: At Great Falls, the Potomac River builds up speed and force as it falls over a series of steep, jagged rocks and flows through the narrow Mather Gorge. The Patowmack Canal offers a glimpse into the early history of this country. Great Falls Park has many opportunities to explore history and nature, all in a beautiful 800-acre park only 15 miles from the Nation's Capital.

emailAddresses.description: GWMP Superintendent

entranceFees.description: 7-day pass. Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle and all its passengers. Organized groups are not eligible for the vehicle permit. Is also valid for entrance into the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls Entrance Fee - Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Admits one single private motorcycle and its passengers. Individuals 15 years of age and younger are admitted free of charge. Also valid for entrance into the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls Entrance Fee- Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual when entering by foot, bicycle, or equestrian. Individuals 15 years old and younger are admitted free of charge. Is also valid for entrance into the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park.
entranceFees.title: Great Falls Entrance Fee - Person

entrancePasses.description: Valid for twelve months from the date of purchase. Pass is valid at Great Falls Park and Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park for entrance fee only. Admits the pass holder and occupants of a single, private non-commercial vehicle OR pass holder and three persons (16 and older) where per person entrance fees are charged.
entrancePasses.title: Great Falls Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: From I-495, take exit 44 for route 193 west; continue 4 miles. Turn right on Old Dominion Drive.

operatingHours.description: Great Falls Park is open until 30 minutes after sunset.  This time varies each day.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.title: Great Falls
images.altText: Water rushes over jagged rocks
images.caption: The Potomac River rushes down the Great Falls on the Virginia-Maryland border.

parks.weatherInfo: The Washington, D.C. area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy. Precipitation averages 2-4” monthly, year-round.
parks.name: Great Falls

parks.fullName: Great Sand Dunes National Park & Preserve
parks.description: Open 24/7 year round! There are no reservations to visit or limit on the number of visitors in the park and preserve, but there is currently limited capacity in the visitor center. The tallest dunes in North America are the centerpiece in a diverse landscape of grasslands, wetlands, forests, alpine lakes, and tundra. Explore this website to learn more!

emailAddresses.description: Email a ranger to get your questions answered.

entranceFees.description: Passenger vehicle with all occupants; fee valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Non-Commercial Vehicle and Occupants

entranceFees.description: Per passenger, 16 years and older in oversized vehicle, including 15 passenger vans, small buses, etc. Valid for 7 days. Passengers under 16 are free.
entranceFees.title: Oversized Vehicle, 15+ passengers, age 16+

entranceFees.description: One motorcycle and all its riders; valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle and Riders

entrancePasses.description: Covers one family's entrance for 12 months from time of purchase. Valid for two adults with signatures plus others in vehicle.
entrancePasses.title: Great Sand Dunes Annual Family Pass

parks.directionsInfo: To access the main park area, including the Dunes Parking Lot, Visitor Center, and Pinon Flats Campground, take US 160 to CO 150 from the south, or CO 17 to Lane 6 to CO 150 from the west. The national park is at the north end of CO 150.

operatingHours.description: The park and preserve are open 24/7 all year
operatingHours.name: Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve

images.title: Dunes and Crestone Peaks at Sunset
images.altText: Grasslands, large dunes, and snow-capped peaks at sunset
images.caption: The view at the park entrance contrasts giant dunes and snow-capped mountains.

images.title: Girls Sand Sledding
images.altText: Girls Sand Sledding
images.caption: Rent specially designed sand sleds to slide on the dry sand.  Note: cardboard, snow sleds, saucers, and other items don't slide on dry sand.

images.title: Elk, Grasslands, Dunes, and Sangre de Cristo Mountains
images.altText: Elk, Grasslands, Dunes, and Sangre de Cristo Mountains
images.caption: Elk are sometimes seen by visitors along the park entrance road or County Lane 6, primarily fall through spring.

images.title: Lower Sand Creek Lake, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Lower Sand Creek Lake, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Spectacular alpine lakes are part of the backcountry of Great Sand Dunes National Preserve

images.title: Upper Sand Creek Basin, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Upper Sand Creek Basin, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Sand Creek Basin, part of Great Sand Dunes National Preserve, contains lush forests and alpine lakes.

images.title: Fall Colors Along Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.altText: Fall Colors Along Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.caption: Fall is a pretty time to visit the park, with great colors and generally nice weather.

images.title: Gold Cottonwoods, Dunes, and Cleveland Peak
images.altText: Gold cottonwood trees, large dunes, a silver cloud, and snow-capped mountain
images.caption: Experiencing Great Sand Dunes in the quieter seasons of fall and winter can be a rewarding experience.

images.title: Girl Floating Medano Creek
images.altText: A teen girl sits on a floatation device
images.caption: Visitors can float Medano Creek's waves during late spring peak flow, in years of good snowpack

parks.weatherInfo: Temperatures are relatively cool all year, thanks to the park and preserve's high elevation. Conditions are most often calm, but winds can arise, especially in spring and during storm fronts. Daytime temperatures feel warmer here year round due to intense high-altitude sunlight, and a scorching mid-day summer sand surface. Plan to explore the dunes morning or evening during summer. Nights are cool in summer, and frigid in winter. Visit the Great Sand Dunes website for the most accurate weather forecasts.
parks.name: Great Sand Dunes

parks.description: Ridge upon ridge of forest straddles the border between North Carolina and Tennessee in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. World renowned for its diversity of plant and animal life, the beauty of its ancient mountains, and the quality of its remnants of Southern Appalachian mountain culture, this is America's most visited national park.

entranceFees.description: Great Smoky Mountains National Park does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Great Smoky Mountains National Park straddles the borders of the states of Tennessee and North Carolina. The three main entrances to the park are in the Gatlinburg, TN; Townsend, TN; and Cherokee, NC.

operatingHours.description: Primary roads are open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, year-round, weather permitting. This includes Newfound Gap Road (US-441), Little River Road, and Laurel Creek Road. Secondary roads are closed seasonally.
operatingHours.name: Great Smoky Mountains National Park

operatingHours.description: Cades Cove Loop Road is open to motor vehicles from sunrise until sunset daily. Pedestrians and bicyclists may access the road 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Cades Cove

images.title: Frosty Morning in Cades Cove
images.altText: A thick layer of frost covers the fields, trees, and mountains in Cades Cove.
images.caption: Wintertime brings a quiet beauty to the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.title: "Smoke" Rising From the Mountains
images.altText: Wisps of fog hang over the forests in the mountains.
images.caption: The park gets its name from mists that often rise like smoke from the mountains.

images.title: A Foggy Morning at Cades Cove Methodist Church
images.altText: Tombstones stand in front of a white, wooden church on a foggy morning.
images.caption: Historic buildings such as churches, gristmills, barns, and homes allow visitors to get a feel for life in the mountains before the national park was created.

images.title: The Waters of Roaring Fork Below Grotto Falls
images.altText: Rhododendron bushes line the banks of a stream filled with large boulders.
images.caption: Abundant rainfall means lush forests and beautiful stream scenes in the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.title: The "Wildflower National Park"
images.altText: A hillside in the forest covered with white trillium flowers
images.caption: Wildflowers, such as these white trillium, can be found blooming from February through November in the park.

images.title: Fall Colors Near Newfound Gap
images.altText: Bright gold and red leaves shine through the fog in a forest.
images.caption: Fall leaf season is one of the busiest times of year in the park.

images.title: Fall Meets Winter
images.altText: Gold and red fall colors fill the valleys while snow coats the mountain tops.
images.caption: In spring and fall, weather in the foothills can be pleasant, while snow and cold rule on the mountain tops.

parks.weatherInfo: Elevations in the park range from approximately 875 feet to 6,643 feet and the topography can drastically affect local weather. Temperatures can vary 10-20 degrees Fahrenheit from mountain base to top, and clear skies lower down do not guarantee equally pleasant weather at higher elevations. Visit http://www.nps.gov/grsm/planyourvisit/weather.htm for seasonal weather information and links to local forecasts.
parks.name: Great Smoky Mountains

parks.description: Green Springs National Historic Landmark District in Virginia’s Piedmont encompasses over 14,000 acres. Its landscapes and structures, privately owned today but viewable from public roads, offer a continuum of rural vernacular architecture with minimal alteration. Many of the farmsteads, often dating to the 19th century and connecting to one another visually, are preserved through easements.

entranceFees.description: The land and buildings within the District are privately owned.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance

parks.directionsInfo: Green Springs National Historic Landmark District is privately owned, includes no public facilities, but is visible from public highways. It sits astride Route 15 in Louisa County, Virginia.

operatingHours.description: The land and buildings within the District are privately owned
operatingHours.name: No Public Access

parks.description: Greenbelt Park is located in suburban Greenbelt, Maryland. Visit to enjoy affordable camping, peaceful surroundings and National Park Service hospitality. Greenbelt Park has a 174 site campground, nine miles of trails and three picnic areas.

entranceFees.description: Greenbelt Park does not have an entrance fee
entranceFees.title: Greenbelt Park Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Off I-95 South Take Exit 23 Route 201 Kenilworth Avenue South(toward Bladensburg). (this will be a left). Drive on Kenilworth Avenue (Route 201). Once crossing over I-95, you will see sign for Route 193 Greenbelt Road. Veer right to Take Route 193 East. Take a left on Greenbelt Road . (Greenbelt Road is Route 193 and is an overpass over Route 201) The park entrance is a quarter mile on the right hand side.

exceptions.name: Park and Campground closed until Late Summer 2021

operatingHours.description: The campground is closed for a park paving, bridge construction and water and sewer project. We will reopen in Spring 2021.

operatingHours.description: Sweetgum Picnic area is a non reserved picnic located in Greenbelt Park, Maryland. It is first come first serve for groups of twenty five or less. Each group can use up to a maximum of four tables.  Sweetgum Picnic area has accessible bathroom facilities.
