parks.weatherInfo: On average, the warmest month is July and the highest recorded temperature was 105F in 1934. The coolest month is January, with the lowest recorded temperature of -25F in 1985. June sees the most precipitation with an average rainfall of 4.66 Inches.
parks.name: Indiana Dunes

parks.description: Explore a rugged, isolated island, far from the sights and sounds of civilization. Surrounded by Lake Superior, Isle Royale offers unparalleled solitude and adventures for backpackers, hikers, boaters, kayakers, canoeists and scuba divers. Here, amid stunning scenic beauty, you'll find opportunities for reflection and discovery, and make memories that last a lifetime.

entranceFees.description:
The daily entrance fee is  $7 per person. It is charged to enter or remain within the park per calendar day (it includes the day you arrive and the day you depart the park). Pay this fee after your transportation reservations have been confirmed. 

All Federal Recreation Passes (Annual, Senior, Access, Military) are honored. Entrance fees will be waived for the pass holder and up to 3 adults traveling with the pass holder.

Children ages 15 and under are exempt from paying entrance fees.
entranceFees.title: Isle Royale Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: Valid from April 16 - October 31 of the year indicated. Covers the entrance fee ($7 per person per day) for the person whose signature appears on the pass and up to 3 adults (aged 16 and up) traveling with the pass holder. Non-refundable and non-transferable. Can be obtained in-person from the Houghton, Rock Harbor, or Windigo Visitor Centers or online at www.pay.gov, search Isle Royale Season Pass and click on "Continue to Form."
entrancePasses.title: Isle Royale Season Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Isle Royale National Park headquarters is located in Houghton, MI. Visit the Houghton page on the Isle Royale National Park website for additional information and a map on how to access the visitor center.

operatingHours.description: Isle Royale National Park is open annually from April 16 to October 31. Transportation services are offered from May to September. The island and its surrounding islands are closed to all visitors from November 1 to April 15 due to extreme winter weather conditions and for the safety and protection of visitors. This closure extends 4.5 miles out into Lake Superior from the island. Park headquarters during the winter is in Houghton, Michigan. Summer headquarters is located at Mott Island on Isle Royale.
operatingHours.name: Isle Royale National Park Open Season (April 16 through October 31)

images.title: Duncan Bay Narrows
images.altText: View from above the trees looking down at Duncan Bay Narrows, trees, Lake Superior, and Canada.
images.caption: Isle Royale, located in the northwestern corner of Lake Superior, offers views of the Canadian shoreline.

images.title: Winter Ice Floes
images.altText: Ice floes float in a harbor
images.caption: Isle Royale National Park is closed in winter, with the exception of a few visiting researchers.

images.title: Aerial View of Belle Harbor
images.altText: Aerial View of Belle Harbor
images.caption: One of the best ways to view Isle Royale's land and water is from the air.

images.title: Bull Moose
images.altText: Young bull moose browsing for food
images.caption: Moose are one of the few mammal species who have journeyed to the island.

images.title: Rock of Ages Lighthouse
images.altText: Aerial view of Rock of Ages Lighthouse
images.caption: Rock of Ages is one of four lighthouses at Isle Royale National Park.

images.title: Aurora Borealis Over Isle Royale National Park
images.altText: Diverse colored Aurora Borealis in the night sky
images.caption: Isle Royale National Park's dark skies make it an excellent location to enjoy nighttime phenomenon, like the Aurora Borealis.

parks.weatherInfo: Isle Royale National Park is a remote island wilderness in the middle of Lake Superior. Weather influences traveling to and from the island, as well as your trip once you arrive. For the most up-to-date weather information, call (906) 482-0984 or email isro_parkinfo@nps.gov prior to your trip.
parks.name: Isle Royale

parks.description: On the rooftop of the world, the Iñupiat Heritage Center in Barrow, Alaska, tells the story of the Iñupiat people. They have thrived for thousands of years in one of the harshest climates on Earth, hunting the bowhead, or "Agviq." In the 19th century, these lonely seas swarmed with commercial whalemen from New England, who also sought the bowhead for its valuable baleen and blubber.
parks.directionsInfo: The Inupiat Heritage Center is located in Barrow, Alaska, the largest city in the North Slope Borough and the northernmost city in the United States. Barrow can be reached via commercial and charter flights from Anchorage and Fairbanks.

images.title: Clothing of the Inupiaq
images.altText: Museum exhibit case with fur parkas and boots
images.caption: Traditional clothing of the Inupiaq on exhibit at the Center

images.credit: Photo courtesy of Inupiat Heritage Center
images.title: Waiting for whales
images.altText: Two people sit by a tent and a skin canoe in snow next to the ocean.
images.caption: A whaling crew (Hopson 1) waits patiently at the open lead for a bowhead whale, May 2002.

images.title: Inupiat Heritage Center
images.altText: Large building with words "Inupiat Heritage Center" on the side
images.caption: The Inupiat Heritage Center promotes Inupiaq culture, history and language through exhibits, classes, performances and activities.

images.title: Inupiaq whalers
images.altText: Five people in heavy clothing paddle a skin canoe in icy waters

images.title: Masks
images.altText: Five masks with fur trim in a display case.
images.caption: A collection of masks from the Inupiat Heritage Center

parks.weatherInfo: Owing to its location 320 miles (515 km) north of the Arctic Circle, Barrow's climate is cold and dry, classified as a polar climate (Köppen ET). Winter weather can be extremely dangerous because of the combination of cold and wind, while summers are cool even at their warmest.
parks.name: Iñupiat Heritage Center

parks.fullName: James A Garfield National Historic Site
parks.description: A front porch can serve many purposes. For some, it is a place to enjoy the breeze on a warm summer night. For others, a perch from which to keep eyes on what's happening in their neighborhood. In 1880, James Garfield used his front porch as a platform to greet thousands of well-wishers during his presidential campaign. Today, the porch serves as a gateway to the story of the Garfield family.

entranceFees.description: Visitors 16 years and above are $10/person. The entrance fee allows each visitor to take a guided tour of the Garfield Home. Reservations are now required for guided tours. Group size per tour is limited to 7 visitors per every hours from 10:15 a.m. to 4:15 p.m. Please call the site at (440) 255-8722 to reserve your tour beginning June 1, 2021.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: 15 and under are FREE!
entranceFees.title: Youth 15 and under

parks.directionsInfo: From Interstate 90 - exit at Route 306 and head north to Route 20. East on Route 20 about 1.5 miles. Site is on north side of Mentor Avenue. From Route 2 - exit at Route 306 and head south to Route 20. East on Route 20 about 1.5 miles. Site is on the north side of Mentor Avenue.

operatingHours.description:
The grounds at James A. Garfield National Historic Site are open 8am-4:30pm year-round, with a few holiday closures (see "Closures and Seasonal Exceptions" below for holiday exceptions). The Visitor Center and Garfield Home are now open daily 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.

Beginning June 1, 2021 the Garfield Home will be reopening for guided tours. Reservations are REQUIRED for tours. Call (440) 255-8722 for more.
operatingHours.name: Grounds at James A. Garfield National Historic Site

images.title: The Front Porch, Garfield Home
images.altText: Front porch of Garfield home showing red front door
images.caption: The front porch of James Garfield's home was the scene of the first front porch campaign. The presidential candidate gave patriotic speeches and met with thousands of people who came to which him well during the summer and fall of 1880.

images.title: Carriage House
images.altText: Carriage House entrance from the south
images.caption: The Carriage House, built in 1894, was repurposed by the National Park Service to become a modern visitor center. It was part of a $12.5 million restoration in the 1990's.

images.title: Visitor Center, Main Entrance
images.altText: Visitor Center main entrance off the parking lot.
images.caption: A friendly greeting awaits visitors who enter the Visitor Center. This historic building, constructed in 1894, serves as bookstore, exhibit gallery and auditorium where the park film is shown. Tickets for tours of the Garfield home are also available her

images.title: James A. Garfield National Historic Site
images.altText: a large gray house with a red roof
images.caption: Thousands to visitors came to this front porch to hear presidential candidate James A. Garfield speak in 1880.

images.title: Library addition, north side
images.altText: A view of the memorial library addition through the trees.
images.caption: Mrs. Garfield constructed a beautiful addition to the Garfield home following the President's assassination in 1881. These 9 rooms contain the first Presidential Memorial Library,  including the a fireproof vault which once contained Garfield's papers.

images.title: Hand-painted Fireplace Tile, Garfield Dining Room
images.altText: Hand-painted tile shows a bird next with blue eggs
images.caption: Mrs. Garfield was known for her artistic talent, which softly blankets the interior of the Garfield home. In particular, the dining room boasts two tiles which were hand-painted by Mrs. Garfield, surround by others done by her children.

parks.weatherInfo: Winter tends to be cold with snow and ice from January - early March. Summers are comfortable, but can be humid and reach into the 90's. There is a 100 yard walk between the Visitor Center and Garfield home; visitors are advised to check weather conditions prior to their visit.
parks.name: James A Garfield

parks.fullName: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
parks.description: In Jean Lafitte's day, silver and gold filled a pirate's treasure chest, but today's treasures are people, places, and memories. Discover New Orleans’ rich cultural mix. Learn Cajun traditions from people who live them. Watch an alligator bask on a bayou’s bank. Walk in the footsteps of the men who fought at 1815’s Battle of New Orleans. Follow the link to discover the treasure of Jean Lafitte.

entranceFees.description: Admission to park visitor centers is always free. Most park programs are free; any fees are always noted on program descriptions. We do not sell the Park Pass at any of our sites, but you can buy one online at  https://www.nps.gov/planyourvisit/passes.htm
entranceFees.title: Admission and Program Fees

parks.directionsInfo: Jean Lafitte's headquarters and the park's French Quarter Visitor Center is located at 419 Decatur St. in New Orleans. There are five other park sites scattered throughout south Louisiana. For information on all of the park sites and visitor centers, see the Directions URL.

operatingHours.description: Each of Jean Lafitte's six sites is open year-round, but each has different operating hours and days. See the specific site(s) you want to visit for operating hours and days information.
operatingHours.name: Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve

images.title: Barataria Preserve of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: Spanish moss hangs from live oak tree
images.caption: Spanish moss and lush vegetation provide glimpses of Louisiana's wild wetlands at Jean Lafitte's Barataria Preserve.

images.title: Chalmete Battlefield at Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: An oak tree arches over a cannon-guarded rampart with historic house and American flag in background
images.caption: Chalmette Battlefield's American rampart and cannons still guard the site of the Battle of New Orleans in 1815.

images.title: Chalmette National Cemetery at Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: Setting sun lights up cemetery headstones
images.caption: Established during the Civil War, Chalmette National Cemetery's 14,000+ headstones pay tribute to those buried there.

images.title: French Quarter Visitor Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: Visitor center exhibit titled "Crossroads of Cultures"
images.caption: Hundreds of years of history and thousands of people from all over the world have created New Orleans' distinctive cultural mix.

images.title: Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: Model of an early Acadian home sits in a glass case
images.caption: Bringing skills and traditions from Nova Scotia, the Acadian exiles in Louisiana found a new home and a new name---Cajuns.

images.title: Wetlands Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: Exhibit case full of musical instruments
images.caption: Acadian (Cajun) music began in cabins and dancehalls and has become famous worldwide.

images.title: Prairie Acadian Cultural Center of Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve
images.altText: guitar sits on a dimly lit porch styled stage
images.caption: The Music Porch at the Prairie Acadian Cultural Center in Eunice, LA

parks.weatherInfo: All temperatures in degrees Fahrenheit. Note that relative humidity, especially in summer months, can reach 90%, so temperatures can feel 10-20 degrees hotter than actual temperature. Spring (March, April, May) average high 77, low 61 Summer (June, July, August) average high 89, low 75 Fall (September, October, November) average high 78, low 64 Winter (December, January, February) average high 64, low 48
parks.name: Jean Lafitte

parks.description: Immerse yourself within the third longest cave in the world. With over 208 miles of mapped and surveyed passages, this underground wilderness appeals to human curiosity. Its splendor is revealed through fragile formations and glimpses of brilliant color. Its maze of passages lure explorers, and its scientific wealth remains a mystery. This resource is truly a jewel in the National Park Service.

emailAddresses.description: This email address connects online guests with staff at the visitor center. Every effort is made to respond to common questions and requests for information within 48 hours. However, some questions or requests for assistance may require input from other staff. In these instances, requests will be forwarded to the appropriate individual for a direct response.

parks.directionsInfo: By car: Jewel Cave National Monument is located 13 miles west of Custer, South Dakota and 24 miles east of Newcastle, Wyoming on U.S. Highway 16. The monument is about 54 miles from Rapid City, South Dakota via U.S. Highway 16 / 385. By plane: The nearest major airport, Rapid City Regional Airport, is 63 miles away.

exceptions.name: Holiday Closures - Martin Luther King, Jr. Day
Spring Season Hours / Early April through Late May
Fall Season Hours / Early September through Late October
Winter Season - Late October to Early April

operatingHours.description: Jewel Cave National Monument is a day-use area and is available for outdoor recreation on a daily basis throughout the year. However, although the monument is normally open for surface activities year round, the visitor center, park store, and ranger-guided cave tours and operational hours vary from season to season. This means that the surface features and recreational areas are open year round, yet staffing levels and visitor services may be limited during the off-season.
operatingHours.name: Jewel Cave National Monument

images.title: Target Room
images.altText: The target room inside Jewel Cave.
images.caption: The target room inside Jewel Cave.

images.title: Hourglass Lake
images.altText: A cave explorer sits on some rocks and looks at a clear blue lake in Jewel Cave.
images.caption: Volunteer cave explorers discovered Hourglass Lake in October 2015, the first sizable body of water found within Jewel Cave.

images.title: Inner Sanctum
images.altText: A park ranger is standing on a metal platform within a long passageway with a vaulted ceiling.
images.caption: The Inner Sanctum is one of the longest and largest passageways along the Scenic Tour route, located near the Torture Room.

images.title: The Brain Drain
images.altText: A caver squeezes through a very small and tight opening, surrounded by multi-colored rocks.
images.caption: The Brain Drain is approximately eight inches high by 24 inches wide and is the tightest passage on the Wild Caving Tour.

images.title: The Heavenly Room
images.altText: A park ranger stands as a silhouette in a large room in Jewel Cave.
images.caption: The Heavenly Room is a large room along the Historic Lantern Tour within the historic entrance of Jewel Cave.

images.title: Nailhead Spar
images.altText: White-colored crystals with blunt tips sparkle against a black background.
images.caption: Calcite crystals, such as nailhead spar, cover most of the walls, ceilings, and floors within Jewel Cave.

images.title: Rocky Mountain Bighorn Sheep
images.altText: A bighorn sheep ram stands in the highway, with a camper stopped in the other lane.
images.caption: Rocky mountain bighorn sheep are commonly seen within the monument, usually along Highway 16.

images.title: Red Squirrel
images.altText: A small red squirrel stands on a dead pine branch.
images.caption: Red squirrels are commonly observed along the Roof Trail near the visitor center.

images.title: Fall Season Foliage in Fog
images.altText: Fog filters through a stand of pine trees, with red and yellow foliage on the forest floor.
images.caption: Autumn is a beautiful time of year to visit the monument. The colors of fall are often the best during mid to late September.

images.title: Winter in the Pines
images.altText: Snow covers the ground and flocks pine trees.
images.caption: Although a "slower" time of year, the winter season offers some of the best scenery of the ponderosa pine forest.

images.title: Canyons Trail Descending toward the Historic Entrance
images.altText: A paved path with steps heads down a hillside, with rock overhangs and pine trees nearby.
images.caption: A portion of the Canyons Trail passes the historic entrance of Jewel Cave, with breathtaking views of nearby Hell Canyon.

images.title: Theodore Roosevelt Addresses an Audience
images.altText: A look-alike Theodore Roosevelt speaks to visitors on the patio of the visitor center.
images.caption: The monument hosts special events each summer, such as living history presentations of President Theodore Roosevelt.

images.title: The Ranger Cabin at Jewel Cave
images.altText: A small, dark-brown cabin sits on top of a hill with a walking path leading to its front porch.
images.caption: The original park ranger cabin, built during the 1930s, is available for public access during the summer and early fall seasons.

images.title: Visitor Center Exhibit Area
images.altText: A wall mural showing red-colored rock transitions into a room with a large cave map on the wall.
images.caption: The visitor center provides several engaging exhibits and displays about the resources within the monument.

images.title: Pasque Flowers in Bloom
images.altText: White to light purple flowers with yellow centers poke through pine needles.
images.caption: Jewel Cave is home to several species of wildflowers, such as the South Dakota State Flower - the pasque flower.

images.title: Bats at Jewel Cave
images.altText: A small brown bat rests on a red-orange colored rock.
images.caption: Nine species of bats live within Jewel Cave National Monument. At times, visitors may see bats outside the historic entrance.

parks.weatherInfo: Weather in the Black Hills varies significantly throughout the year and may be drastically different from the northern hills to the southern hills. The temperatures listed are for average lows to average highs in the location of Custer, South Dakota. Spring ~ Temp. Range of 29F to 53F / Summer ~ Temp. Range of 54F to 80F / Fall ~ Temp. Range of 33F to 58F / Winter ~ Temp. Range of 14F to 37F The yearly average rain is 19 inches, with May being the wettest month. The yearly average snow is 48 inches.
parks.name: Jewel Cave

parks.description: Few U.S. Presidents have had such close ties with where they were born and raised. The rural southern culture of Plains, Georgia, that revolves around farming, church and school, had a large influence in molding the character and in shaping the political policies of the 39th President of the United States.

entranceFees.description: The Jimmy Carter National Historic Site consists of three locations: Plains High School Visitor Center, Plains Depot, and The Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm. All locations are fee free.
entranceFees.title: The Jimmy Carter National Historic Site is fee free.

parks.directionsInfo: In Americus take US 280W/ W Forsyth St. until it becomes US-19 S/US-280 W/S Martin Luther King Blvd. Turn left and go .08 mile. Turn right onto US-280 W and travel 8.9 miles. Turn right onto North Bond Street/ Hwy 45 North. Plains High School will be on the right side of the road 500 feet from the intersection.

operatingHours.description: The main visitor center for the Jimmy Carter National Historic Site
operatingHours.name: Plains High School Museum and Visitor Center

operatingHours.description: The 1976 headquarters for Jimmy Carter's Presidential Campaign,
operatingHours.name: Plains Depot

operatingHours.description: The farm where Jimmy Carter lived from 1928 until 1941. His father, Earl Carter, later sold this farm in 1949.
operatingHours.name: The Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm

images.title: Jimmy Carter's Boyhood Home
images.altText: A picture of the front of the home Jimmy Carter lived in as a young boy.
images.caption: Front view of the Jimmy Carter Boyhood Home in Archery, Georgia.

images.title: Plains High School Museum and Visitors Center
images.altText: Front view of Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum
images.caption: Almost one hundred thousand visitors visit Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum yearly.

images.title: Plains Depot, 1976 Campaign Headquarters
images.altText: The Plains train depot that President Carter used as the 1976 campaign headquarters.
images.caption: The oldest building in Plains, the train depot, was used as the 1976 campaign headquarters for President Carter.

images.title: Jimmy Carter Presidents' Day 2016
images.altText: Jimmy Carter speaking to the crowd; Presidents' Day 2016
images.caption: President Jimmy Carter speaking to the crowd at Plains High School for Presidents' Day 2016

images.title: Rosalynn Carter, Presidents' Day 2016
images.altText: Rosalynn Carter signing a book, Presidents' Day 2016
images.caption: Rosalynn Carter signing a book she authored during Presidents' Day 2016

parks.weatherInfo: Weather in Southwest Georgia can change in the blink of an eye during the summer months. Thunderstorms and high temperatures can make it unpleasant for visitors. Check the local forecast and dress appropriately.
parks.name: Jimmy Carter

parks.fullName: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument
parks.description: Colorful rock formations at John Day Fossil Beds preserve a world class record of plant and animal evolution, changing climate, and past ecosystems that span over 40 million years. Exhibits and a working lab at the Thomas Condon Paleontology and Visitor Center as well as scenic drives and hikes at all three units allow visitors to explore the prehistoric past of Oregon and see science in action.

entranceFees.description: There are no entry fees at John Day Fossil Beds National Monument.
entranceFees.title: No entrance fees at John Day Fossil Beds National Monument

parks.directionsInfo: John Day Fossil Beds encompasses 14,000 acres in three geographically separated units in Oregon: Sheep Rock, Painted Hills, and Clarno. The Sheep Rock Unit is located between the towns of Dayville and Kimberly. The Painted Hills Unit is located 9 miles northwest of of the town of Mitchell. The Clarno Unit is located on Highway 218 twenty miles west of the town of Fossil.

operatingHours.description: All outdoor recreation opportunities in the park are open daily from sunrise to sunset, including all overlooks and hiking trails at the park’s three units: Sheep Rock, Painted Hills, and Clarno.
operatingHours.name: Outdoor Recreation Areas

images.title: Sheep Rock
images.altText: Sheep Rock
images.caption: Sheep Rock, with the John Day River in the foreground

images.title: Painted Hills
images.altText: Painted Hills
images.caption: The Painted Hills on a stormy winter day.

images.title: Clarno
images.altText: Clarno
images.caption: The Clarno Palisades are remains of ancient volcanic mudslides.

images.title: Paleontologist at work
images.altText: Paleontologist at work
images.caption: The Thomas Condon Paleontology Center is both a visitor center and research center.

images.title: Historic James Cant Ranch Home
images.altText: White house surrounded by green with concrete path leading to the front
images.caption: Cant Ranch home

parks.weatherInfo: Weather conditions at John Day Fossil Beds National Monument are highly variable in this semi-arid desert landscape. Summer highs can climb into the 110's. Winters tend to be fairly mild, with occassional snow and ice and lows occasionally dipping into the single digits.
parks.name: John Day Fossil Beds

parks.fullName: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
parks.description: As a boy, JFK’s parents never expected he would grow up to be president. Yet in his birthplace home he learned values that inspired a life in public service. His mother, Rose Kennedy, recreated her family’s first home to share her memories of those early years with visitors. We commemorate not only his early life, but the ideas and principles he left behind.

entranceFees.description: All tours of the John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site are free of charge.
entranceFees.title: None

parks.directionsInfo: By Subway: Take Green line ("C" -Cleveland Circle) trolley to Coolidge Corner stop. Walk four blocks north on Harvard Street, turn right on Beals Street and continue to number 83. By Car: From Exit 18 (I-90 E) or Exit 20 (1-90 W) follow the Allston/Brighton exit ramp, merge onto Cambridge Street and go one mile. At the fourth light, turn left on Harvard Street and proceed about one mile. Turn left on Beals Street and go to number 83. Limited Street Parking available.

operatingHours.description: The site is closed through 2021 for Visitor Center renovations. The newly renovated Visitor Center will offer greater accessibility and make more efficient use of the space. Offsite programs, as they become available, will be listed on the park website.
operatingHours.name: Closed for Visitor Center Renovations

images.title: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
images.altText: John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site
images.caption: Photograph of the birthplace of John F. Kennedy on Beals st. in Brookline, MA

images.title: Nursery
images.altText: Room with white wicker furniture, including bassinet and rocking chair. Long white baby dress hangs.
images.caption: The Kennedy christening gown on a stand next to the bassinet in which all the Kennedy children slept, at the John F. Kennedy National Historic Site.

images.title: Kennedy Dining Room
images.altText: Dining room with oval dining table with six place settings of silver and fine china.
images.caption: The dining table is set with the fine china and silver that Rose Kennedy received as a wedding present.

parks.weatherInfo: Typical New England Weather: Warm, humid summers and cold winters. Any available outdoor programs take place rain or shine.
parks.name: John Fitzgerald Kennedy

parks.description: John Muir played many roles in his life, all of which helped him succeed in his role as an advocate for Nature. As America’s most famous naturalist and conservationist, Muir fought to protect the wild places he loved, places we can still visit today. Muir’s writings convinced the U.S. government to protect Yosemite, Sequoia, Grand Canyon and Mt. Rainier as national parks.

entranceFees.description: The John Muir National Historic Site and Mount Wanda are free to visit.
entranceFees.title: John Muir National Historic Site

entrancePasses.description: Passes are not require and are not sold at this location.

parks.weatherInfo: The Mediterranean climate of Martinez features hot, dry summers with lower temperatures near 60º F and upper temperatures near 100º F. The heat gives way to cool, rainy winters with lows near 45º F and highs near 75º F. Fall and spring can bring rain and temperatures from 55-80º F. March to April: wet/dry, 60-80º F May to September: very dry, 60-100º+ F October to November: dry/wet, 55-80º F December to February: wet, 45-75º F
parks.name: John Muir

parks.description: The South Fork dam failed on Friday, May 31, 1889 and unleashed 20,000,000 tons of water that devastated Johnstown, PA. The flood killed 2,209 people but it brought the nation and the world together to aid the "Johnstown sufferers." The story of the Johnstown Flood reminds us all, "...that we must leave nothing undone for the preservation and protection of our brother men."

entranceFees.description: Admission is free to visit the Johnstown Flood National Memorial, as well as all five Western Pennsylvania National Parks.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee.

entrancePasses.description: For US Citizens or Permanent Residents of any age who have a permanent disability (must bring proper documentation); good for life. This admits the guest and three additional adult guests in the party.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Take US Route 219 to the St Michael/Sidman exit. At the end of the exit ramp head East on PA 869 (there is a park sign at the end of the exit ramp). Travel approximately 1.5 miles on PA 869 watching for a left turn onto Lake Road at the sign for Johnstown Flood National Memorial. Follow Lake Road 1.5 miles until the visitor center appears on your right. Please park safely in the designated parking lot and not block any emergency access roads.

operatingHours.description:
The Lake View Visitor Center is open daily from 9 AM- 5 PM. 

The Lake View Visitor Center and theater are operating at 25% capacity. 

The Visitor Center is closed on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day. 

Park grounds and trails are open daily from sunrise to sunset.

"Standard Hours" reflects the hours of operation for the Visitor Center.
operatingHours.name: Johnstown Flood National Memorial

parks.weatherInfo: Winters can be cold and severe. Spring can be seasonable and wet. Summer can be hot with potentials for thunderstorms. Fall can be seasonal, with cold temperatures into October and November.
parks.name: Johnstown Flood

parks.description: Two distinct desert ecosystems, the Mojave and the Colorado, come together in Joshua Tree National Park. A fascinating variety of plants and animals make their homes in a land sculpted by strong winds and occasional torrents of rain. Dark night skies, a rich cultural history, and surreal geologic features add to the wonder of this vast wilderness in southern California. Come explore for yourself.
